href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=nHPTSxprnvQ:BElSyt3Exa4:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nHPTSxprnvQ:BElSyt3Exa4:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=nHPTSxprnvQ:BElSyt3Exa4:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nHPTSxprnvQ:BElSyt3Exa4:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=nHPTSxprnvQ:BElSyt3Exa4:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=nHPTSxprnvQ:BElSyt3Exa4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nHPTSxprnvQ:BElSyt3Exa4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/nHPTSxprnvQ\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 16:40:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fac57a998669500182b57f8?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7dca0dfe9687ce21df7fc1cc96c5412e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn28@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-04-386_e10b556ed1017ed7.webp","destWidth":5119,"destHeight":3840,"sourceBytes":314830,"destBytes":314830,"author":"tborden@businessinsider.com (Taylor Borden)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fac57a998669500182b57f8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn28@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-04-386_e10b556ed1017ed7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nHPTSxprnvQ:BElSyt3Exa4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn67@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-24-937_4d687bfeacb2dc9a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nHPTSxprnvQ:BElSyt3Exa4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn47@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-32-305_b5cded1c386a6575.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nHPTSxprnvQ:BElSyt3Exa4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn27@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-24-957_2d86a56b12c7ed1a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/nHPTSxprnvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn46@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-39-066_ab4a16f356bf8438.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991860},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Restaurants are setting up tents and temporary structures to extend outdoor dining during the winter. But they come with their own hazards, and in some cases, could be riskier than eating indoors.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/outdoor-dining-tent-safety-risks-explained-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faeb8501c741f0019ac9a9d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Outdoor dining tent\" height=\"2040\" width=\"2727\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Outdoor dining tents in New York City in October.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Noam Galai/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Bars and restaurants have set up tents and other temporary structures to prolong outdoor dining as temperatures drop in many parts of the US.&#160;</li>\n<li>But Jaimie Meyer, an infectious disease physician at Yale Medicine and associate professor at Yale School of Medicine, told Business Insider that enclosed outdoor spaces could be risky for customers.&#160;</li>\n<li>\"When you're making those outdoor spaces look a lot more like indoor spaces &#8212; so if they have, all of a sudden, three-and-a-half walls, or the air flow's not great, or there's lots of people still at a table, then you kind of get rid of all of the potential benefits of outside,\" Meyer said.</li>\n<li>Several cities and states have put rules in place for outdoor structures, mandating that 50% of the sides open and banning totally enclosed structures. In places like New York City, enclosed tents must be treated like indoor spaces and limited to 25% capacity.&#160;</li>\n<li>Totally enclosed tents and temporary buildings might even be riskier than dining inside a restaurant since they lack built-in ventilation systems to increase airflow, Meyer said.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>As the temperature drops in many parts of the US, restaurants are coming up with creative solutions to allow for outdoor dining. But in some cases, these solutions may increase diners' coronavirus risk.&#160;</p><p>Since the onset of the pandemic, outdoor dining has allowed restaurants and bars to stay open while offering customers a way to continue eating, drinking, and socializing in a low-risk environment. Outdoor dining has become so popular and lucrative that it's becoming a more permanent fixture everywhere from <a href=\"https://www.jsonline.com/story/money/real-estate/commercial/2020/10/21/extension-milwaukees-outdoor-dining-program-moves-ahead/6003924002/\">Milwaukee</a> to <a href=\"https://www.boston.gov/news/temporary-outdoor-extension-licensed-premise-guidance-and-application\">Boston</a>. But as we head into the winter months, restaurants will be hard-pressed to convince diners to sit outdoors, exposed to chilly temperatures, wind, and possibly even snow.&#160;</p><p>Enter: tents, enclosed patios, and even curbside cabanas.&#160;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Sara Ackerman 🐺🗽  (@saramikaila) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1326948735885127681?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 12, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Benj  (@benjrainwrite) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1326946333584977927?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 12, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;👻Jenny Foxe 👻  (@urbanfoxe) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1326526214283071488?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 11, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>City and state governments across the country seem somewhat split on what types of structures are safe. In Chicago, for example, <a href=\"https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/depts/bacp/supp_info/WinterDining.html\">the city mandates</a> that temporary outdoor structures must have 50% of the sides open in order to ensure air flow. New York City <a href=\"https://www1.nyc.gov/html/dot/html/pedestrians/openrestaurants.shtml\">has the same rule</a>, but will allow fully enclosed structures — they'll just be regulated like indoor dining and capped at 25% capacity. Cities in <a href=\"https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/DECD/Covid_Business_Recovery-Sept-17-updates/CTReopens_IndoorDining1029.pdf\">Connecticut</a> and <a href=\"https://www.summitdaily.com/news/breckenridge-discusses-restaurant-plans-for-outdoor-dining-tents-rethinks-events/\">Colorado</a> have similar mandates.&#160;</p><p>State and local laws aside, however, <a href=\"https://www.baltimoresun.com/coronavirus/bs-fo-restaurant-tents-outdoor-seating-20201110-rwozzqatirdoxptus7oc2no3gu-story.html\">infectious disease experts say</a> this type of dining comes with clear risks that customers should take into account before dining in one of these structures.&#160;</p><p>Jaimie Meyer, an infectious disease physician at Yale Medicine and associate professor at Yale School of Medicine, told Business Insider that while she applauds businesses for thinking creatively about how to prolong outdoor dining, some are going too far and essentially creating an indoor space.</p><p>\"When you're making those outdoor spaces look a lot more like indoor spaces — so if they have, all of a sudden, three-and-a-half walls, or the air flow's not great, or there's lots of people still at a table, then you kind of get rid of all of the potential benefits of outside,\" Meyer said.</p><p>Meyer said the two keys to safe outdoor dining are the ability to physically distance and airflow. But structures like four-sided tents lack air circulation that restaurants have — businesses aren't installing ventilation systems in a temporary curbside hut, meaning dining in an enclosed space like that could be even riskier than sitting inside at a restaurant, Meyer said.&#160;</p><p>\"You don't want air to essentially be stagnant,\" Meyer said. \"That's especially true in the winter because when there's less humidity in the air the droplets can actually disperse farther.\"&#160;</p><p>Meyer suggested bars and restaurants add a fan if they're going to have an enclosed outdoor space, or just lift a tent flap or leave a window open — anything to keep air circulating throughout the structure.&#160;</p><p>Beyond the inherent risks associated with little air flow and close proximity to other people, Meyer warned that outdoor dining structures may give people a false sense of security. Since they're not technically inside the restaurant, diners may relax social distancing measures, move around without their masks on, or otherwise treat it as an outdoor space, even if, for all intents and purposes, it's more like being indoors.&#160;</p><p>In many parts of the country, especially in places that experience wintry weather like New York or Chicago, <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/10/restaurants-get-creative-to-keep-outdoor-diners-warm.html\">restaurants have set up igloos and greenhouses</a> that allow customers to dine, essentially, in a bubble. While those individual tents carry the same risks — namely, no ventilation — Meyer said they're a better solution as long as you only dine with people in your household.&#160;</p><p>\"Some virus particles can be aerosolized and kind of hang in the air, and they like to stick to surfaces like tables and chairs and potentially the inside of this bubble,\" Meyer said. \"There need to be precautions in place for a little bit of downtime between customers and good cleaning and disinfecting practices in between in order to make that safe.\"&#160;</p><p>Regardless of the precautions restaurants are taking with tents, igloos, and huts, Meyer said it's possible outdoor dining could be shut down again soon anyway as cases continue to rise.</p><p>The US reported nearly <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/covid-19-us-sets-record-for-hospitalizations-new-cases-2020-11\">151,000 new COVID cases</a> on Thursday, and more than 67,000 people are currently hospitalized as a result of complications from COVID-19. The US has now seen more than 234,000 deaths since of the onset of the pandemic. It's difficult to measure which part of the country is currently the hardest hit by the virus — <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/12/us/coronavirus-crisis-united-states.html\">as The New York Times notes</a>, several parts of the country could be considered the biggest hot spot depending on how you measure it.&#160;</p><p>\"We're, as a country, really headed in a bad direction,\" Meyer said.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/outdoor-dining-tent-safety-risks-explained-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=gf3IBMjyVwQ:HUSshg2CUmI:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gf3IBMjyVwQ:HUSshg2CUmI:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=gf3IBMjyVwQ:HUSshg2CUmI:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gf3IBMjyVwQ:HUSshg2CUmI:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=gf3IBMjyVwQ:HUSshg2CUmI:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=gf3IBMjyVwQ:HUSshg2CUmI:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gf3IBMjyVwQ:HUSshg2CUmI:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/gf3IBMjyVwQ\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 14:40:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5faeb8501c741f0019ac9a9d?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"60fa44050f53b56e5bd453f46ada4ff4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn38@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-23-159_c2acf63348a16c6b.webp","destWidth":2727,"destHeight":2040,"sourceBytes":340828,"destBytes":340828,"author":"ahartmans@businessinsider.com (Avery Hartmans)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5faeb8501c741f0019ac9a9d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn38@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-23-159_c2acf63348a16c6b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gf3IBMjyVwQ:HUSshg2CUmI:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn19@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-37-610_0b02a65bfaa1d10f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gf3IBMjyVwQ:HUSshg2CUmI:V_sGLiPBpWU":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gf3IBMjyVwQ:HUSshg2CUmI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn71@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-30-375_a21bed5c7dc8ba49.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/gf3IBMjyVwQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn41@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-36-722_12b9009997d78067.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991842},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"The pandemic was supposed to break relationships and drive a wave of divorces. But in reality, most couples have drawn closer.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/pandemic-predicted-demise-relationships-but-has-drawn-couples-closer-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fad65ffdf90d00018378195?format=jpeg\" alt=\"couple working from home\" height=\"5504\" width=\"7338\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Our survey found that relationships were more likely to get better during the pandemic than worse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Uwe Krejci/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>When the pandemic hit, many predicted that economic stress and forced quarantine would break a lot of relationships and marriages.&#160;</li>\n<li>A recent study by the couples app Paired and The Open University revealed that relationships were more likely to get better than worse during the pandemic.&#160;</li>\n<li>Hard times can lead us to draw closer to one another.&#160;</li>\n<li>Kevin Shanahan is the CEO of couples app, Paired.&#160;</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>When the pandemic hit, many couples and families were thrust into forced lockdown with one another. Some people <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/26/parenting/breakups-divorces-relationships-coronavirus.html\">foretold the demise of relationships</a> and romance: would pandemic-induced financial stress and emotional turmoil lead to increased bickering, distance, and a divorce boom?</p><p>It's an interesting reflex to think that more time together might cause us more relationship problems. Certainly, being together 24 hours a day and absent our outside social support networks has led some couples to <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/26/parenting/breakups-divorces-relationships-coronavirus.html\">break stale or toxic relationships</a>. In Washington, DC, some divorce law firms <a href=\"https://wtop.com/local/2020/10/number-of-divorce-cases-in-dc-area-surge-amid-coronavirus-pandemic/\">saw a 70% increase</a> in the volume of calls. Other families are in the process of \"<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/01/opinion/sunday/divorce-marriage-coronavirus.html\">restructuring</a>\" — not necessarily because the pandemic caused the demise of their relationship, but because it gave them the time and space to make changes that were a long time coming.&#160;</p><p>While some relationships will certainly end during the pandemic, the reality for most couples might be far less dramatic than we think.&#160;</p><h2>Time spent together might have been just what some people needed.</h2><p>According to a <a href=\"https://media.graphcms.com/Lenti2dQtaMEvOMHmHXA\">recent survey</a>&#160;conducted by my couples app company Paired, in collaboration with The Open University, many couples are seeing their relationships improve instead of deteriorate. We surveyed approximately 2,800 adults in a relationship in the US and the UK, and found that relationships were more likely to get better during the pandemic than worse in both countries.&#160;</p><p>Respondents said that they spent more quality time together than usual, gave each other more emotional support, engaged in hobbies together, and split household duties more equally than they had in the past.&#160;</p><p>In the face of apocalyptic situations, or what we perceive to be \"end times\", humans want to find someone to brave the storm with. As Galit Atlas, a psychotherapist and professor at New York University, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/06/style/cuffing-season.html\">points out</a>, \"there is a lot of anxiety about the future right now, about the second wave of Covid…[p]eople talking about civil war and conspiracy theories and fear about the future. I do think that makes people not want to be alone.\"</p><p>Enduring hardship can also draw couples closer together. Researchers at Monmouth University observed that <a href=\"https://www.monmouth.edu/polling-institute/reports/monmouthpoll_us_052120/\">in the face of adversity \"we turn to our partners,</a>\" who can be a support system. Those same researchers found that over half of couples in the United States said they would <a href=\"https://www.monmouth.edu/polling-institute/reports/monmouthpoll_us_052120/\">come out of the quarantine with a stronger relationship</a> than before.&#160;</p><h2>Newer relationships were either strengthened or fell apart, while older relationships stayed steady.&#160;</h2><p>Our data showed the pandemic had a polarizing effect on couples depending on the age of the partners and the length of the relationship. In other words, younger couples or those with shorter relationship lifespans were more likely to either strengthen or worsen their relationship during the pandemic, while older couples or those who had been together for a longer period of time were more likely to have a steady relationship quality.</p><p>One interpretation of this is that the challenges of the pandemic were more likely to 'make-or-break' newer relationships. For example, moving in together in an haphazard way or not being able to spend time together can either worsen a relationship or prompt people to make extra effort to make things work. Longer and more committed relationships may be more stable in the face of changes.&#160;</p><p>Even if relationships overall were more likely to improve, this doesn't mean that arguments and uncomfortable conversations haven't happened for couples. With unstable economic conditions, a contagious disease running rampant, and uncertainty over when this will all end, tensions can run high. But along with these strong feelings, other strong emotions can be accessed, too.</p><p>A big piece of growing closer together is unearthing feelings that have been suppressed, or discussing the taboo topics we generally skirt around. Dr. Terri Orbuch, professor at Oakland University and research scientist who wrote \"<a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Simple-Steps-Take-Marriage-Great/dp/1632990563/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1445441399&sr=8-1&keywords=simple+steps+to+take+your+marriageour+marriage\">5 Simple Steps to Take Your Marriage From Good to Great</a>,\" found in her ongoing study of 373 couples for over 30 years that, \"When couples shared their anxieties, concerns and fears with each other in a constructive manner, rather than let them fester and grow, they were happier in their relationship over time.\"&#160;</p><p>We will always remember this era of our lives and will no doubt be changed for it. But that change can also be something that shifts the way we look at those we love and our lives together. Whether that means we stay together —or not — might be the one thing we can thank the pandemic for.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/pandemic-predicted-demise-relationships-but-has-drawn-couples-closer-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a Shanahan)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fad65ffdf90d00018378195?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn75@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-08-588_7d0d749d23cd1a3b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bZrAjX_0qSc:Fd_cJObyx_c:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn41@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-34-474_6fcf700aa3ab876c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bZrAjX_0qSc:Fd_cJObyx_c:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn14@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-394_8c8986313a1c08a4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bZrAjX_0qSc:Fd_cJObyx_c:gIN9vFwOqvQ":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/bZrAjX_0qSc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn1@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-33-975_36fff413df4db2d7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991835},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"A hot sauce company created the world's first touchless hot sauce dispenser after restaurants removed its bottles during the pandemic","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/cholula-touchless-hot-sauce-dispenser-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fad9b684652d4001974416b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Cholula and simplehuman&#39;s touch-free dispenser\" height=\"1825\" width=\"2439\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Cholula and simplehuman&#39;s touch-free dispenser.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://cholulafoodservice.com/hands-free/\" target=\"_blank\">Cholula</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Cholula and home tools maker Simplehuman have teamed up to unveil a touch-free Cholula dispenser.</li>\n<li>A limited number of dispensers with half-gallon jugs of Cholula will be available to the public for $130 starting December 1, and all proceeds from this flash sale will go to the Independent Restaurant Coalition.&#160;</li>\n<li>\"When restaurant operators began removing Cholula bottles from tabletops amid the pandemic, we needed to develop a solution that could adapt to their new environment,\" CEO of The Cholula Food Company Maura Mottolese <a href=\"https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cholula-and-simplehuman-unveil-worlds-first-hands-free-hot-sauce-dispenser-301170523.html\">said in a statement</a>.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Hot sauce maker Cholula has partnered with home tools maker Simplehuman <a href=\"https://cholulafoodservice.com/hands-free/\">to unveil</a> what they call the \"<a href=\"https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cholula-and-simplehuman-unveil-worlds-first-hands-free-hot-sauce-dispenser-301170523.html\">world's first</a>\" touch-free hot sauce dispenser.</p><p>The touchless Cholula dispenser comes at a time in which more fields, especially the restaurant industry, have been <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/contactless-cublicle-bathroom-handsfree-invention-latch-doorknob-innovation-tech-flight-2020-8\">exploring alternatives</a> to commonly used and touched items as the coronavirus pandemic continues to rage on in the US.</p><p><strong><em>Read more: </em></strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/restaurants-facing-negative-review-on-yelp-for-covid-guidelines-2020-10?r=bc-sub\"><em>Restaurants are caught between Yelpers and state regulations as they attempt to serve patrons who just want to return to normal</em></a></p><p>\"When restaurant operators began removing Cholula bottles from tabletops amid the pandemic, we needed to develop a solution that could adapt to their new environment,\" <a href=\"https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cholula-and-simplehuman-unveil-worlds-first-hands-free-hot-sauce-dispenser-301170523.html\">The Cholula Food Company CEO Maura Mottolese said in a statement</a>.</p><p>A limited number of these Cholula dispensers will be <a href=\"https://www.cholula.com/handsfree\">available to the public</a> for $130 starting December 1, and all proceeds from this flash sale will go to the Independent Restaurant Coalition.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tThis flash sale price also includes a half-gallon jug of Cholula that can be used to refill the dispenser.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fad9cf24652d4001974417d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Cholula and simplehuman&#39;s touch-free dispenser\" pounds, which means it can be moved around freely.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fad9cc71e8d500019813394?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Cholula and simplehuman&#39;s touch-free dispenser\" target=\"_blank\">Cholula</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe entire unit stands at one foot tall, 9.5-inches long, and 6.3-inches wide.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fad9cbc4652d40019744179?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Cholula and simplehuman&#39;s touch-free dispenser\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Cholula and simplehuman&#39;s touch-free dispenser.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://cholulafoodservice.com/hands-free/\" target=\"_blank\">Cholula</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://cholulafoodservice.com/wp-content/uploads/Cholula-Dispenser.pdf\">Cholula</a></em></p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/cholula-touchless-hot-sauce-dispenser-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=jwZV2Ap2SQw:gpInVwQ8i3Q:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=jwZV2Ap2SQw:gpInVwQ8i3Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jwZV2Ap2SQw:gpInVwQ8i3Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=jwZV2Ap2SQw:gpInVwQ8i3Q:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jwZV2Ap2SQw:gpInVwQ8i3Q:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=jwZV2Ap2SQw:gpInVwQ8i3Q:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=jwZV2Ap2SQw:gpInVwQ8i3Q:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jwZV2Ap2SQw:gpInVwQ8i3Q:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/jwZV2Ap2SQw\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 14:36:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fad9c881e8d500019813390?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"f5e1f31ad6e296897e34f2aa37ec73e8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn40@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-39-660_d071b0a511061ca8.webp","destWidth":2500,"destHeight":1875,"sourceBytes":102402,"destBytes":102402,"author":"bchang@businessinsider.com (Brittany Chang)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fad9b684652d4001974416b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn79@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-28-312_4efa041349af33ee.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fad9cf24652d4001974417d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn73@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-35-597_93a67183395c9de3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fad9cc71e8d500019813394?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn26@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-25-059_4b1ab19d9af55cdb.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fad9cdf1e8d500019813395?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn55@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-27-046_9b6518420ff85f0a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fad9cd44652d4001974417b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn40@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-33-311_94d8a2e7b7978212.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fad9cbc4652d40019744179?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn7@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-32-657_91379d72f71b1116.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jwZV2Ap2SQw:gpInVwQ8i3Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn56@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-26-888_b32e815c953d60a9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jwZV2Ap2SQw:gpInVwQ8i3Q:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn47@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-27-920_1c8fdbd33dfb5b3e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jwZV2Ap2SQw:gpInVwQ8i3Q:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn96@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-24-960_36c3cea8f1558768.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/jwZV2Ap2SQw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn91@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-30-428_2239c24b2f21809f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991858},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"4 tactics to get coworkers to stop interrupting you during meetings","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/tactics-to-get-coworkers-to-stop-interrupting-you-during-meetings-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ef6554d4dca683a8d664277?format=jpeg\" alt=\"coworkers talking anxious serious\" height=\"3892\" width=\"5838\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You can establish your authority in a respectful, calm, and compelling way.\n<p class=\"copyright\">fizkes/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>If you want coworkers to recognize your good ideas, but keep getting interrupted in meetings, there are ways to politely and firmly get people to stop.&#160;</li>\n<li>When someone interrupts you, wait for the person to finish speaking before completing your statement, and then follow up on your original idea or opinion.&#160;</li>\n<li>Pair up with a colleague to use the \"amplification\" strategy &#8212; when one person makes an important point, another emphasizes and credits it.</li>\n<li>Remember that your word choice, tone, cadence, and body language should exude confidence so that people focus on what you're sharing.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>You're talking to your boss and you're ready for your mic-drop moment. You start to explain your winning idea when your coworker interrupts the conversation, and takes your metaphorical mic from your hands. Now you know how Taylor Swift must have felt at the 2009 MTV Awards when Kanye West stole her thunder mid-speech.</p><p>In the heat of a meeting, anyone can get interrupted, but an abundance of research has shown that women are more frequently interrupted than men. In fact, a&#160;<a href=\"https://journals.sagepub.com/action/cookieAbsent\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">study</a>&#160;found that men interrupted women 2.1 times over the course of a three-minute conversation and only interrupted men 1.8 times. Interestingly, women were also more likely to interrupt another woman than to interrupt a man.</p><p>Gender aside, when someone interrupts you, it implies that your statement isn't valuable — and when it comes time to get evaluated for a promotion, you want <a href=\"https://www.monster.com/career-advice/article/make-a-great-impression-at-business-meetings-0518\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">people to recognize you</a> for your good ideas — not your almost-good-idea-that-got-cut-off. Monster spoke to experts to find out how to politely (but firmly) get people to stop interrupting you.</p><h2><strong>Take ownership of your idea</strong></h2><p>If someone barges into your explanation of your very good idea, wait for the person to finish speaking, then finish your statement, says Kathy Caprino, founder of Connecticut-based career coaching firm, Ellia Communications. Then, in a factual (read: non-accusatory) way, mention that you're following up on your idea or opinion.</p><p>For example, when a coworker interrupts a conversation, she suggests saying, \"Thanks, Fred. I'd like to circle back and share the final piece of my idea, because it's important to the discussion.\"&#160;</p><p>\"The key is to establish your authority, confidence, and know-how on this topic and not to get derailed,\" Caprino said, \"but do it in a respectful, calm, and compelling way.\"</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/8-ways-to-make-yourself-job-indispensable-post-covid-19-2020-5\">8 ways to make yourself indispensable at work during COVID-19, according to an executive coach</a></em></p><h2><strong>Use the amplification strategy</strong></h2><p>If you're dealing with a notorious interrupter, you can pair up with a colleague and use the&#160;<a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2016/09/13/white-house-women-are-now-in-the-room-where-it-happens/\">\"amplification\" strategy,</a>&#160;a tactic popular with female White House staffers, whereby a woman makes an important point and another woman emphasizes it and credits it accordingly.</p><p>Similarly, Baltimore-based career coach Rachel Andujar recommends developing a \"buddy system\" in advance. \"You and a colleague can stand up for each other's ideas to make sure that they are heard and are validated,\" she said. Now you're covertly claiming ownership and helping out a colleague. Win-win.</p><h2><strong>Speak confidently</strong></h2><p>Take time to think objectively about your delivery. Remember that word choice, tone, and cadence can all <a href=\"https://www.monster.com/career-advice/article/7-words-that-make-you-sound-less-confident-in-emails-0916\">undermine your confidence</a>. Jill Jacinto, a millennial career expert at the career and lifestyle site WORKS, recommends paying attention to your volume, clarity, up-speak, and whether you are concise or verbose. (And please don't be the person who starts a statement with, \"This may be a bad idea, but...\" or, \"I could be wrong, but…\")</p><p>If you're worried the problem may not be&#160;<em>what</em> you say but rather how you say it, use a popular media-training technique. Film a mock meeting, and pay attention to any crutches like speaking a mile a minute, pausing frequently, not fully composing your thoughts, or mumbling.</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-ask-boss-more-autonomy-at-work-script-2020-8\">The script you can use to ask your micromanaging boss for more autonomy at work</a></em></p><h2><strong>Adjust your body language</strong></h2><p>Your&#160;<a href=\"https://www.monster.com/career-advice/article/body-language-can-make-or-break-a-job-interview-hot-jobs\">body language</a> doesn't just impact people's perceptions of you — it also impacts how you feel about yourself. Jacinto suggests that you lean in and sit up straight when you're speaking.</p><p>Other strategies include striking a high-power pose such as \"The Loomer\" (put your hands on the table and lean forward a la \"House of Cards'\" Francis Underwood) or \"The CEO\" (lean back in your chair and keep your feet firmly planted on the floor). They might not stop someone from interrupting you, but they may just help give you the courage to speak more confidently about the work you're doing.</p><p>Having a coworker interrupt conversations constantly is a pain to deal with, but being able to work with all types of personalities is an asset that others will notice.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/tactics-to-get-coworkers-to-stop-interrupting-you-during-meetings-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=60TcDdHMYUA:JANF0bKpB5A:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=60TcDdHMYUA:JANF0bKpB5A:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=60TcDdHMYUA:JANF0bKpB5A:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=60TcDdHMYUA:JANF0bKpB5A:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=60TcDdHMYUA:JANF0bKpB5A:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=60TcDdHMYUA:JANF0bKpB5A:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=60TcDdHMYUA:JANF0bKpB5A:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=60TcDdHMYUA:JANF0bKpB5A:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/60TcDdHMYUA\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 14:00:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5faec7d41c741f0019ac9afa?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"413421ec08c0fe52024dc591064d6ddd","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn17@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-40-739_0875259d60ad0089.webp","destWidth":5189,"destHeight":3892,"sourceBytes":603450,"destBytes":603450,"author":"insider@insider.com (Elana Lyn Gross)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5ef6554d4dca683a8d664277?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn23@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-36-772_3c32c119675588d2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=60TcDdHMYUA:JANF0bKpB5A:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn23@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-32-948_f1a6f7f5f7a19bed.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=60TcDdHMYUA:JANF0bKpB5A:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn84@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-30-293_f3e371366f6314c2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=60TcDdHMYUA:JANF0bKpB5A:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn56@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-33-881_1e13ae74e0574959.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/60TcDdHMYUA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn87@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-36-532_65dbccdac09bfd28.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991878},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"How the 2020 election revealed a divide in the American Dream","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-the-2020-election-revealed-divide-in-american-dream-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fadb6284652d40019744228?format=jpeg\" alt=\"joe biden donald trump\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The 2020 election represents a divide in the American Dream.\n<p class=\"copyright\">BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The 2020 election confirmed a divide between rural America and urban America.</li>\n<li>Big cities and dense suburbs went for Biden, and less-populated areas went for Trump, or to put it another way, wealthier regions were blue and less wealthy were red.</li>\n<li>A Brookings report estimated that Biden counties accounted for a whopping 70% of GDP, up from 64% for Clinton counties in 2016.</li>\n<li>Simply put, the wealthier and less wealthy parts of the country have totally different visions of political leadership.</li>\n<li>It implies nothing less than a divide in the American Dream.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The 2020 presidential election results split along several lines: Democrat vs. Republican, educated vs. working class, and town vs. country. By and large, though, the surprisingly close final vote tally broke down along social class: the wealthiest parts of the country overwhelmingly voted for Biden and the poorest overwhelmingly for Trump.&#160;</p><p>After an election run-up featuring polls projecting a clear lead, maybe even a landslide for Biden, the reveal was anything but a consensus, instead a deep divide in American views on how to move forward from 2020, perhaps in the American Dream itself.&#160;</p><p>The American Dream has taken on various meanings since the phrase first appeared in James Truslow Adams'&#160;\"<a href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/1180986-the-epic-of-america\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/1180986-the-epic-of-america\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">The Epic of America</a>\" in 1931, but it typically means freedom of opportunity and the promise that anyone can be a success if they work hard enough. The election of 2020 proved as never before that the more and less economically&#160;successful regions of the US look at the concept differently.</p><p>Understanding these divergent views requires understanding how party votes mirror population density patterns, how America's elite class continues to pull away from the rest, and how large-scale patterns of wealth in America swung the 2020 election.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f984892861cb70019936ace?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump rally\" height=\"1252\" width=\"1669\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Trump cemented support among America&#39;s rural communities.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>The rural divide</strong></h2><p>Rural America has <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/nov/04/democrats-fail-persuade-rural-america-heartlands-us-election-2020-trump\">supported Trump since he took office</a>, praising him for cutting taxes, <a href=\"https://www.usda.gov/media/press-releases/2020/11/02/icymi-president-trump-fighting-our-farmers-ranchers-and-rural\">tackling overregulation</a>, and pushing back against China's trade practices to protect American jobs.</p><p>This perception of Trump as a man of the working class is significant in America, where elections often boil down to geography. The 477 counties that Biden won comprise 70% of America's GDP,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/blog/the-avenue/2020/11/09/biden-voting-counties-equal-70-of-americas-economy-what-does-this-mean-for-the-nations-political-economic-divide/\">according to a Brookings report</a>, whereas the 2,497 counties that voted for Trump comprise 29%. This is a greater disparity than 2016, when Hillary Clinton counties comprised about 64% of GDP. (These stats reflect unofficial results from 96% of counties.)</p><p>Mark Muro, senior fellow and policy director of Brookings' Metropolitan Program and one of the report's authors, told Business Insider that this result \"leaves us with two economic parties that really reside in different economic worlds talking past each other.\"&#160;</p><p>This economic divide has been sharpening since the 2000 election before accelerating in the past decade peaking in 2020, Muro added, leaving America with an unproductive state of affairs. He said he doesn't see the fundamental trends driving this intensified division changing anytime soon.</p><p>But there's another angle to this division that has to do with density.</p><p>Will Wilkinson, vice president of research at the the <a href=\"https://www.niskanencenter.org/the-density-divide-urbanization-polarization-and-populist-backlash/\">moderate-leaning think tank</a> Niskanen Center, who authored research on the correlation between population density and party vote share, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/willwilkinson/status/1324049645639708673\">tweeted the day after the election</a> that he was \"embarrassed\" he hadn't taken his own research \"seriously enough.\" In 2020, he didn't see Biden's slim victory in many states coming, but his 2019 paper almost predicted it.</p><p>Wilkinson told Business Insider that his research shows the densest part of a city or metro area is primarily Democratic, and this trend drops as you move&#160;out toward the country. The inner and outer suburbs then become split along party lines, with Republicans starting to take on the majority the farther out you drive as the population becomes less dense.</p><p>To be sure, Trump has many wealthy supporters and Biden has many working-class ones, but the 2020 election revealed that the rank-and-file voter in the wealthier part of the country is pro-Biden, and the reverse is true of Trump.&#160;</p><p>Wilkinson cited the example of a car dealership owner in a poorer, rural area, where \"there's kind of a sense of malaise,\" so despite making a decent living, the sense that things are \"kind of falling apart\" leads to a vote for Republicans, especially Trump, whose \"Make America Great Again\" slogan harkens back to that exact sense of reversing decline.&#160;</p><h2>Whither the American Dream?</h2><p>Trump's actual economic plan for his rural voters hasn't been as clear as his sloganeering, though.&#160;</p><p>Promises to boost rural America were central planks of his 2016 campaign, but not all came to fruition. In 2017, for instance, he and the Wisconsin GDP <a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/21507966/foxconn-empty-factories-wisconsin-jobs-loophole-trump\">made a deal with manufacturing company Foxconn</a> to revive manufacturing in the state's southeastern region, but the factory doesn't exist today. And while Trump has promised to revive the coal industry, coal production is declining at a faster rate than it did under Obama, <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/trumps-promise-to-revive-coal-thwarted-by-falling-demand-cheaper-alternatives-11600269350\">reported The Wall Street Journal</a> in September.</p><p>Biden has offered a <a href=\"https://joebiden.com/joe-bidens-plan-to-build-back-better-for-american-workers/\">detailed economic plan</a>, targeted directly at improving opportunities for the working class in many ways. Trump hasn't been as specific, preferring instead to <a href=\"https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/economy/article/Trump-says-he-built-a-booming-economy-15674039.php\">tout the performance of the economy</a> until the pandemic hit American shores, although Trump's economy was largely similar to the one from <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/charts-contrasting-trump-economy-obama-bush-administrations-republicans-democrats-2020-10\">Barack Obama's second term</a>.</p><p>As Muro points out, Trump's agenda didn't include a lot of specific proposals. \"If Trump promised something about reviving American factories and manufacturing and so on, I think it was for a stylistic appeal to an anti-system, a brash and resentful view of those big cities,\" he said. &#160;</p><p>Trump voters bought into this strategy, Wilkinson said, and thus didn't blame him for the pandemic-led downturn. \"How well you think the economy is performing depends on who is in power,\" he said. If a Democrat is in the White House, Democrats will think the economy is doing better than Republicans, and vice versa. This dynamic has worsened with the election, he said.</p><h2>America in the age of 'elite overproduction'</h2><p>An unorthodox social scientist has created a dark theory that may explain this divide between a party with a plan and another with a sort of anti-plan: \"<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/a-booklist-for-better-capitalism-2019-3\">elite overproduction</a>.\" The University of Connecticut's Peter Turchin, a \"cultural evolution scientist,\" coined this term, arising out of his use of data to chart how societies rise and decline.</p><p>At the stage America finds itself in now, Turchin <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2020/12/can-history-predict-future/616993/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+TheAtlantic+%28The+Atlantic+-+Master+Feed%29+Feed%29\">explained to The Atlantic's Graeme Wood in a recent article</a>, the growth of its elite class has exceeded the growth of jobs for members of that class. Turchin told Wood it's \"too late\" for America to correct this, likening its current trajectory to a ship sailing toward an iceberg.</p><p>The \"elites\" who voted for Biden by Turchin's definition — or residents of the dense America in Wilkinson's — seem to acknowledge that the their best bet for the future is betting on the economies of dense, rich places which may not have quite enough jobs to go around.&#160;Turchin defines the Trump administration as a \"counter-elite movement,\" which appeals to the less wealthy in society while seeking revenge on the traditional elite class.</p><p>Some argue that the polarization isn't about wealth or economics, but about culture. Elissa Slotkin, a Michigan Democratic congresswoman who barely won re-election in 2020, argued to <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2020/11/13/elissa-slotkin-braces-for-a-democratic-civil-war-436301\">Tim Alberta in Politico</a> that the defining divide is between half of the country with a conceited view of its own enlightenment, and another half that resents that attitude.</p><p>However, Slotkin also implicitly supported Wilkinson's density theory, saying the biggest difference she notices in politicians is between those who are in competitive districts and those who aren't — the most competitive districts are the ones that straddle the line between dense and rural.</p><p>Muro said economics, wealth, and culture shouldn't be discussed separately. \"It's very clear there are divisions in the economic base inflaming cultural or racial animosity. Economies really matter and shape identity and culture.\"</p><h2><strong>The unbridgeable gap</strong></h2><p>What's clear is that while Joe Biden may have won the 2020 election, the economic and political divide that separates the wealthy, dense America from the other one isn't going anywhere.&#160;</p><p>Joe Biden counties may account for around 70% of GDP and Trump counties only around 30%, but their popular vote totals represent 51% and 47% of the country, respectively. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-wins-general-election-against-donald-trump-2020-11\">More than 73 million</a> Americans voted for Trump, the second-highest total for any candidate ever, <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/joe-biden-popular-vote-record-barack-obama-us-presidential-election-donald-trump/\">behind only Biden</a>'s total of more than 78 million.&#160;</p><p>The land of the wealthy sees a clear solution to what ails America, and the land of the left behind sees the opposite. How Joe Biden can tie together this maybe unbridgeable gap is likely to be the defining issue of his presidency — and a question for wealth and opportunity in the United States for much longer.</p><p><em>[This article has been updated with regard to when President Trump took office.]</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/how-the-2020-election-revealed-divide-in-american-dream-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=nmJiDkaR8bw:iIY_8eIy02k:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nmJiDkaR8bw:iIY_8eIy02k:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=nmJiDkaR8bw:iIY_8eIy02k:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=nmJiDkaR8bw:iIY_8eIy02k:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nmJiDkaR8bw:iIY_8eIy02k:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/nmJiDkaR8bw\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 13:45:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fadb6284652d40019744228?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"642c515ad2e8ab4781adf91a1f15aecc","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn41@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-14-374_83ba19d8ecd138fe.webp","destWidth":2500,"destHeight":1875,"sourceBytes":153290,"destBytes":153290,"author":"nlichtenberg@businessinsider.com (Nick Lichtenberg,Hillary Hoffower)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fadb6284652d40019744228?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn41@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-14-374_83ba19d8ecd138fe.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f984892861cb70019936ace?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn10@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-33-939_d2559fba1fbbce82.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nmJiDkaR8bw:iIY_8eIy02k:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn10@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-38-222_4c9da08b0f3b5b71.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nmJiDkaR8bw:iIY_8eIy02k:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn52@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-27-993_ad47d6710efc9de9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nmJiDkaR8bw:iIY_8eIy02k:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn17@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-35-279_c4f1552f4eb425ec.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/nmJiDkaR8bw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn35@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-29-877_c9af42a6f19760eb.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991890},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Meet Carly Cooperman, the millennial CEO of one of NYC's top political consulting firms. She was the firm's first hire 13 years ago — her first job after college.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/schoen-cooperman-ceo-carly-cooperman-interview-millennial-political-pollster-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa1c5801df1d50018218ae1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Carly Cooperman\" height=\"2150\" width=\"2867\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Carly Cooperman.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carly Cooperman</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Carly Cooperman, 35, is the CEO and partner at Schoen Cooperman Research, a consulting and analytical firm based in New York City.&#160;</li>\n<li>Cooperman joined the company in 2007 straight out of college and held nearly every position at the firm until being appointed as CEO in July of this year.&#160;</li>\n<li>She was the lead pollster on Bloomberg's 2020 presidential run and helped Democrats take the House in 2018. She has also worked with HBO, Apple, and Snapchat,and helped uphold San Francisco's ban on e-cigarettes.&#160;</li>\n<li>In an interview with Business Insider, Cooperman talks about her rise in political consulting and how she manages often being the only woman in the room.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Carly Cooperman always thought she wanted to enter politics, but never thought she would end up in polling. Little did she know.</p><p>She studied political communications at George Washington University, and during her time in Washington DC, worked internships at NPR, Fox News, the Washington Post, on Capitol Hill, and at a political advertising firm.&#160;</p><p>In her senior year of college, she was working for a small political advertising firm when a conversation with the head of the company led to an interview in New York City with <a href=\"http://douglasschoen.com/bio/\">Douglas E. Schoen</a>, a huge name in the field who was striking out on his own.</p><p>In 2007, Schoen made Cooperman the first hire at his new firm, <a href=\"https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20200729005993/en/Schoen-Consulting-Rebrands-as-Schoen-Cooperman-Research-Appoints-Carly-Cooperman-as-CEO\">Schoen Cooperman Research</a>, and just this past July, the 35-year-old Cooperman was named CEO.</p><p>\"Carly Cooperman is a brilliant researcher, a sophisticated analyst of public opinion, and a natural choice to be the CEO of Schoen Cooperman Research,\" Schoen told Business Insider.</p><p>He said that she \"represents the best of the next generation of survey researchers — technically sophisticated, client-focused, and extremely well organized.\"&#160;</p><p>As for Cooperman, she recalled moments when she would show up to meetings, and in addition to being one of the few women in the room, she was also one of the youngest people to take a seat.&#160;</p><p>Here's how she worked her way up and landed big-fish clients along the way, from Mike Bloomberg to HBO.</p><h2>The first hire for a new firm, mentored by an industry legend</h2><p>When Cooperman met Schoen in 2007, he was coming off a long tenure at top consulting firm Penn, Schoen &#38; Berland, which he cofounded in 1977 with another famed political strategist, Mark Penn, who among other things, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mark-penn-microsofts-master-of-dark-political-arts-gets-a-boost-in-the-companys-new-reorg-2013-7\">coined the \"soccer mom\" term</a> in the Clinton administration of the 1990s.</p><p>Previous clients for Schoen included former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair, Microsoft cofounder Bill Gates and former US President Bill Clinton.&#160;</p><p>Schoen was referred to Cooperman by her consulting boss from her college days, who passed on her resume to Schoen at a book party.&#160;A few days later, Schoen called, offering a huge opportunity, but without certainty attached.</p><p>As Cooperman recounted, Schoen told her, \"I'm really not sure where this is going to look like, and I will offer you a six-month job, and just come work and you can learn the business and see what it is.\"</p><p>She decided to bet on herself. \"I just figured I was young and I should take a chance,\" she told Business Insider.</p><p>At the time, she says, it was just Doug and his assistant, making her the new firm's first official employee.</p><p>\"I loved the idea of taking numbers and data and hard science and using it to inform messaging and communication strategy,\" she said. \"It just hit home to me.\" She said she went on to hold essentially every job at the firm before being named CEO earlier this year.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa1c7061df1d50018218aee?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Doug Schoen\" height=\"2400\" width=\"3600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>(L-R) Jon Corzine, Doug Schoen and Mike Bloomberg attend the NYU Child Study Center Eighth Annual Child Advocacy Award Dinner at Cipriani on November 29, 2005 in New York City.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Patrick McMullan / Contributor / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Today, Schoen Cooperman has grown to a team of 10, and it doesn't just have political heavyweights under its wing — it also has big media players&#160;such as HBO, Vice, and Snap, in addition to Equinox, Walmart, and Major League Baseball.</p><p>But political initiatives remain a huge area where the firm makes its presence felt, often with longtime client Mike Bloomberg.</p><p>Schoen Cooperman played a big part in helping to uphold the ban on flavored e-cigarettes in San Francisco, a major Bloomberg initiative, and, also working with Bloomberg, helped the Democrats take back the House of Representatives in 2018. (Cooperman said her firm has worked with Bloomberg for the last 10 years, dating back to his tenure as mayor of New York City, while Schoen's consulting relationship with Bloomberg goes back two decades.)</p><blockquote class=\"pullquote\">21 of the 24 candidates that we supported eventually won; 15 of those candidates were women.</blockquote><p>In 2018, she recalled, Bloomberg wanted to do whatever he could to help the Democrats win control of the House. Her consulting firm helped him identify about 80 swing districts and narrowed down 24 that were worth targeting with different ads.&#160;</p><p>\"In New Jersey, we were talking about taxes, in California, we talked about climate issues. In Oklahoma, it was a Republican district, but voters were moved by pro-choice issues,\" she said. \"And 21 of the 24 candidates that we supported eventually won; 15 of those candidates were women.\"&#160;</p><p>Schoen Cooperman is still very involved with the former candidate, she said, now working with him on behalf of Democratic nominee Joe Biden on the swing states of Florida, Texas, and Ohio in the 2020 presidential election.&#160;</p><p>\"As Mike said, he's committed to helping whatever Democrat gets elected,\" Cooperman says. \"He felt like the most important thing is to defeat Donald Trump. And so that's what we're doing now to try — to help execute on that vision.\" &#160;</p><h2>Personal relationships are key to success</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa1c7c669331a0011bc719f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Richard Plepler\" height=\"2544\" width=\"3823\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Richard Plepler was the CEO of HBO from 2012 to 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mike Coppola / Staff / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Personal relationships are a big aspect of Cooperman's success in the field, she said, since most of her clients come from word of mouth. Apple, for instance, was referred to Schoen Cooperman by Richard Plepler, the former CEO of HBO, with whom&#160;Schoen Cooperman had worked as the media giant sought to launch its streaming service to compete with Netflix.</p><p>A few years later, that work led to them helping Apple launch Apple Music to compete with Spotify.&#160;\"They were trying to enter a market where there was already Spotify and other music streaming services,\" she said. \"And they were like, 'Hey, how do we make this launch? How can we enter this space stronger? How do we attract people's attention? How do we pull them away from these already competing, and existing spaces?\"</p><p>Plepler also referred them to Snapchat and Vice for later work, Cooperman said.</p><p>Cooperman's ease with other people has been a hallmark of her time in consulting, according to her employees.</p><p>Sam Turer, a senior strategist at the firm, said Cooperman taught him about the importance of maintaining personal relationships, whether it's with clients or coworkers.</p><blockquote class=\"pullquote float_right\">The way she is able to take such a bird's eye view of everything we have going on, compartmentalize it, and make sure everything is running smoothly is incredibly impressive</blockquote><p>Another strategist, Saul Mangel, said Cooperman's friendliness has helped inspire the team to perform its best. \"There is obviously the hierarchical relationship of her as the CEO,\" he continued. \"But I know I can go to her informally and casually.\"</p><p>\"When she says something, it's less 'the boss says this' and more 'Carly says this,'\" Mangel continued. \"Because she's more experienced and educated on anything we do than we are.\"&#160;</p><h2>Attention to detail pays off</h2><p>Married to this friendliness is an attention to detail, according to both Cooperman and her employees.&#160;</p><p>\"Carly has preached that speed is fine,\" Mangel said. \"But she would rather get something from me that is maybe 30 minutes later, but [that] I have double and triple-checked.\" When Mangel first joined the firm in May 2019, he said he would focus on getting tasks done quickly, often missing out on the \"little things.\"&#160;</p><p>Turer shared a similar observation that Cooperman \"still gets in the weeds with the work, and that is something I believe is critically important for upper management.\"&#160;&#160;</p><p>\"The way she is able to take such a bird's eye view of everything we have going on, compartmentalize it, and make sure everything is running smoothly is incredibly impressive,\" he told Business Insider.</p><p>\"When the system is run by men that are making the calls and running things, it's almost like an echo chamber, '' she said. This attention to detail may come from another place: that Cooperman is the top-ranking woman at her firm in a field still dominated by men.&#160;</p><p>She recalls the moments when she would show up to meetings, and in addition to being one of the few women in the room, she was also one of the youngest people to take a seat.&#160;</p><p>But she said she has learned to handle that over the past 13 years, mostly by making sure to walk into each room prepared, full of confidence, and full of competence. \"Most of the people in the room are men,\" she said. \" There's this feeling of working 10 times harder to be able to prove yourself and to hold your own in a room full of men.\"&#160;</p><p>\"I know what I'm talking about and I know the material that I'm presenting,\" she continued. \"I walk in there knowing I have a better understanding of what we're about to share with the client than anyone else.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/schoen-cooperman-ceo-carly-cooperman-interview-millennial-political-pollster-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
