2020 17:02:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fa1c5801df1d50018218ae1?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"b7f2a0591c5fe8b2a56198cf19f687b3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn26@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-00-400_1126bfd54a42a746.webp","destWidth":2867,"destHeight":2150,"sourceBytes":176010,"destBytes":176010,"author":"ddavis@businessinsider.com (Dominic-Madori Davis)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fa1c5801df1d50018218ae1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn26@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-00-400_1126bfd54a42a746.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fa1c7061df1d50018218aee?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn27@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-29-749_d245f60669035aee.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fa1c7c669331a0011bc719f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn43@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-26-725_d3c613e2a8c48485.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=9QMa4bmYLRk:XgdOfOt96Jo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn91@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-24-925_8278113547b49503.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=9QMa4bmYLRk:XgdOfOt96Jo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-31-449_9d4edca2d873f091.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=9QMa4bmYLRk:XgdOfOt96Jo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn15@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-25-032_71c6622194d49eac.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/9QMa4bmYLRk":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991939},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"A hotel chain turned some of its luxury suites into private offices for the 'work from anywhere' crowd — see what it's like","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/proper-hospitality-hotel-chain-luxury-suites-private-offices-remote-workers-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c275769331a0011bc64b3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Santa Monica Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Hotel brand Proper Hospitality and coworking space provider Industrious partnered to turn some of Proper's luxury hotel suites into private offices.</li>\n<li>The suites can accommodate one to six people depending on the location.</li>\n<li>Visitors will receive free WiFi, coffee, an extra computer monitor, printing access, and a digital subscription to The New York Times, to name a few perks.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Hotel brand <a href=\"https://www.properhotel.com/\">Proper Hospitality</a> and coworking space provider <a href=\"https://www.industriousoffice.com/\">Industrious</a> has partnered to turn some of Proper's luxury hotel suites into private offices.</p><p>The \"work from anywhere\" mentality and digital nomad lifestyle saw a strong resurgence during the pandemic when employers across the US started announcing long-term or permanent work from home protocols. As a result, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rv-camper-van-travel-trailer-makers-changing-digital-nomads-2020-9\">several industries </a>started looking at this rising nomadic workforce as a potential segment of new customers.</p><p>This includes Proper Hospitality, which recently partnered with Industrious' \"<a href=\"https://www.wfhbyindustrious.com/\">Work From Here by Industrious</a>\" program to turn some of the brand's luxury hotel suites into private offices for the work remote crowd.&#160;</p><p>Keep scrolling to see what this looks like:</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tThe brand's Proper Hotels in Austin, San Francisco, and Santa Monica, Avalon Hotels in Beverly Hills and Palm Springs, and Hotel June in west Los Angeles are all taking part in the Industrious program.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c284e6f5b3100117246b8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1879\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Hotel June.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.wfhbyindustrious.com/\">WFHere by Industrious</a></em></p>\n\tThe program is also being offered at hotels not owned by Proper, specifically the Wythe Hotel in Brooklyn.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c29c869331a0011bc64ca?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1872\" width=\"2496\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The San Francisco Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.wfhbyindustrious.com/\">WFHere by Industrious</a></em></p>\n\tEvery converted office suite has a bathroom and up to two designated work areas.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c296b6f5b3100117246c8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Hotel June.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe hotels also offer lofts that can accommodate up to six people for those who want to work with a team, family, or friends.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c287a6f5b3100117246bd?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2223\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Hotel June.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t\"People are craving an escape from work-from-home, but that doesn't mean they're ready to get back to the traditional open office,\" cofounder and CEO of Industrious Jamie Hodari said in a statement.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c288169331a0011bc64ba?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Austin Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe \"Industrious at Proper Hotels\" spaces will include all the amenities needed to work and more, including WiFi, printing, computer monitors, and a smart television.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c29496f5b3100117246c6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Hotel June.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tVisitors will also receive digital access to The New York Times.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c288a6f5b3100117246c0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Santa Monica Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tLike many modern-day offices, the suites will also come with coffee, Nespresso machines, cold brew, water in the refrigerator, and snacks.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c290569331a0011bc64c0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Santa Monica Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAnd like any typical stay at a hotel, room service is also available at an extra charge.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c29926f5b3100117246cb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The San Francisco Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t\"With remote work continuing for the foreseeable future, there's an urgent need for safe, accessible workspace where and when it's needed, even for employees who are only going to the office once or twice a week,\" Hodari said in a statement.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c289669331a0011bc64bd?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1214\" width=\"2428\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Santa Monica Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tGuests visiting with the program can still take advantage of the other amenities the hotel has to offer, including swimming pools, gyms, and eateries.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c299e69331a0011bc64c8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2499\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The San Francisco Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tDigital nomads can book a stay for any duration, whether it be for a day, week, or month.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c29896f5b3100117246ca?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1874\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The San Francisco Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tUnsurprisingly, prices vary per location.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c295a6f5b3100117246c7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1878\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Santa Monica Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe Santa Monica location starts at almost $200 per day and shoots up to almost $4,480 for a month-long stay for one person. For a loft with four to six workspaces, prices start at around $540 for one day and go up to about $11,320 for one month.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c25b56f5b310011724694?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Santa Monica Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.wfhbyindustrious.com/santa-monica-proper-hotel\">WFHere by Industrious</a></em></p>\n\tThe least expensive option is the Hotel June stay in west Los Angeles, which starts at $99 per day for one person. The loft bookings for four to six people then begin at $300 per day.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c285c6f5b3100117246bb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1879\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Hotel June.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.wfhbyindustrious.com/hotel-june/#book\">WFHere by Industrious</a></em></p>\n\tBookings are open through December 15.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c29a869331a0011bc64c9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Proper Hospitality, Industrious remote workplace hotel\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The San Francisco Proper.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Industrious and Proper Hospitality</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 896f5b3100117246ca?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn52@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-30-260_2458b6b84d50dd47.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9c295a6f5b3100117246c7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn38@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-36-726_e05f9980e07e73ff.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9c25b56f5b310011724694?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn36@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-37-561_661ba07fbd0241de.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9c285c6f5b3100117246bb?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn58@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-38-578_b961f9478dc485c3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9c29a869331a0011bc64c9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-30-990_2b7259be8de70097.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_sVHK7Nrl9c:thVP8NdDDU8:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn76@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-27-253_8e45971f828ffab8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_sVHK7Nrl9c:thVP8NdDDU8:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn39@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-31-030_dba83224ef4d5c50.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_sVHK7Nrl9c:thVP8NdDDU8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn49@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-39-149_2da5b9520877ba6d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/_sVHK7Nrl9c":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn91@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-39-389_e444f93f0b322d6a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991879},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Mike Pence suggests the Trump administration will be in place for four more years despite Biden victory: 'That's the plan'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/pence-trump-to-be-in-place-for-4-more-years-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f22ef9d4dca6877da35ae7a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mike pence\" height=\"2000\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Vice President Mike Pence told supporters on Friday that the Trump administration plans to be in place for another four years.&#160;</li>\n<li>\"That's the plan,\" Pence replied to a crowd cheering \"four more years.\"&#160;</li>\n<li>His remark serves as yet another signal that Donald Trump will continue to refuse to concede the election to President-elect Joe Biden.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>In an extension of Donald Trump's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-refusing-to-concede-to-biden-after-losing-the-election-2020-10\">refusal to concede the election</a> to Joe Biden, Vice President Mike Pence on Friday said the administration plans to remain in place for another full term.&#160;</p><p>Supporters on Friday began chanting \"four more years\" at Pence, who was delivering a speech to conservative nonprofit Council for National Policy.&#160;</p><p>\"That's the plan,\" Pence replied to the event attendees, according to <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/andrewsolender/2020/11/14/pence-met-with-chants-of-four-more-years-replies-thats-the-plan/?sh=1aca99b1bbb9\">Forbes</a>.&#160;</p><p>\"I promise you: We will keep fighting until every legal vote is counted, until every illegal vote is thrown out, and we will never stop fighting to make America great again.\"</p><p>Business Insider&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/2020-election-results\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"32f0cab0603d51c59235d607f82d5055\">called the presidency</a> for Biden on Friday, November 6.</p><p>More than a week after Biden's victory, Trump is still refusing to concede.&#160;</p><p>Last week, Trump released a statement accusing Biden of \"rushing to falsely pose as the winner\" after dozens of news outlets projected the former vice president to have won the election.&#160;</p><p>\"The simple fact is this election is far from over,\" Trump said in a statement disseminated to news outlets.&#160;</p><p>Many Republican lawmakers have followed Trump's lead, avoiding <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gop-senators-privately-contacting-biden-while-publicly-very-few-have-2020-11\">publicly acknowledging</a> President-elect Joe Biden and Vice Presidential-elect Kamala Harris as the winners.</p><p>Several prominent Republicans, including <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/george-w-bush-congatulates-president-elect-biden-vp-elect-harris-2020-11\">former President George W. Bush</a> and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mitt-romney-donald-trump-accepting-results-biden-transition-election-2020-11\">Republican Sen. Mitt Romney</a>, have congratulated Biden and Harris.&#160;</p><p>People close to Trump, including first lady Melania, have been <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/melania-trump-urging-trump-concede-biden-election-cnn-2020-11\">urging him to accept the results</a>, according to CNN.</p><p>After the election was called for Biden, Trump turned his attention to ongoing lawsuits against multiple states. The Trump campaign is trying to undercut the integrity of mail-in voting with&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-is-involved-in-litigation-about-voting-2020-9\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"edd8cccf2b2a2adfb9066d05bdd8332b\">litigation</a>&#160;against mail-in ballots. The president is falsely arguing that vote by mail leads to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bill-barr-foreign-interference-mail-ballot-conspiracy-cnn-interview-2020-9\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"12bf228439f95d4224ffae2c1e4b9a3f\">widespread voter fraud</a>.&#160;</p><p>Pence maintained Trump's assertion that the election has not yet been decided, saying \"we await the results of our election,\" Forbes reported.</p><p>His remarks come as the Biden administration prepares for a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-transition-moves-ahead-calls-trump-embarrassment-quote-2020-11\">rocky transition</a>. Still, Biden has been building out his incoming administration, appointing <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-names-transition-teams-for-energy-environment-climate-agencies-2020-11\">environment and energy heads</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-to-announce-a-new-coronavirus-task-force-on-monday-2020-11\">forming a coronavirus task force</a>.&#160;</p><p>\"The fact that they're not willing to acknowledge that we won at this point is not of much consequence in our planning and what we're able to do between now and January 20,\" Biden <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/--biden-to-speak-up-for-obamacare-amid-key-supreme-court-case-9497953\">said</a> on Tuesday.</p><p>Several other White House officials have built on Trump and Pence's remarks.&#160;</p><p>Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, for example, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pompeo-smooth-transition-2nd-trump-administration-joke-video-2020-11\">said</a> Tuesday that \"there will be a smooth transition to a second Trump administration.\" And Trade Advisor Peter Navarro <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/peter-navarro-trump-white-house-ignoring-election-results-2020-11\">said</a> Friday that the White House is operating \"under the assumption\" that Trump will serve a second term in office.&#160;</p><p>The Biden campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.</p><div +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5faff8231c741f0019ac9d8a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"5769326314436269862930bbb3f3e4db","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn14@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-40-653_93991a66d270f800.webp","destWidth":2666,"destHeight":2000,"sourceBytes":141080,"destBytes":141080,"author":"ydzhanova@businessinsider.com (Yelena Dzhanova)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f22ef9d4dca6877da35ae7a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn99@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-40-247_10eafff81b3f938e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0i7aq9JbnCk:-ZtnSL7BXKo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn76@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-33-704_92748454e4f4fcbb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0i7aq9JbnCk:-ZtnSL7BXKo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn8@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-28-672_468451dbc3cc025a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0i7aq9JbnCk:-ZtnSL7BXKo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn57@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-34-713_53cf890684da89d4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/0i7aq9JbnCk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn95@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-30-332_4d323e978e107dc7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991868},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"An interactive tool will let you calculate the chance that someone at your Thanksgiving dinner may have COVID-19","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/covid-risk-tool-calculates-chance-of-encountering-sick-person-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89d3d89e9fe40019009cd1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Family gathering coronavirus\" height=\"2662\" width=\"3993\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Family members wearing masks gather for a meal.\n<p class=\"copyright\">2K Studio/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Researchers created an interactive tool that calculates your chances of encountering a person with COVID-19 based on your location and how many people are at a gathering.</li>\n<li>The tool shows a county-by-county breakdown of your coronavirus risk in real-time.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>With Thanksgiving less than two weeks away, Americans are contemplating how much risk they're willing to take on in order to hang out with loved ones.</p><p>To help with that assessment, researchers at Georgia Tech created <a href=\"https://covid19risk.biosci.gatech.edu/\">an interactive tool</a> that calculates the risk for you.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.nature.com/articles/s41562-020-01000-9\">A study published Monday</a> describes the tool, which can tell you the likelihood that you'll encounter at least one person infected with COVID-19 at a gathering, depending on your location and the size of the group.&#160;</p><p>According to Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, indoor gatherings are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fauci-urges-caution-for-thanksgiving-covid-family-and-friends-gatherings-2020-10\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"340437995c5943212cdd73964562f092\">driving the unprecedented coronavirus surge in the US</a>. So ideally, people should avoid close contact with those outside their households to lower their risk of getting the coronavirus.</p><p>But if you <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-clebrate-thanksgiving-holidays-safely-coronavirus-experts-2020-10\">are planning to see your friends and family this holiday season</a> anyway, the risk-assessment tool can offer a sense of just how big a risk you're taking. The numbers get updated in real time, so your risk may change from day to day.</p><p>\"It gives people a way of envisioning themselves in a situation and be able to decide whether to go to the event or not,\" Clio Andris, a professor of city planning at Georgia Tech and co-author of the new study, told Business Insider.</p><p>Say you are planning a dinner party with nine other guests on Friday. If you're in New York City, the tool shows that you'd have at least a 12% chance of sharing air with an infected person. But if the party is in Chicago with a group the same size, the risk jumps to more than 50%.&#160;</p><h2>Risk depends on the gathering size and your county</h2><p>To use <a href=\"https://covid19risk.biosci.gatech.edu/\">the tool</a>,&#160;first select how big your gathering is — between 10 and 5,000 people. Then you'll be prompted to hover your cursor over the US county where your gathering will take place.&#160;</p><p>The probability that an infected person will be present is shown on a scale from 0% to 100%. The data underpinning the math is updated everyday, Andris said, based on daily case numbers collected by <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html#states\">The New York Times</a>.</p><h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faeddc2402d49001924ee11?format=jpeg\" alt=\"covid risk assessment tool\" height=\"491\" width=\"1199\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A screenshot of the COVID-19 risk assessment tool map from Georgia Tech.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://covid19risk.biosci.gatech.edu/\" target=\"_blank\">COVID-19 Risk Assessment Tool</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></h2><p>The tool shows how different the risk can be from county to county: The higher the number of cases per capita, the higher the risk. Risk also grows as groups get larger.</p><p>As of Friday, for instance, there's an 89% chance that an infected person will be at a 10-person gathering in Norton County, Kansas. Compare that to 11% for the same size party in Monroe County, New York.&#160;</p><h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faeddc11c741f0019ac9bb4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"covid risk assessment tool\" height=\"640\" width=\"1033\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A screenshot of coronavirus risk in Norton County, Kansas on Friday.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://covid19risk.biosci.gatech.edu/\" target=\"_blank\">COVID-19 Risk Assessment Tool</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></h2><p>The tool also attempts to factor in the asymptomatic carriers that COVID-19 testing might be missing. According to Andris, the researchers introduced an element into their calculations called \"ascertainment bias,\" which is an estimate of the number of actual coronavirus cases per documented case. They based this estimate on <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1001/jamainternmed.2020.4130\">July research</a> that compared the total number of people who tested positive to the total number of people with antibodies (which indicates they'd previously been infected) at 10 sites across the US.</p><p>The tool offers two \"ascertainment bias\" options: Users can have the tool assume that the actual number of coronavirus cases in the US is either five or 10 times higher than official tallies. That latter option is likely more accurate, according to <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/commercial-lab-surveys.html\">an August report</a> by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.</p><h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faeddc1402d49001924ee10?format=jpeg\" alt=\"covid risk assessment tool\" height=\"506\" width=\"904\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 risk assessment tool from Georgia Tech uses gathering size to calculate risk.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://covid19risk.biosci.gatech.edu/\" target=\"_blank\">COVID-19 Risk Assessment Tool</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></h2><p>A larger ascertainment bias also results in increased risk.</p><h2>A 'decision support system'</h2><p>What the tool cannot do, the study authors said, is tell a user the likelihood that they might get infected at a gathering. Rather, it's designed as a \"decision support system that allows individuals to measure the risk of their own actions and plan accordingly,\" they wrote.&#160;`</p><p>Andris helped the tool's creator, Joshua Weitz, get the dashboard up and running in July. Weitz's inspiration came from his desire to determine the probability that someone infected with COVID-19 would have been at an Atlanta United FC Soccer game this winter, before the team played their last game on March 11.&#160;</p><p>By September, more than 2 million people had visited the site.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f0788774dca6854a732b51b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"family eating dinner\" height=\"1414\" width=\"2121\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Klaus Vedfelt/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Andris even used it herself to decide whether to visit three friends near her home in Fulton County, Georgia, on election night. The tool said the risk at that time was 3%.</p><p>\"It was my first time indoors with friends since March,\" Andris said, adding, \"the risk was minimal, but it's not something I would do every night or every week.\"</p><p>In fact, she said, Andris is likely planning a \"lay-low type of Thanksgiving\" this year, even though she hasn't seen her family in Washington DC in eight months.</p><p>She hopes other holiday travelers will use the tool to inform their decisions, too.</p><p>\"We know it's been a hard year for people, we really want to get together and see each other,\" Andris said. \"But we hope people use this tool to reassess their plans.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/hGyN7xo4WzQ\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 13:44:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5faf253e402d49001924efa5?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"dac8d036a3b968885ce14580c9989831","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn65@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-39-919_dc4e70f41da60f05.webp","destWidth":3549,"destHeight":2662,"sourceBytes":187896,"destBytes":187896,"author":"awoodward@businessinsider.com (Aylin Woodward)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f89d3d89e9fe40019009cd1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn100@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-29-555_98ba9198b1bc7764.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faeddc2402d49001924ee11?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn87@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-30-306_1672e0aaf5b2697e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faeddc11c741f0019ac9bb4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn95@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-32-632_dab7f80b924016a2.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faeddc1402d49001924ee10?format=jpeg":null,"https://i.insider.com/5f0788774dca6854a732b51b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn9@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-25-158_74fd77c1b2b77d42.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=hGyN7xo4WzQ:G-AyapA6e6U:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn8@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-38-733_26b7aa861daf2d0e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=hGyN7xo4WzQ:G-AyapA6e6U:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn23@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-29-667_77f1e5b9248567cc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=hGyN7xo4WzQ:G-AyapA6e6U:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn53@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-36-252_0402fb057582ff41.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/hGyN7xo4WzQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn37@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-35-194_dc4fa5bdc945fc3e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991860},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Despite initial panic over toilet paper and Lysol spray, researchers from the Kellogg School say consumers have responded surprisingly rationally to the pandemic","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/kellogg-researchers-say-consumers-acted-rationally-during-pandemic-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f21e3b5de1e96496636874c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"older woman using laptop computer\" height=\"1866\" width=\"2800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>During the pandemic, older people in Portugal avoided consuming &#34;high-contact&#34; goods and services.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Alistair Berg/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Many consumers exercised a great deal of rationality in their spending during the pandemic, says Sergio Rebelo, a professor of finance at the Kellogg School of Management.</li>\n<li>After examining consumer spending in Portugal, Rebelo and his team found people at greater risk of getting sick &#8212; older or immunocompromised individuals &#8212; took more precautions when spending money.&#160;</li>\n<li>Both younger and older demographics cut their spending on high- and low-contact goods and services, but older groups reduced their consumption much more.&#160;</li>\n<li>Rebelo warns while the results suggest most were rational in their responses to COVID-19, the behavior observed might be linked to Portugal's handling of the pandemic&#160;&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Most of us changed our behavior as the pandemic spread in early 2020. That meant everything from stocking up on toilet paper and flour to cancelling air travel.</p><p>But how rational were the COVID-related actions we took?</p><p>That's a question driving recent research by&#160;<a href=\"https://www.kellogg.northwestern.edu/faculty/directory/rebelo_sergio.aspx\">Sergio Rebelo</a>, a professor of finance at the Kellogg School. \"A big theme in economics is: How do people react to risk?\" he said. \"Even in the face of a well-publicized risk, people might not always act rationally.\"</p><p>Rebelo and collaborators&#160;<a href=\"https://cepr.org/active/publications/discussion_papers/dp.php?dpno=15373\">studied</a>&#160;whether consumers changed their spending habits in order to lower their risk of contracting COVID-19. Did people disproportionately avoid consuming \"high-contact\" goods and services such as restaurant meals, movies, and sporting events, which involve significant exposure to others?</p><p>The researchers used data on Portuguese consumer-spending patterns before and during the pandemic and showed that people acted to reduce their individual risk. Overall, people reduced purchases of high-contact goods and services. Even more strikingly, older individuals and people who are likely to have health problems decreased that type of spending much more than younger, healthier consumers.</p><p>\"Overall, we saw people act in a way that is consistent with the models of risk-taking behavior commonly used in economics,\" Rebelo said. \"And that's encouraging.\"</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-small-retailers-prepare-holiday-season-supply-chain-inventory-2020-10\">How small retailers are handling supply chain disruptions and limited inventory as the holiday season approaches</a></em></p><section></section><h2>Spending in the time of COVID-19</h2><p>To examine these changes in consumer behavior, Rebelo teamed up with&#160;<a href=\"https://faculty.wcas.northwestern.edu/~yona/\">Martin Eichenbaum</a>, an economics professor at Northwestern University,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.clsbe.lisboa.ucp.pt/pt-pt/pessoa/miguel-godinho-matos\">Miguel Godinho de Matos</a>&#160;at Católica Lisbon School of Business and Economics,&#160;<a href=\"https://lisboa.academia.edu/FranciscoLima\">Francisco Lima</a>&#160;at Universidade de Lisboa, and&#160;<a href=\"https://www.wiwiss.fu-berlin.de/en/fachbereich/vwl/trabandt/index.html\">Mathias Trabandt</a>&#160;at Freie Universitat Berlin. They studied consumer spending in Portugal from January 2018, well before the pandemic hit, to May 2020, after the first peak in global cases.</p><p>Beyond the fact that Portugal is Rebelo's home country, they chose to focus their study there because the country's statistical authority gave them access to a treasure trove of data: an anonymized monthly summary of electronic&#160;<a href=\"https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/www.investopedia.com/terms/v/valueaddedtax.asp__;!!Dq0X2DkFhyF93HkjWTBQKhk!HgFX25ct9fQM-lh73u9j70XDXqfdO0eeWED6EUJcnR-MwQKPj7XPoSvks8Og9Vd5ecIL-s8lIHjg6w$\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">value-added-tax (VAT)</a> receipts for purchases of goods and services. The data includes consumers' anonymized identifiers that proxy for fiscal numbers, which are similar to Social Security numbers in the US. These identifiers are integrated with individual characteristics, including age and annual income. The final sample includes anonymized data for close to 100 million transactions undertaken by 400,000 Portuguese consumers.\"</p><p>\"In Portugal, people have an incentive to put their fiscal number on the VAT receipt because they get some tax deductions and can be entered into lotteries,\" Rebelo said. \"Pretty much everybody knows their fiscal number by heart and gives it even when making small purchases like buying a sandwich.\"</p><p>Rebelo and collaborators focused on the purchase patterns of civil servants and retirees. This enabled them to control for the effects of COVID-related income fluctuations. \"We know that civil servants have stable jobs, so losing jobs wasn't an issue for them. It was obviously also not an issue for retirees,\" he explained.</p><p>The researchers examined how spending for high-contact goods and services, like food in restaurants, and for low-contact purchases, like legal and accounting services, changed for different age groups and for healthier and less-healthy people, after the pandemic started.</p><h2>Evidence of rationality</h2><p>As expected, the pandemic affected spending in ways that reduced the risk of getting infected with coronavirus.</p><p>For one, spending declined in general once COVID hit. \"In Portugal, as in much of the rest of the world, that first wave peaked in April, with the largest number of infections,\" Rebelo said. \"So that's when there was the highest risk of infection.\" In line with this timing, spending dropped across all age groups during April.</p><p>But the pattern of spending cuts differed by age. While older individuals cut spending significantly, younger people, who face a lower risk of dramatic health consequences, cut spending by much less. For example, in April, consumers age 20 to 49 cut their total expenditures by about 29%, while those in their 70s reduced spending by more than 50%. Strikingly, the response of consumers by age mirrors the probability of dying from COVID-19.</p><p>These patterns hold for the purchase of high- and low-contact items, as well: While spending fell for both categories, there was a greater drop in purchases of high-contact goods and services — which involved greater risk of infection — and that reduction was more pronounced for older individuals. In April, consumers in their 70s cut expenditures on high- and low-contact goods by 62% and 28%, respectively, while those under 49 decreased spending by 26% and 19%.</p><p>\"Older people were much more careful than younger people,\" Rebelo said. \"They reduced their consumption of high-contact items by much more.\"</p><p>The researchers also wanted to understand how spending changed for people with health conditions. They implemented this analysis by observing how much money people spent on pharmaceuticals. The idea is that those who spend more at the pharmacy are more likely to have health conditions. They then compared the overall spending of those in the top 10% of pharmaceutical spending with that of everyone else.</p><p>\"For every age group,\" Rebelo said, \"those likely to have health conditions cut their spending a lot more than those less likely to have health conditions.\" That was true for purchases overall — and especially for high-contact items.</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/retail-grocery-stores-embrace-dynamic-pricing-esl-compete-online-2020-9\">Experts say the pandemic might force the adoption of dynamic pricing as brick-and-mortar stores adapt online retailers' strategies to survive</a></em></p><section></section><h2>It starts at the top</h2><p>Overall, the results suggest a great deal of rationality in the way people responded to COVID, with those at greater risk taking larger measures to reduce their exposure to infection.</p><p>\"It's always easy to find examples of people who do not act rationally,\" Rebelo said. \"But here we see people acting to protect their self-interest.\"</p><p>However, he cautions that the behavior observed in Portugal may have been linked to how that country's leadership handled the early days of the pandemic.</p><p>\"Portugal had a coherent nationwide containment and communication strategy,\" Rebelo said. \"That strategy is likely to have helped people make sounder decisions. Had communication been less cohesive, with different voices supporting different policies, we might have seen less prudence on the part of the consumer.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/V90CzuPo84A\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 14:05:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5faed6fe402d49001924edf4?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"a1ade12138edc95b5c109c9be378ab4e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn74@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-40-299_7a2781b9c70541ef.webp","destWidth":2489,"destHeight":1866,"sourceBytes":133594,"destBytes":133594,"author":"insider@insider.com (Sachin Waikar)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f21e3b5de1e96496636874c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn3@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-28-544_580170bad6897a85.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=V90CzuPo84A:1csWGQoBi9U:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn4@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-35-710_96dbc4cc0e68781b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=V90CzuPo84A:1csWGQoBi9U:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn67@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-29-199_ed23b810435dcfe3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=V90CzuPo84A:1csWGQoBi9U:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn13@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-34-086_f8be148b1b667b63.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/V90CzuPo84A":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn80@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-32-397_19b47c4b71ed5b43.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991850},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Trumpworld's faux-intellectual grifters are helping him debase democracy with bogus 'voter fraud' claims. And Republicans rake in the cash.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-republicans-using-fake-voter-fraud-claims-allegations-fundraise-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fadb29f4652d40019744214?format=jpeg\" alt=\"stopthesteal protester\" height=\"1666\" width=\"3333\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>CARSON, NEVADA, UNITED STATES - 2020/11/08: A protester holds a placard saying &#39;Stop The Steal, Election Fraud&#39; during the demonstration.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/protester-holds-a-placard-saying-stop-the-steal-election-news-photo/1229547211?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">Ty O&#39;Neil/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Trump lost the election, by a lot. Because he's too weak to admit he's a loser, he's damaging democracy.&#160;</li>\n<li>Internet \"skeptics\" are amplifying his fake voter fraud claims by engaging in baseless speculation couched in faux intellectual inquiry.&#160;</li>\n<li>The skeptics created smoke in search of a fire, but these gullible simpletons are just helping Republicans raise money, while GOP voters' faith in the democratic process plummets.&#160;</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Trump seems intent on not admitting that he lost the election. He seems doubly intent on ignoring the fact that he will lose the election by slightly more than the electoral college margin by which he defeated Hillary Clinton in 2016 — while also losing the popular vote by twice that election's margin.&#160;</p><p>Instead of accepting the plain reality staring him in the face, Trump insists there has been widespread voter fraud, while providing zero compelling evidence.&#160;</p><p>He's been peppering his base with voter fraud allegations for years (remember his <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trumps-revival-of-claim-of-voting-fraud-in-new-hampshire-alarms-some-state-republicans/2019/08/28/0c22107e-c38f-11e9-9986-1fb3e4397be4_story.html\">shameless lie</a> about caravans of illegal 2016 voters in New Hampshire?). And the president spent months <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/trump-peaceful-transition-if-he-loses-get-rid-ballots-there-n1240896\">pre-emptively subverting public confidence in the election</a> to keep his base exorcised if he were to lose (which he has, decisively).&#160;</p><p>Meanwhile, the facts are not in Trump's favor. The right-wing Heritage Foundation tried to prove an epidemic of voter fraud in the US and came up with <a href=\"https://www.heritage.org/voterfraud\">1,298 cases of alleged election misconduct</a>. But that was spread out <a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/blog/fixgov/2020/09/21/voter-fraud-fears-and-mail-worries-grab-headlines-but-the-wait-will-be-the-worry-in-2020/\">over 36 years and 1,826,807,464 ballots</a>. Heritage effectively proved voter fraud is a negligible issue.&#160;</p><p>And in a <a href=\"https://www.cisa.gov/news/2020/11/12/joint-statement-elections-infrastructure-government-coordinating-council-election\">joint statement</a> by the Election Infrastructure Government Coordinating Council Executive Committee and Election Infrastructure Sector Coordinating Council, the non-partisan government election watchdogs stated plainly: \"There is no evidence that any voting system deleted or lost votes, changed votes, or was in any way compromised.\"</p><p>\"The November 3rd election was the most secure in American history,\" the agencies declared.</p><h2>Republicans refuse to push back</h2><p>But all that \"evidence\" is just Deep State hooey to the \"<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/a-very-stable-genius-authors-trumps-dysfunctional-white-house-2020-2\">very stable genius</a>\" in the White House. Trump still won't accept the message that he's been fired — <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/real-trump-derangement-syndrome-orange-man-good-election-2020-10\">with good cause</a> — by the American people.</p><p>The president's disdain for the will of the people goes hand in glove with his idealization of \"<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trumpn-tiananmen-square-massacre-china-showed-power-of-strength-2019-6\">tough</a>\" authoritarian tactics and \"<a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2018/03/trump-xi-jinping-dictators/554810/\">strong</a>\" authoritarian leaders. Trump's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/lame-duck-trump-dangerous-days-presidency-joe-biden-wont-concede-inauguration-2020-11\">never going to be a dictator</a>, but when it comes down to it, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/11/world/europe/trump-autocrats-dictators.html\">he's just not that into democracy</a>.&#160;</p><p>Also not being much of a <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/30/us/politics/trump-books.html\">reader</a> or <a href=\"https://www.baltimoresun.com/citypaper/bcpnews-five-times-law-enforcers-could-have-arrested-donald-trump-but-didn-t-20170306-story.html\">law-abider</a>, it's conceivable that <a href=\"https://twitter.com/normative/status/1326404449405964288\">Trump may legitimately not know</a>&#160;he can't illegally occupy the White House after January. And most of his fellow Republicans don't seem inclined to tell him, so they're sitting back while he smashes the retweet button on every berserk internet fabrication that comes across his screen.</p><p>(In a thread that spans hundreds of tweets —with more coming every few hours! — the <a href=\"https://tangle.substack.com/p/election-fraud-claims-debunked-donald-trump\">journalist Issac Saul</a> has attempted to assemble <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Ike_Saul/status/1324435797374808066\">a comprehensive debunking depot</a> for suspicious-sounding but ultimately baseless voter fraud claims spreading across the internet.)</p><p>To be sure, there are a few Republicans willing to \"bravely\" demonstrate that they live in a reality-based world.&#160;</p><p>George W. Bush's political mastermind <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/this-election-result-wont-be-overturned-11605134335\">Karl Rove wrote in a Wall Street Journal op-ed</a> that there's \"no evidence\" of voter fraud.</p><p>The Trump-appointed Election Assistance Commission Chairman Benjamin Hovland told <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nations-chief-election-administrator-calls-trumps-voting-fraud-claims-shameful-2020-11\">Insider</a> that the president's claims of voter fraud are \"shameful,\" they \"hurt the fabric of our nation,\" and the \"undermining of confidence in our elections and our democracy\" is \"exactly what our foreign adversaries want to see.\"</p><p>Republican Philadelphia City Commissioner Al Schmidt — who sits on the board that oversees elections — <a href=\"https://billypenn.com/2020/11/11/republican-philly-commissioner-al-schmidt-trump-tweet-attack-cnn-fraud-fake-news-vote-counting/\">probably put it best</a> to CNN: \"I have seen the most fantastical things on social media, making completely ridiculous allegations that have no basis in fact at all ... One thing I can't comprehend is how hungry people are to consume lies.\"</p><p>There'd be less to worry about if most of Trump's fellow Republicans similarly cared enough about the country's future as a liberal democracy to insist that he accept the will of the people, graciously concede, and help provide a stable transition of power to the next democratically-elected administration.&#160;</p><p>If the GOP stepped up and denounced the president's wild theories, then Trump could continue to be a clown who debases the country to enrich himself — but he'd just be an increasingly irrelevant one.&#160;</p><p>Unfortunately for our democracy, there's <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-fundraising-insigh/donations-under-8k-to-trump-election-defense-instead-go-to-president-rnc-idUSKBN27R309\">money to be raised</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/10/trump-georgia-senate-runoff-435786\">two runoff elections in Georgia</a> that will determine the balance of power in the Senate.&#160;</p><p>So the GOP tacitly supports Trump's very lame but very dangerous assault on democracy. They're ok with poisoning their party's voters' faith in a fair US presidential election. According to a <a href=\"https://morningconsult.com/form/tracking-voter-trust-in-elections/\">Politico/Morning Consult poll</a>, almost 70% of Republican voters said the election was not \"free and fair,\" a figure which doubled in the week after the election.&#160;</p><p>Backing up Republicans' cynical refrains that there should be \"investigations\" into supposed voter fraud — essentially demanding that a negative be proven — is an internet and talk radio echo chamber of people \"just asking questions.\"</p><p>Much as Trump usually takes care to say he's just asking questions when power-spraying <a href=\"https://www.factcheck.org/2020/05/trumps-evidence-free-attempt-to-link-scarborough-to-aides-death/\">absolute nonsense conspiracy theories</a> into the brains of his followers and the willful idiots of the internet that are creating a cacophony of doubt.</p><h2>Where Pizzagaters and QAnoners become Math PhDs</h2><p>In the fever swamps of the internet where Pizzagate, QAnon, and the <a href=\"https://www.npr.org/2019/07/11/740608323/the-origins-of-the-seth-rich-conspiracy-theory\">hoax conspiracy theories</a> about the murder of DNC staffer Seth Rich were born — the democracy skeptics are \"just asking questions.\"&#160;</p><p>They know all the evidence points to a typically fair and free US election, one that for all the fears it would be a disaster of disenfranchisement, actually worked out pretty well!&#160;</p><p>Even in the midst of a pandemic, there was <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/elections/voter-turnout/\">record voter turnout</a>. Media outlets were cautious and patient with their calls. And despite the <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/election-day-legal-challenges-b85ec8351882d5508fde27e8dd6b251d\">unnecessary confusion created by the GOP's efforts</a> to prevent early votes from being counted as they arrived, even the one-time vote-counting basket case state of <a href=\"https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/elections/2020/11/06/wheres-the-drama-not-in-florida-and-thats-fine-with-elections-officials/\">Florida did a pretty admirable job</a> of staving off Election Day chaos.&#160;</p><p>Still the skeptics insist that there's sufficient smoke to suspect fire.&#160;</p><p>They're not <em>saying</em> Trump lost the election because of massive, multi-state voter fraud requiring the complicity of both Democratic and Republican officials...they're \"<a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=447471139460615\">just asking questions</a>.\"</p><p>But these questions lead nowhere but back to their typically anonymous sources.</p><p>Case in point is a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/APhilosophae/status/1325592112428163072\">viral thread</a> by an anonymous pro-Trump Twitter account that claimed to show information \"provided via an anonymous data scientist and another anonymous individual\" who created a script analyzing \"ballot counting time data.\"</p><p>The <a href=\"https://twitter.com/APhilosophae/status/1325603136128552960\">last tweet</a> in the thread reads: \"Please disseminate as necessary. Good luck. Stay safe. Be kind to your neighbors. #Epsteindidntkillhimself.\"</p><p>And just like that, a supposedly \"intellectual\" unmasking of the Deep State conspiracy to rig millions of ballots across many states for Joe Biden — but not for the down ballot elections that were <a href=\"https://www.npr.org/2020/11/11/933435840/the-2020-election-was-a-good-one-for-republicans-not-named-trump\">overwhelmingly favorable to Republicans</a> — had been born.</p><p>It was featured on the popular right-of-center site <a href=\"https://www.zerohedge.com/political/it-defies-logic-scientist-finds-telltale-signs-election-fraud-after-analyzing-mail-ballot\">ZeroHedge</a> and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/BretWeinstein/status/1326252023570812929\">shared</a> by <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/08/opinion/intellectual-dark-web.html\">Intellectual Dark Web</a> \"liberals\" with <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/unity-2020-idw-patriotic-bipartisan-presidential-tulsi-gabbard-crenshaw-2020-9\">huge online audiences</a>. That's greater dissemination than most conspiracy theories are blessed with, and backed up with <a href=\"https://twitter.com/cb_miller_/status/1325714414490824704\">impressive-sounding but incorrect</a> math lexicon. And there's no putting the genies back in the bottle.&#160;</p><p>Similarly, for a few days last week \"<a href=\"https://www.thegatewaypundit.com/2020/11/update-benfords-law-used-prove-election-fraud-past-joe-bidens-numbers-michigan-99-flawed-no-surprise-tech-giants-banning-information/\">Benford's Law</a>\" was the talk of pro-Trump conspiracy theory sites like Gateway Pundit, and suddenly every Alex Jones fan miraculously had a math PhD. When <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Prof_BearB/status/1326908766906888194\">actual math-doers</a> noted that the <a href=\"https://t.co/5noCBcmXoH?amp=1\">theory</a> is <a href=\"https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/political-analysis/article/benfords-law-and-the-detection-of-election-fraud/3B1D64E822371C461AF3C61CE91AAF6D\">essentially useless</a> for <a href=\"https://twitter.com/nntaleb/status/1326206485735616514\">analyzing election results</a>, it didn't matter to the \"just asking questions\" crypto-Trumpists.&#160;</p><p>The skeptics had created smoke in search of a fire.&#160;</p><p>Voter fraud truthers believe they possess <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aiMLJAZajxg\">special sunglasses</a> allowing them to see through the lies of the \"globalist mainstream media\" and Deep State establishment.&#160;</p><p>In actuality, these gullible simpletons are helping to enrich Republican political coffers.</p><p>But under the guise of caring about a fair vote count — which we're already well on the way to getting — the voter fraud truthers are willfully damaging democracy.&#160;</p><ul class=\"read-more-links\"><li>Read more:</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/maga-media-mean-kids-want-you-nice-trump-losing-election-2020-11\" data-analytics-position=\"1\" data-analytics-module=\"\">MAGA mean kids want you to be nice to them about Trump losing</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/berlin-wall-fall-30-years-anniversary-witnesses-remember-mauerfall-2019-11\" data-analytics-position=\"2\" data-analytics-module=\"\">The Berlin Wall fell 31 years ago. Here's how people who were there in 1989 remember the historic 'Mauerfall' today.</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/police-unions-enable-abuse-spread-destructive-propaganda-philadelphia-walter-wallace-2020-11\" data-analytics-position=\"4\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Police unions are enemies of reform. It's time we take them head on.</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/americans-declared-drug-war-over-election-prohibition-lawmakers-marijuana-oregon-2020-11\" data-analytics-position=\"6\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Americans have declared the Drug War is over</a></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 2020 13:28:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fadb2b64652d40019744215?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"ab4819a0fa9355c7e9b1aa26b4999315","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn80@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-39-316_fbda1086e995ecf9.webp","destWidth":3333,"destHeight":2505,"sourceBytes":304636,"destBytes":304636,"author":"afisher@businessinsider.com (Anthony L. Fisher)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fadb29f4652d40019744214?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn92@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-28-316_61b87357b6a19bf0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=w4WzEvtITDU:XCmKypXEjs8:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn54@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-34-356_b8b59501053eeafe.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=w4WzEvtITDU:XCmKypXEjs8:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn99@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-31-696_6754ae618084dee1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=w4WzEvtITDU:XCmKypXEjs8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn43@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-33-345_ef8363d7676112c4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/w4WzEvtITDU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn1@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-275_8352870e17fd9e73.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991870},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"How a jewelry designer went in just 3 years from launching her startup from her dorm room with $25k to partnering with Michelle Obama's When We All Vote","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/shiffons-shilpa-yarlagadda-talks-business-and-michelle-obama-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9b222569331a0011bc62b4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Shiffon\" height=\"1152\" width=\"1536\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Shilpa Yarlagadda, cofounder of Shiffon.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shiffon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Shilpa Yarlagadda, 24, is the cofounder of fine jewelry line <a href=\"https://www.shiffonco.com\">Shiffon</a>.&#160;</li>\n<li>The brand is known for its spiral pinky rings, which represent the pinky promise to support and empower women.&#160;</li>\n<li>When she founded the business just three years ago, Yarlagadda had only $25,000 in startup capital, most of it from a grant won in her high-school days.</li>\n<li>Earlier this month, Shiffon teamed up with When We All Vote Foundation, co-chaired by Michelle Obama, to launch special edition hoop earrings that represent the hoops women had to jump through to get equal rights.&#160;</li>\n<li>In an interview with Business Insider, Yarlagadda talks about her career journey, the importance of mentorship, and her collaboration with the When We All Vote Foundation.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>When Shilpa Yarlagadda was in between her freshman and sophomore years at Harvard, she had an idea.</p><p>At the time, she was a computer science major with no experience in jewelry. She did, however, have the desire to make a change.</p><p>In Indian culture, jewelry holds great sentimental value and is something that is typically passed down for generations. And as a Silicon Valley native, Yarlagadda grew up close to one of the US' venture capital hotspots.</p><p>Her idea was a jewelry business that would also \"give women access to venture capital and opportunities beyond the capital.\" She told Business Insider, \"there's so much work to do.\" Yarlagadda's initial idea was to take the good financial margins from fine jewelry and then continuously <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/shiffonco/?hl=en\">investing Shiffon's</a> profits back into female-owned businesses.&#160;</p><p>Yarlagadda had her own capital to work with, and she cofounded her <a href=\"https://www.shiffonco.com\">fine jewelry company, Shiffon</a>, with $25,000, in 2017. She drew from $5,000 of her own savings and $20,000 from a grant she had won in high school. (The grant originated out of a nonprofit she had founded, which made video tutorials to help students understand various educational concepts.)</p><p>\"Twenty-five thousand to me sounded like a lot of money, but now growing and seeing what other founders are able to do, I'm realizing it actually wasn't,\" she said. \"We had to be really resourceful in what we did.\"</p><p>Now 24 years old, Yarlagadda's business is thriving and recently helped her win the support of Michelle Obama and her stylist Meredith Koop, whose foundation When We All Vote has partnered with Shiffon to launch a line of jewelry right before the election.</p><h2>Shiffon rings have a symbolic meaning</h2><p>Shiffon's most famous product is the Duet Pink Ring.</p><p>It's a pinky ring, Yarlagadda, says, to represent the pinky promise that women will pay it forward to other women. The ring is also adjustable so that it can fit everyone, adding that at the time, she didn't know her own ring size and that making a ring in one size helped cut inventory costs.&#160;</p><p>Its spiral designs represent how the company aims to help women spiral upward.</p><p>The rings range from $155 for sterling silver to $695 for 18-karat gold, and those who buy the rings unlock a secret menu that gives them access to more Shiffon products.&#160;&#160;</p><p>\"That was kind of an opportunity to customize and build products around like what our customers wanted in a way that wouldn't always be so public or take away from the focus that our business had on this one product,\" Yarlagadda said.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9b240d69331a0011bc62c3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Shiffon\" height=\"1559\" width=\"2079\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shiffon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Half of Shiffon's profits are given to the company's nonprofit organization, the Startup Girl Foundation, which then focuses on giving funding to female-owned businesses. They take equity in each company they invest in, with all returns going back to the foundation to then be used to invest again in more companies.&#160;</p><p>To date, Yarlagadda said, it has supported more than 11 startups, including the bra company Pepper, and the espadrille brand Sea Star Beachwear.</p><p>This kind of investment is sorely needed. In 2017, <a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/324743\">less than 2.2% of the $85 billion</a> given out in VC funding went to female founders. That number is even more dismal for women of color, Yarlagadda said, adding that she wants to help inspire female founders to help support each other in the funding sphere.&#160;</p><p>\"If we can create exponential growth and a chain reaction, it's going to help us reach equality in the venture capital and business ecosystem sooner,\" she said.</p><h2><strong>Mentorship is almost as important as capital</strong></h2><p>Mentorship has played a big part in Yarlagadda's career, and she said it's almost as important for young entrepreneurs to receive mentorship as to receive capital. This is one reason why Shiffon has a mentorship board which includes stylist Sarah Slutsky, Beyoncé's stylist Ty Hunter, and former Elle Editor-in-Chief Robbie Meyers.&#160;</p><p>\"So often in business and in life, having key advice from people who've been there before and people that you look up to can just really make a huge difference,\" Yarlagadda said.&#160;</p><p>Yarlagadda's own mentorship journey began in the early days of her business when she just started reaching out to people she looked up to, including Slutsky, who is best known for working with the likes of Emma Watson and Tory Burch.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9b257869331a0011bc62d0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Sarah Slutsky\" height=\"2676\" width=\"3569\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sarah Slutsky became a mentor to Yarlagadda.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Roy Rochlin / Contributor / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>It was Slutsky who, in addition to providing mentorship, taught Yarlagadda about the Kimberley Process, a certification scheme which requires those who sign up to source conflict-free diamonds and helped her find ways to source her diamonds.&#160;</p><p>\"I loved her taste in jewelry. I loved her focus on sustainability as a business,\" Yarlagadda said. \"I just felt it's our duty to make sure that we're operating [the business] in a way that is really ethical and not causing more harm in the world.\"&#160;</p><p>Slutsky's client Emma Watson was one of the first to wear a Shiffon ring. Watson wore the piece in 2017 during a press tour for her movie \"The Circle.\" Then, Nicole Kidman wore a Shiffon ring at the Emmys that same year.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9b26b769331a0011bc62d6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Nicole Kidman\" height=\"2788\" width=\"2358\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Nicole Kidman wearing a Shiffon ring on her left pinky.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by Jason LaVeris/FilmMagic / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Since then, many high-profile names have worn Shiffon, including Serena Williams, Cynthia Erivo, and Shailene Woodley.&#160;</p><p>The biggest name, however, has been Michelle Obama, who wore the ring during her book tour in 2018.&#160;</p><p>Obama's stylist, Meredith Koop, became a big supporter of the brand, Yarlagadda said, and eventually became another mentor. Yarlagadda had reached out to Koop via her agent, and Koop told Business Insider that she was \"completely taken with her drive, openness, resourcefulness, and ingenuity.\"</p><p>Yarlagadda's relationship with Koop eventually led Shiffon to its latest endeavor: a partnership with the foundation When We All Vote, co-chaired by Michelle Obama, that seeks to increase voter participation.&#160;</p><h2>Koop started working at the foundation earlier this year as a creative advisor and thought Shiffon would make for a good collaboration</h2><p>The foundation had been doing merchandising drops leading up to the election, with Shiffon being part of the second and final merch drop right before the election.&#160;</p><p>\"We were looking for cool products and, also, cool stories of diverse brands, designers and founders,\" Koop told Business Insider. \"Shiffon was an obvious fit.\"</p><p>Together, Shiffon and When We All Vote released special edition hoop earrings with the words \"Vote\" engraved on them. The earrings range from $150 to $1,280 and were promoted on social media by <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/CGXj-Ielfqo/\">Hailey Bieber</a>, <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/CGXldvqgYCg/\">Mandy Moore</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/CGam-zAgzYU/\">basketball player Sue Bird</a>.&#160;</p><p>\"Shilpa and I discussed the idea of beautiful, covetable hoops that would have a subtle yet striking nod to voting,\" Koop said. \"And also connect aesthetically to the duet pinky ring with the double stones. Shilpa connected the idea of the hoops women have continuously had to jump through for equality and voting rights.\"</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9b24af69331a0011bc62c8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Shiffon\" height=\"3840\" width=\"5119\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shiffon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>As a public figure in the realm of politics, Obama's style, Yarlagadda said, has a huge impact on young designers and designers of color, and with the presidential election right around the corner, Yarlagadda and the foundation wanted an opportunity to step in and help encourage people to vote.&#160;</p><p>The \"Vote\" earrings were officially released on October 7 and at the time of publishing, have been nearly sold out. Through November 3, half of the profits from the earrings and the pinky rings will benefit When We All Vote.</p><p>Yarlagadda said she hopes she can continue to do partnerships like this in the future to raise awareness about other important elections, such as the midterms. \"There's so many that actually matter so much, as well,\" she continued.&#160;</p><p>It all, she said, goes back to her mission to help empower women and to help inspire and encourage the next generation of female entrepreneurs.&#160;</p><p>\"In the boardrooms, women are still not given a fair and equal say,\" she continued. \"I think we really wanted to do this as a way to inspire and remind women how hard they work to get these rights and that their voice matters.\"&#160;</p><p><em>[Editor's note: This article has been corrected throughout to clarify that Michelle Obama's co-chaired organization, When We All Vote, is partnered with Shiffon, not Obama herself.]</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/shiffons-shilpa-yarlagadda-talks-business-and-michelle-obama-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div
