+0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f9b222569331a0011bc62b4?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"dd110e028d68851290c4d510d4fd6e6e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn39@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-06-398_deef70032f20a361.webp","destWidth":1536,"destHeight":1152,"sourceBytes":123718,"destBytes":123718,"author":"ddavis@businessinsider.com (Dominic-Madori Davis)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f9b222569331a0011bc62b4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn39@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-06-398_deef70032f20a361.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9b240d69331a0011bc62c3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn71@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-38-951_259b40724eb12000.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9b257869331a0011bc62d0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn64@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-38-645_33c387a3b991caab.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9b26b769331a0011bc62d6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn27@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-36-054_04d0607bb5d5a100.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9b24af69331a0011bc62c8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn31@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-24-935_921fec4722d67c39.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RcSQ_7qLR1w:jqdV80UvEA0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RcSQ_7qLR1w:jqdV80UvEA0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn57@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-35-321_153dcf6c7eada866.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RcSQ_7qLR1w:jqdV80UvEA0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn9@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-35-233_88d20c7fa5326955.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/RcSQ_7qLR1w":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn25@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-36-576_9e8cedab76a13d3a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991939},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Gritty is a marketing marvel and an international election icon. The artist behind him weighs in on Gritty fever: 'I don't think he's going away anytime soon.'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/artist-behind-gritty-on-marketing-gritty-does-not-go-away-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faed2471c741f0019ac9b6b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"gritty election philadelphia\" height=\"4480\" width=\"5973\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>People wear costumes of U.S. Postal Service mailboxes, Gritty, the mascot of the Philadelphia Flyers NHL hockey team, and Independence Hall while demonstrating outside the Pennsylvania Convention Center where votes are being counted, Thursday, Nov. 5, 2020, in Philadelphia, following Tuesday&#39;s election.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Rebecca Blackwell</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Gritty, the monstrously orange mascot for the Philadelphia Flyers National Hockey League franchise, has become a resistance symbol, especially amid the 2020 election.</li>\n<li>But when he was first launched in 2018, the mascot didn't get a wholly positive reaction.</li>\n<li>Brian Allen, the artist behind Gritty, talked to Business Insider about the marketing strategy behind the fun-loving monster and why he thinks people have latched on to him.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>As the ballots were being counted in Philadelphia, one orange monstrosity was omnipresent as locals gathered — and the world watched the Pennsylvania results roll in.</p><p>He has googly eyes, an <a href=\"https://www.phillymag.com/news/2019/03/11/grittys-belly-button-philadelphia-flyers/\">ever-changing belly button</a>, a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gritty-flyers-mascot-accused-assaulting-boy-2020-1\">slight propensity for violence</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.phillymag.com/news/2019/01/12/gritty-philadelphia-flyers-mascot/\">a mass of orange fur</a>.</p><p>His name is Gritty, if you haven't heard, and his day job is to serve as the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/flyers-new-mascot-gritty-viral-2018-9\">mascot for hockey's Philadelphia Flyers</a>.</p><p>He's also a <a href=\"https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/how-the-left-won-the-war-for-gritty\">renowned leftist icon</a>&#160;and <a href=\"https://slate.com/culture/2020/11/gritty-2020-presidential-election-icon.html\">an international resistance symbol</a>. During the 2020 election, he was, according to Vox, \"<a href=\"https://www.vox.com/2020/11/6/21553085/gritty-memes-2020-election-trump-biden\">Donald Trump's mortal enemy</a>,\" and left the <a href=\"https://twitter.com/NicoleConlan/status/1326928011963195397\">French media puzzled:</a> <em>c'est quoi Gritty?</em>&#160;&#160;</p><p>Gritty stands as one of the most irreverent (and successful) marketing tactics in recent American history. A mascot, an envoy, an archetype — of a team, of a city, of a movement, and perhaps 2020 itself.</p><h2>How to design a marketing coup</h2><p>Gritty, in his Mel Brooks-ian embrace of the absurd, has found an audience.</p><p>An initial run of <a href=\"https://www.phillyvoice.com/gritty-birthday-four-new-bobbleheads/#:~:text=The%20original%20Gritty%20bobblehead%20is,cheerleader%20is%20getting%20four%20more.\">Gritty bobbleheads flew off the shelves</a>, and the <a href=\"https://www.nbcsports.com/philadelphia/flyers/gritty-flyers-bobblehead-month-kim-kardashian-christmas-zamboni\">Flyers created a Gritty of the month bobblehead</a>. A search for <a href=\"https://www.etsy.com/search?q=gritty\">Gritty on Etsy returns 3,236 results</a>. When the Flyers store reopened this summer after shuttering for the pandemic, one of its new pieces of merchandise featured a portrait of the monster himself, <a href=\"https://www.nhl.com/flyers/news/philadelphia-flyers-reveal-brand-new-lineup-of-playoff-merchandise/c-317444518\">with an overlay that says \"Summer of Grit.\"</a> During election week, the term <a href=\"https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?q=gritty&geo=USo=US\">\"Gritty\" saw a spike on Google Trends</a>.</p><p>Artist Brian Allen, who runs <a href=\"https://www.flylanddesigns.com/\">Flyland Designs</a> and has worked with clients like <a href=\"https://www.flylanddesigns.com/about/\">Hasbro and Marvel,</a> said he was approached by the Flyers about two or three months before Gritty was released in 2018. They were displeased with the \"traditional\" and \"safe\" concepts they had received for a mascot.</p><blockquote class=\"instagram-media\"   style=\"background:#FFF; border:0; border-radius:3px; box-shadow:0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width:540; padding:0; width:99.375%; width:-webkit-calc(100% - 2px); width:calc(100% - 2px); data.width~540;\">\n\t<div style=\"padding:8px;\">\n\t\t<div style=\"background:#F8F8F8; line-height:0; margin-top:40px; padding:62.4537037037% 0; text-align:center; width:100%;\">\n\t\t\t<div style=\"background:url(data:image/png;base64,); display:block; height:44px; margin:0 auto -44px; position:relative; top:-22px; width:44px;\"></div>\n\t\t</div>\n\t\t<p style=\"margin:8px 0 0 0; padding:0 4px;\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/B8OfKAaJKja\" style=\" color:#000; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; font-style:normal; font-weight:normal; line-height:17px; text-decoration:none; word-wrap:break-word;\" target=\"_blank\"></a></p> <p style=\" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px; margin-bottom:0; margin-top:8px; overflow:hidden; padding:8px 0 7px; text-align:center; text-overflow:ellipsis; white-space:nowrap;\">A post shared by Brian Allen (@flylanddesigns_russ)<time style=\" font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px;\" datetime=\"\"></time>\n\t\t</p></div></blockquote><script async defer src=\"//platform.instagram.com/en_US/embeds.js\"></script><p>\"The art director said was that they wanted him to be somebody who you'd want to high five, but not hug,\" Allen said. \"They wanted him to be right off the rails at the beginning.\"</p><p>Allen said that he presented the Flyers with about 25 different concepts, which spanned everything from a bulldog, different monsters, and a more human silhouette. He couldn't comment on the specific concepts, but said that Gritty was in his \"top three\" of potential designs.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faebee7402d49001924ed33?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Philadelphia Flyers Mascot Turn around 07\" height=\"3600\" width=\"3600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Gritty concept sketch.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.flylanddesigns.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Brian Allen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>Allen said that Gritty's ascent to international resistance symbol 'kinda came out of nowhere'</h2><p>\"I guess it makes sense,\" he said, \"because Gritty, from the very beginning, is sort of anti-establishment. Not really in a political way, but just because he doesn't fit in with any of the other mascots — he's sort of an anti-mascot.\"</p><p>And that ties in to the marketing strategy behind Gritty. Allen emphasized that a more normative mascot — one that's essentially someone in a big foam mask — wouldn't necessarily resonate today. Gritty was born to be an outsider, and that's made all the difference.</p><h2>From humble origins to social media star</h2><p>Gritty did have a bit of a rough launch; while children who met him first loved his absurdity, <a href=\"https://www.phillymag.com/news/2019/01/12/gritty-philadelphia-flyers-mascot/\">the Internet wasn't so kind</a>. In his initial rollout, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/flyers-new-mascot-gritty-viral-2018-9\">he was met with a mixed reception</a> by the people of Philadelphia (and fascination and horror from Internet denizens).</p><p>His early social media presence — where Gritty's personality emerged, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/GrittyNHL/status/1044258341017587713\">including one tweet where he threatened the Pittsburgh Penguins</a> — \"saved the day.\"</p><p>\"I don't know if this is still true — it may not because of how big he's become — but the performer actually was writing most or handling most of his own social media,\" Allen said, \"which I think is really unique because normally in these situations, you'd have some corporate social media team running through everything.\"&#160;</p><p>It's an effort that paid off, as Gritty transformed from potentially creepy mascot to beloved absurdist icon.</p><p>His chaos is his draw, and has helped catapult him to international fame, <a href=\"https://slate.com/culture/2020/11/gritty-2020-presidential-election-icon.html\">with coverage in Palestinian and French media</a>. For instance, there's now a female Gritty — <a href=\"https://www.phillyvoice.com/gritty-grittney-riot-rogers-london-philadelphia-flyers-mascot-2020-election-trump/\">Grittney</a> — roaming the streets of London with pro-democracy messages.</p><p>\"None of these people, I'm sure, are Flyers fans; they're probably not even hockey fans,\" Allen said. \"And I think that's what really speaks to the success of Gritty for the Flyers is that their brand is now recognizable way beyond the sport.\"</p><p>Gritty and the Philadelphia Flyers did not immediately respond to Insider's request for comment.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faecda1402d49001924edaa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Allen and Gritty\" height=\"960\" width=\"960\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Brian Allen (left) and Gritty (right).\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.flylanddesigns.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Brian Allen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>What's next for Gritty</h2><p>\"I think it would be cool to maybe see some supporting characters for Gritty. I would love to see that come about,\" Allen said. \"I don't know, Gritty's done it all already.\"</p><p>Allen, the artist behind it all, can't say how much he made creating for Gritty, since he signed an NDA.</p><p>\"A lot of people assume I'm a millionaire now and I'm not. Check with me in 50 years.\"</p><p>But he did say that the design of Gritty is the \"most recognizable thing I've done.\" Allen is appreciative that his name has been so attached to Gritty. He's worked with big brands, including Metallica, before, but he said that those designs are often released, get buzz, and that's it.&#160;</p><p>\"Gritty does not go away — whether you want him to or not,\" Allen said. \"And I don't think he's going away anytime soon.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/artist-behind-gritty-on-marketing-gritty-does-not-go-away-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=opca9ARiVGk:nE1LnDqAhCM:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=opca9ARiVGk:nE1LnDqAhCM:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=opca9ARiVGk:nE1LnDqAhCM:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=opca9ARiVGk:nE1LnDqAhCM:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/opca9ARiVGk\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 15:00:00 Kaplan)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5faed2471c741f0019ac9b6b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn80@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-29-53-800_6b020a065dcb83db.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faebee7402d49001924ed33?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn20@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-26-355_01aabbad0cebecc6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faecda1402d49001924edaa?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn88@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-25-037_2a2231bdcb0276eb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=opca9ARiVGk:nE1LnDqAhCM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn45@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-36-800_72cf08fe84222baf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=opca9ARiVGk:nE1LnDqAhCM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn11@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-28-252_3dcd03e2ef93b384.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=opca9ARiVGk:nE1LnDqAhCM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn11@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-37-420_590676606102cc0d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/opca9ARiVGk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn30@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-36-754_e57616e6fed04211.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991848},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"China's Xi Jinping personally halted Ant's record-breaking $37 billion IPO after boss Jack Ma snubbed government leaders, report src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fae42d54652d40019744297?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jack ma xi jinping\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ted S. Warren-Pool/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Chinese President Xi Jinping halted Ant Group's historic $37 billion initial public offering after its founder, Jack Ma, criticized government leaders, The Wall Street Journal reported.</li><li>A week before the Chinese fintech was set to go public, Ma made incendiary comments that didn't go down well with the president or other government officials, the report said.</li><li>Xi has displayed a low tolerance for big private businesses that accumulate wealth and power as they threaten his authority, The Journal said.</li><li>It's unclear whether Xi or another government official was the first to suggest suspending the IPO, the newspaper said.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>Chinese President Xi Jinping halted Ant Group's record-breaking initial public offering after its founder, Jack Ma, snubbed government leaders, <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-president-xi-jinping-halted-jack-ma-ant-ipo-11605203556?mod=markets_lead_pos2\">The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday</a>.</p><p>The Chinese fintech's public listing was <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/ant-group-ipo-billion-largest-ever-jack-ma-alibaba-raise-2020-10-1029721033\">expected to be the largest in history</a>, at $37 billion, but China's new lending rules threw a wrench in its plans, and financial authorities eventually <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/ant-group-ipo-suspended-shanghai-hong-kong-china-regulators-2020-11-1029758861\">suspended the offering</a>.</p><p>Xi has not been a fan of the ascendance of big private businesses that rack up wealth and power in the country, as they are seen as posing a challenge to his authority, The Journal said.</p><p>At a conference in Shanghai on October 24, about a week before Ant was set to go public, Ma <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/jack-ma-financial-regulations-ant-group-alibaba-2020-10\">dismissed global banking rules</a>, saying they were unsuitable for healthy innovation.</p><p>Ma quoted Xi as saying \"success does not have to come from me\" and said he wanted to use innovation to help solve China's financial problems, The Journal reported. Sources told the newspaper that government officials thought his comments sought to damage regulators' reputations.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-jeffrey-gundlach-likens-market-to-tech-bubble-2020-11\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">'The most dangerous type of market': Billionaire Bond King Jeffrey Gundlach says stocks are entering the difficult final stages of their cycle — and warns the market will 'crack pretty hard' in the near future</a></em></p><p>Ma also criticized the regulators who enforce a set of international banking rules as \"an old people's club,\" <a href=\"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/business/jack-ma-no-fan-of-old-people-who-regulate-global-banking-hfmstk5x0?wgu=270525_54264_16052840139888_4caa4de729&wgexpiry=1613060013&utm_source=planit&utm_medium=affiliate&utm_content=22278tm_content=22278\">The Times reported</a>.</p><p>Xi and other government officials who read reports about Ma's speech were enraged by the comments, The Journal reported. On Xi's instructions, Chinese regulators investigated Ant's offering, and the IPO was suspended on November 3.</p><p>The fintech had already secured over <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/ant-group-record-ipo-attracts-trillions-retail-investor-bids-alibaba-2020-10-1029746289\">$3 trillion in orders</a> from individual investors across its dual listings in Hong Kong and Shanghai.</p><p>It was unclear whether Xi or another government official was the first to suggest the IPO suspension, The Journal said.</p><p>Ant Group did not immediately respond to Business Insider's request for comment.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-tips-for-success-william-danoff-shares-market-beating-guide-2020-11\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Peter Lynch disciple William Danoff manages over $124 billion and has beaten the market for 30 years. He shares the 10 investment rules that ensured his success.</a></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Nagarajan)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fae42d54652d40019744297?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn2@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-34-875_192ad417f85b68ea.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ym-u0OKNn4Q:bs3vdO4PpEU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn25@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-38-269_1d7cc55f659429da.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ym-u0OKNn4Q:bs3vdO4PpEU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn96@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-31-518_6f97c7003d3049bb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Ym-u0OKNn4Q:bs3vdO4PpEU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn61@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-37-717_81889c66af1d7ffb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Ym-u0OKNn4Q":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991875},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Biden is considering Janet Yellen for Treasury Secretary, potentially making her the first woman to hold the role: report","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/janet-yellen-federal-reserve-possible-treasury-secretary-joe-biden-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fb003491c741f0019ac9d8f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Yellen-2\" height=\"3000\" width=\"4500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Former Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen.\n<p class=\"copyright\">BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>President-elect Joe Biden is considering former Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen to join his Cabinet as Treasury secretary, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-11-14/yellen-under-consideration-by-biden-team-for-treasury-secretary\">according to a Bloomberg report</a>.</li>\n<li>If nominated and confirmed, Yellen would become the first female Treasury secretary in US history.</li>\n<li>For the past few months, Yellen has been part of a circle of advisors that have consulted with Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris on economic matters.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>President-elect Joe Biden is considering former Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen as his potential Treasury secretary, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-11-14/yellen-under-consideration-by-biden-team-for-treasury-secretary\">according to a Bloomberg report</a>.</p><p>The Bloomberg report stated that Yellen recently backed away from a speaking engagement due to her consideration for the role, according to individuals familiar with the situation.</p><p>Yellen is reportedly joining a shortlist that includes Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard and former Federal Reserve Vice Chair Roger Ferguson.</p><p>If nominated and confirmed, Yellen would become the first female Treasury secretary in US history. In February 2014, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/07/business/economy/Yellen-Senate-Vote.html\">she made history</a> in becoming the nation's first female Chair of the Federal Reserve, replacing outgoing Chair Ben Bernanke.</p><p>She served as Chair of the Federal Reserve until February 2018, when she was replaced by Trump appointee Jerome Powell. Yellen decided to step down from the Federal Reserve Board once her chairmanship was over.</p><p>Biden has already launched his transition team and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-ron-klain-chief-of-staff-white-house-2020-11\">has named veteran Democratic aide Ron Klain</a> as his future White House Chief of Staff.</p><p>On November 13, <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/13/politics/biden-cabinet/index.html\">CNN reported</a> that Biden was spending that day and the immediate weekend considering potential Cabinet nominees, with aides saying that no major announcements were in the pipeline in the short-term.</p><p>For months, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-13/former-fed-chair-janet-yellen-advising-biden-harris\">Yellen has advised</a> both Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris on the state of the economy. She is currently <a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/experts/janet-l-yellen/\">a distinguished fellow in residence</a> with the Economic Studies program at the Brookings Institution, the prominent Washington think tank, and is <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/economic-outlook-fed-yellen-stimulus-needed-coronavirus-slows-recovery-fiscal-2020-10-1029694850#\">a strong proponent of additional stimulus measures</a> to aid the current US economic recovery.</p><p>Yellen, <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/usa-climate-tax/u-s-could-adopt-carbon-tax-under-a-biden-presidency-ex-fed-chair-yellen-idUSL1N2GY2EI\">who recently discussed</a> with Reuters how a Biden presidency could tax carbon emissions, is likely to attract support from progressive Democratic lawmakers.</p><p>\"There really is a new kind of recognition that you've got a society where capitalism is beginning to run amok and needs to be readjusted in order to make sure that what we're doing is sustainable and the benefits of growth are widely shared in ways they haven't been,\" Yellen said. \"What I see is a growing recognition on both sides of the aisle that climate change is a very serious concern and that action needs to occur.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/janet-yellen-federal-reserve-possible-treasury-secretary-joe-biden-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=BDhMAhq0ypo:b_f7fsF6iww:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=BDhMAhq0ypo:b_f7fsF6iww:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=BDhMAhq0ypo:b_f7fsF6iww:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=BDhMAhq0ypo:b_f7fsF6iww:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/BDhMAhq0ypo\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 17:16:28 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fb0036a402d49001924efe6?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"216ee38cc5f38ba0c9b7f760e1e39543","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn11@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-39-976_936236788edfb797.webp","destWidth":3999,"destHeight":3000,"sourceBytes":577718,"destBytes":577718,"author":"insider@insider.com (John L. Dorman)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fb003491c741f0019ac9d8f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn29@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-35-885_e6d741875c50ec6f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=BDhMAhq0ypo:b_f7fsF6iww:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn83@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-32-433_5e85fc1156286ec7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=BDhMAhq0ypo:b_f7fsF6iww:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn82@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-37-790_7ea350c0d4ee8b21.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=BDhMAhq0ypo:b_f7fsF6iww:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn27@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-33-192_565900c21a45d770.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/BDhMAhq0ypo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn79@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-26-093_a001daeaa0223fa5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991907},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Fighting climate change isn't just about saving the planet, it's also about boosting the US economy and helping American workers","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/climate-change-economy-clean-energy-us-economic-driver-election-polls-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa43f121df1d50018219169?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: Solar installers from Baker Electric place solar panels on the roof of a residential home in Scripps Ranch, San Diego, California, U.S. October 14, 2016.  Picture taken October 14, 2016.      REUTERS/Mike Blake\" height=\"3117\" width=\"4156\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A shift to clean energy will create millions of new jobs and protect our economy and our future.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The climate is changing, wreaking havoc across the US in the form of hurricanes and wildfires.</li>\n<li>A new narrative is needed to build widespread public support: \"It's the economy, stupid.\"</li>\n<li>Climate change will be the number one economic driver for the twenty-first century by creating hundreds of new occupations across industries.</li>\n<li>William M. Sisson is the executive director, North America, for the World Business Council for Sustainable Development.</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The United States has seen a series of concurrent climate-related disasters this summer.&#160;</p><p>As the climate changes, the air and oceans get hotter. As the oceans get hotter, the warmer water acts as a catalyst giving more strength to hurricanes. As a storm moves over hot water, it captures moisture and energy very quickly. So far in 2020, we <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/11/us/2020-atlantic-hurricane-season-fast-facts/index.html#:~:text=August%206%2C%202020%20%2D%20NOAA%20releases,including%20seven%20to%2011%20hurricanes\">have already experienced</a> 17 tropical storms and 10 hurricanes in the United States.&#160;</p><p>The fingerprints of climate change are all over the Western wildfires too. A century of increased planet warming has fueled the dry, hot winds in the Western US that now regularly turn forests into tinder at unprecedented rates. This year alone, <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/11/us/2020-atlantic-hurricane-season-fast-facts/index.html#:~:text=August%206%2C%202020%20%2D%20NOAA%20releases,including%20seven%20to%2011%20hurricanes\">more than 4 million acres</a> have burned in uncontained forest fires in California, killing 31 people and creating \"climate refugees\" among the thousands of people who lost everything in these fires. In addition, not only did the wildfires <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/california-oregon-business-owners-on-the-existential-threat-of-wildfire-2020-9\">force many companies to close</a>, the acrid smoke from the fires blanketed cities and cast a haze from coast to coast.</p><p>There is no doubt the climate is changing and wreaking havoc on American livelihoods. The question then becomes, what type of course correction should the country take to avoid the worst impact of a changing climate?&#160;&#160;</p><h2><strong>Changing the narrative</strong></h2><p>In an article published last year in the <a href=\"https://ssir.org/articles/entry/changing_the_climate_by_leaving_climate_change_behind\">Stanford Social Innovation Review</a>, the authors found that more than a decade of investment in advocacy and marketing to raise awareness about climate change has not yet sufficiently galvanized political or public will in the US. \"The issue remains a political third rail even for people who believe we need to act now,\" the authors concluded.</p><p>Despite this finding, climate change advocacy has continued to focus on the imperative of a stable climate and the need to mitigate trends in rising temperatures. Scientists loudly proclaim we must act immediately to reduce carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions, but they have largely failed to inspire widespread action in the US.&#160;</p><p>Scaring people and corporations to change behavior has, by and large, failed to build a rock-solid constituency that cuts across the political divide on this issue. Instead, the narrative should be changed to focus on the new jobs and economic growth that can result from a coordinated effort to address climate change.</p><h2><strong>\"It's the economy, stupid\"</strong></h2><p>This phrase was made famous by James Carville back in 1992 when he ran Bill Clinton's presidential campaign. As the story goes, Carville posted a sign around the campaign's headquarters with three phrases. \"<em>It's the economy, stupid</em>,\" was the most memorable and became the rallying cry for the campaign.&#160;</p><p>Ironically, that phrase is as relevant today as it was nearly three decades ago. And, while pre-election polls indicated <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/graphics/election-2020-issues-key-counties/\">US voters</a> were also considering COVID-19, racial concerns, and political leadership, economic concerns took precedence. In fact, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/11/03/us/elections/exit-polls-president.html\">exit polls</a> showed more voters were concerned about the economy than any other issue. Creating well-paying jobs will be the foundation from which the US will claw its way out of the pandemic economic hole we're in today.</p><h2><strong>Climate change will be </strong><strong><em>the</em></strong><strong> economic driver in the 21</strong><strong>st</strong><strong> Century</strong></h2><p>At the start of this decade, we are on the verge of the next economic era following the digital revolution of the last half century. This new era (let's call it the \"Climate Revolution\") will transform business and society through efforts to address climate change.&#160;&#160;</p><p>The Brookings Institution released <a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/research/advancing-inclusion-through-clean-energy-jobs/\">a report</a> last year that found the \"transition to the clean energy economy will primarily involve 320 unique occupations spread across three major industrial sectors: Clean energy production, energy efficiency, and environmental management.\"&#160;</p><p>The report, titled \"The Hidden STEM Economy,\" states that \"staffing all these industries entails a broad assortment of occupations. Energy-related industries are typified by a need for skilled trades to help manufacture advanced products, execute large-scale construction projects, research and develop new technologies, and deliver other detailed STEM-related services.\"&#160;</p><p>Another Brookings report also found that \"businesses within these industries rely on an expansive suite of support services — including business, financial, and customer management — to compete. Likewise, government and nonprofit organizations rely on specially trained workers to execute their missions.\"</p><p>So, it becomes clear that transitioning to a clean energy economy has compounding economic benefits for everyone.&#160;&#160;</p><h2><strong>US businesses are driving this economy</strong></h2><p>While the current administration is not serious about addressing this issue, many US companies are adapting their business models to account for both the risks and opportunities a changing climate provides. <a href=\"https://sciencebasedtargets.org/2020/05/18/uniting-business-and-governments-to-recover-better/\">Companies</a> are beginning to talk about commitments to achieve \"Net Zero Emissions\" and use <a href=\"https://sciencebasedtargets.org/\">\"Science-Based Target Initiatives</a>\" to align their climate change commitments with what was agreed upon in the 2015 Paris UN Climate Change agreement. <a href=\"https://www.newsbreak.com/news/1615174022876/apple-ford-mcdonalds-and-microsoft-among-this-summers-climate-leaders\">Companies</a> as diverse as Apple, Ford, Microsoft, Nike and McDonald's have already made bold public statements about their climate intentions.&#160;&#160;</p><p>Members of my organization, the World Business Council for Sustainable Development&#160; (WBCSD), are taking concrete steps to compete in this economic transition and are not waiting for the federal government to act.&#160;</p><p>Recently, WBCSD members approved <a href=\"https://www.wbcsd.org/Overview/News-Insights/General/News/New-membership-criteria\">new conditions for membership</a> in the organization. Among them is a commitment to achieve Net Zero Emissions by 2050 and use science-informed methods to develop the path by which to achieve this goal.&#160;</p><p>More broadly, at a time when everyone talks about \"building back or forward better\", the new member commitments address the three interconnected challenges our society face — the climate emergency, nature loss, and inequality — and pave the way for business action.&#160;</p><p>In doing so, they are creating new, sustainable jobs, and, at the same time, helping to ensure all people can live well and within the boundaries of the planet for generations to come.</p><h2><strong>China and Europe are leading the way</strong></h2><p>While we still argue in the US over whether the climate is worsening and the degree to which humans play in making it worse, China and many <a href=\"https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/policies/climate-change/\">European countries</a> have already been moving to transition their economies.&#160;</p><p>China has been especially aggressive of late to capture the climate market. President Xi Jinping recently announced China's plans to reach peak carbon emissions by 2030 and <a href=\"https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-02927-9\">carbon neutrality</a> by 2060, positioning China as a global leader.</p><p>China's main thrust focuses on the new jobs that will spring from its efforts to corral climate change. It will then sell the new technologies, products, and services innovated and made in China to other countries to avert climate disaster while fueling the Chinese economy.&#160;</p><p>We have learned from COVID-19 that America must be prepared for looming threats and have seen the consequences of \"too little, too late\" responsiveness or, worse, the outright ignorance of the science. In terms of the environment, we must act knowledgeably and swiftly to reduce emissions and avoid the worst impacts of climate change. We must and will take the opportunity of the pandemic-induced economic pause to find a way to build back better.&#160;&#160;</p><p>In doing so, we too can create millions of new jobs, foster clean energy innovation in the US, increase our national security, and, most importantly, protect the health of our people, economy, and our future.&#160;</p><p>The private sector is calling on local, state, and federal governments to enact stronger and consistent climate policy to give them clarity and confidence to invest in the technologies and markets needed to avert climate disaster. Businesses cannot do it alone.&#160;</p><p>Politicians today should realize that Carville was right in 1992, and his phrase rings even truer today. Climate responsibility is all about \"the economy, stupid!\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/climate-change-economy-clean-energy-us-economic-driver-election-polls-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=NTjQKw1E9qU:YXV218rv7hs:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=NTjQKw1E9qU:YXV218rv7hs:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=NTjQKw1E9qU:YXV218rv7hs:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=NTjQKw1E9qU:YXV218rv7hs:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=NTjQKw1E9qU:YXV218rv7hs:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=NTjQKw1E9qU:YXV218rv7hs:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=NTjQKw1E9qU:YXV218rv7hs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=NTjQKw1E9qU:YXV218rv7hs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/NTjQKw1E9qU\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 15:33:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fa43f121df1d50018219169?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"981c111fbc1efc080735fa0499459fa0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn23@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-04-378_a51cd141d3f7b9d6.webp","destWidth":4156,"destHeight":3117,"sourceBytes":517500,"destBytes":517500,"author":"insider@insider.com (William M. Sisson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fa43f121df1d50018219169?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn23@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-04-378_a51cd141d3f7b9d6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=NTjQKw1E9qU:YXV218rv7hs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn84@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-27-239_165b435f196b5e99.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=NTjQKw1E9qU:YXV218rv7hs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn12@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-30-733_563f20de85174dbd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=NTjQKw1E9qU:YXV218rv7hs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn58@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-39-323_1cdd80ef7fc890d7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/NTjQKw1E9qU":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991823},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Asian American businesses are facing racist obstacles driven by the COVID-19 pandemic. They need our support.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/asian-american-businesses-covid-19-racism-coronavirus-restaurants-economy-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9b0d306f5b310011724438?format=jpeg\" alt=\"New York Chinatown business pandemic Congee Village\" height=\"1220\" width=\"2440\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Irene Jiang/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Asian American small businesses are struggling to weather the pandemic on top of dealing with COVID-related racism.</li>\n<li>Some Asian American entrepreneurs are turning to e-commerce to survive.</li>\n<li>Now more than ever we need to support small businesses if we want them to still be around once the pandemic is over.</li>\n<li>Jocelyn Azada is the director of supply chain sustainability at Nielsen.</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>As the novel coronavirus became formally known as COVID-19 and declared a pandemic in March, businesses in the US started closing to slow the spread, including restaurants and small retailers that depended on local communities to sustain them. Asian American businesses were some of the first hit, as revenue at Chinatown businesses across the country began trending down in January due to fear by customers of any link to what was first touted as the \"Chinese virus.\"</p><p>This was not made any better by politicians, including President Trump, repeatedly using the phrase. As months go by, some businesses have had to close shop while others changed course to remain in operation while riding out this period of uncertainty.</p><p>Asian American businesses are incredibly important for multiple reasons. For the Asian American community, they provide avenues to connect to their culture and purchase items that they can't find easily in regular shops. For others, they provide a glimpse into the rich cultures they represent.&#160;</p><p>The US Census <a href=\"https://www.census.gov/newsroom/blogs/random-samplings/2016/07/asian-owned-businesses-nearing-two-million.html\">reported that</a> there are over 2 million Asian American-owned businesses servicing neighborhoods across the country. With 42% of them in \"Accommodation and Food Services\" and \"Retail\" industries, versus just 21% of all businesses, Asian American businesses have been hard hit.</p><p>A recent UCLA study found that between February to April of this year, about <a href=\"http://www.aasc.ucla.edu/resources/policyreports/COVID19_Employment_CNK-AASC_072020.pdf\">233,000 Asian American small businesses have closed</a>, and in May 2020 the Asian American jobless rate was 21%. The idea that Asian Americans and their businesses are some of the worst hit may be shocking to those who still believe in the Asian American model minority myth.</p><h2>The racism effect</h2><p>Anti-Asian rhetoric is adding insult to injury when it comes to businesses already trying to survive the effects of the pandemic. According to the Asian Pacific Policy and Planning Council, hate incidents <a href=\"http://www.asianpacificpolicyandplanningcouncil.org/stop-aapi-hate/\">have seen an upward trend</a> since the outbreak of the virus. In a recent report they've compiled over 2,500 incidents of anti-Chinese and anti-Asian rhetoric between March and August of this year. Many of these incidents have taken place in places of work and in public spaces, and includes multiple incidents of vandalism of Asian American businesses. The actual number of incidents that have occured is expected to be much larger, as those are just the ones that have been reported to the organization.</p><p>Pearl River Mart, an emporium of Asian goods in New York City, was impacted by COVID-19 early on and laid off most of their employees, many of whom have been working for them for decades.</p><p>It was difficult, but to stay in operation, they continued marketing their brand on social media and sending e-newsletters to customers. They also found a need in their community for face masks and PPEs for front-line workers, raised funds, and used their import business to obtain supplies from China and other Asian markets.</p><p>They now sell face masks online which supplements their revenue, as well as utilize their design, production, and distribution channels to create the Chinatown Collection — a merch collection bringing together beloved Chinatown businesses, creative artists, and neighborhood non-profits.</p><p>The shift to e-commerce from brick and mortar has been a lifesaver for Pearl River Mart. With consumers on lockdown, the only place they can shop was online. Big box retailers with robust purchasing systems have benefited from this turn, as many are considered \"essential\" companies because they sell food and household items necessary for everyday living.</p><p>Asian American snack food company Dang Foods is a small business supplier that's been selling its healthy snacks in grocery stores since 2011. Dang, founded by Vincent Kitirattragarn, started an e-commerce site in 2018. And while its products are currently selling in stores, they've seen a big shift in consumers shopping online for their coconut chips, Thai rice chips, and Keto-friendly bars.</p><p>Though young entrepreneurs such as Kitirattragarn have found ways to stay in operation during the pandemic, many businesses in Asian communities such as Chinatowns, Little Indias, and Koreatowns have shuttered. Because of this, the places where locals and visitors used to shop the stores for Asian goods and visit restaurants to dine with family and friends have also gone digital to reach customers, some using third-party services to help with deliveries and find distributors to sell their goods online.</p><p>Stories like these demonstrate the resiliency of small Asian American businesses. Still, small Asian American businesses and restaurants face numerous obstacles, such as language and cultural barriers, and the lack of a relationship with a financial institution. While some Asian language translations regarding federal financial aid for businesses were eventually made available on the US Small Business Administration website, they were not provided when these programs first launched.</p><p>For non-native English speakers, culturally appropriate translations would have eased some of the initial barriers to entry to navigating the process of applying, let alone receiving, this federal aid. The impacts of these structural barriers were widely documented throughout the summer and early fall as multiple reports showed that minority owned businesses have not been able to secure governmental assistance like the Paycheck Protection program to bolster them through this downturn.</p><p>We can all play a part to help these businesses. Using our power as consumers by continuing to support small and local Asian American businesses is key. These businesses add character to our neighborhoods, provide jobs for employees, and build local economies. This not only helps small businesses, but strengthens our overall economic environment and recovery, as diverse businesses <a href=\"https://community-wealth.org/content/color-entrepreneurship-why-racial-gap-among-firms-costs-us-billions\">created 67% of the new jobs</a> in the US from 2009-2012, the years following the Great Recession. Better yet — connecting with your local businesses and business owners creates a sense of community and economic resiliency, an antidote for the social distancing and lockdowns that we are facing everyday.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/asian-american-businesses-covid-19-racism-coronavirus-restaurants-economy-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
