href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ZHmWrIwVqjI:BymzNpEpnN4:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZHmWrIwVqjI:BymzNpEpnN4:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ZHmWrIwVqjI:BymzNpEpnN4:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZHmWrIwVqjI:BymzNpEpnN4:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ZHmWrIwVqjI:BymzNpEpnN4:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ZHmWrIwVqjI:BymzNpEpnN4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZHmWrIwVqjI:BymzNpEpnN4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ZHmWrIwVqjI\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 14:33:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f9b0d2a69331a0011bc6225?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"0c1525722576d14ab0721aa52def7bc0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn57@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-39-901_a1b61c843d6f4e1f.webp","destWidth":2222,"destHeight":1666,"sourceBytes":382720,"destBytes":382720,"author":"insider@insider.com (Jocelyn Azada)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f9b0d306f5b310011724438?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn3@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-35-008_ec56b3ae41fd07f4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZHmWrIwVqjI:BymzNpEpnN4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn3@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-38-697_d7fa74e318c043f9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZHmWrIwVqjI:BymzNpEpnN4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn59@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-30-772_26b61caf15142690.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZHmWrIwVqjI:BymzNpEpnN4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn79@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-35-568_5bb1d1f792b37ac1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ZHmWrIwVqjI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn88@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-38-660_978e1df0a2fea143.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991849},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Philadelphia city council apologizes for approving the police bombing of one of its Black neighborhood's killing 11 people, including 5 children","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/city-of-philadelphia-apologizes-for-bombing-black-militants-killing-16-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fafd1a0402d49001924efcc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"MOVE Bombing 1985\" height=\"2655\" width=\"3541\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Aerial view of smoke rising from Osage Avenue in Cobbs Creek on May 14, 1985 after police bombed the roof of MOVE&#39;s compound.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Bettmann/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Philadelphia City Council voted on Thursday to formally apologize for their decision to approve a bombing, which left 11 people dead, including five children, and burned down 61 homes in 1985.</li>\n<li>On May 13, 1985, police dropped an explosive device on the roof of the compound of MOVE, a Black radical group, as officers tried to evict them, according to <a href=\"https://www.inquirer.com/news/philadelphia/move-bombing-apology-philadelphia-walter-wallace-20201112.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Philadelphia Inquirer</a>.</li>\n<li>The blaze was left to rage. There were 11 deaths, including five children aged seven to 13, and 61 homes destroyed in the largely black neighborhood,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/nov/13/philadelphia-1985-move-bombing-apology\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Guardian</a>&#160;reported.</li>\n<li>In the <a href=\"https://twitter.com/CouncilmemberJG/status/1326936274037575680?s=20\">resolution</a>,&#160;Cllr Gauthier said: \"We can draw a straight line from the unresolved pain and trauma of that day to Walter Wallace Jr's earlier this week in the very same neighborhood.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Philadelphia City Council voted to formally apologize for their decision to approve a bombing, which left 11 people dead, including five children, and burned down 61 homes in 1985.</p><p>On May 13, police dropped an explosive device on the roof of 6621 Ossage Avenue in West Philadelphia after a daylong confrontation with the Black radical group, MOVE, as officers tried to evict them from their compound, <a href=\"https://www.inquirer.com/news/philadelphia/move-bombing-apology-philadelphia-walter-wallace-20201112.html\">The Philadelphia Inquirer</a>&#160;reported.</p><p>The bomb then sparked a blaze that was left to rage by authorities until there were 11 deaths, including those of five children aged seven to 13, and 61 homes destroyed in the largely black neighborhood, according to <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/nov/13/philadelphia-1985-move-bombing-apology\">The Guardian</a>.</p><p>MOVE was founded&#160;in 1972 by Vincent Leaphart, a West Philadelphia native and Korean War veteran who took the name John Africa to demonstrate his reverence for the continent.&#160;</p><p>The group's ideology and aims were outlined in a document entitled 'The Guidlines.' It combined black revolutionary ideals with environmental and animal rights, <a href=\"https://www.vox.com/the-highlight/2019/8/8/20747198/philadelphia-bombing-1985-move\">Vox</a> reported.</p><p>They had a mixed relationship with the local community but frequently had run-ins with the police. A police officer was killed in 1978. Nine MOVE members were controversially given life sentences, <a href=\"https://www.vox.com/the-highlight/2019/8/8/20747198/philadelphia-bombing-1985-move\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Vox</a>&#160;added.</p><p>Gregore J. Sambor, the Police Commissioner who directed the bombing, resigned in November of that year. A grand jury in 1988 cleared then-Mayor W. Wilson Goode and other top city officials of criminal liability for death and destruction resulting from the operation, the&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/13/us/philadelphia-bombing-apology-move.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">New York Times</a>&#160;reported.</p><p>However, W. Wilson Goode wrote in&#160;<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/may/10/when-i-was-mayor-philadelphia-bombed-civilians-its-time-for-the-city-to-apologise\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Guardian</a>: \"The event will remain in my conscience for the rest of my life,\" and called on the city to issue a formal apology.</p><p>The vote was introduced by Jamie Gauthier, a councillor who grew up near the Cobbs Creek neighborhood where the attack occurred and whose district also includes it, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/13/us/philadelphia-bombing-apology-move.html\">The New York Times</a>&#160;added.</p><p>She also called for an annual remembrance on May 13 and had a draft resolution prepared before this year's 35th anniversary but it was put on hold due to COVID-19.</p><p>Cllr Gauthier&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/CouncilmemberJG/status/1326934272561860608?s=20\">tweeted</a> on Thursday: \"My MOVE Bombing resolution passed unanimously today. Thank you to all my Council colleagues for your support. This resolution serves as a recognition of the pain and trauma that these events have brought upon the Cobbs Creek community, and Black people in our city as a whole.\"</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Councilmember Jamie Gauthier  (@CouncilmemberJG) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1326936274037575680?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 12, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>In the resolution also posted on <a href=\"https://twitter.com/CouncilmemberJG/status/1326936274037575680?s=20\">Twitter</a>, she said: \"We can draw a straight line from the unresolved pain and trauma of that day to Walter Wallace Jr's earlier this week in the very same neighborhood. \"</p><p>Two Philadelphia police officers fatally shot Walter Wallace Jr. in Cobbs Creek last month, which led to protests across the city and calls for&#160;<a href=\"https://www.insider.com/philadelphia-police-reforms-in-response-to-fatal-shooting-walter-wallace-2020-11\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reforms</a>&#160;within the police force.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/city-of-philadelphia-apologizes-for-bombing-black-militants-killing-16-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ClGfEtEzMsU:SVaryXyYpa4:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ClGfEtEzMsU:SVaryXyYpa4:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ClGfEtEzMsU:SVaryXyYpa4:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ClGfEtEzMsU:SVaryXyYpa4:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ClGfEtEzMsU:SVaryXyYpa4:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ClGfEtEzMsU:SVaryXyYpa4:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ClGfEtEzMsU:SVaryXyYpa4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ClGfEtEzMsU:SVaryXyYpa4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ClGfEtEzMsU\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 16:08:49 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fafd1a0402d49001924efcc?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"939f081e3a887dfe5d2c6673babcfd96","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn30@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-00-908_6333aac3aa7e3b95.webp","destWidth":3541,"destHeight":2655,"sourceBytes":1577630,"destBytes":1577630,"author":"insider@insider.com (Naina Bhardwaj)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fafd1a0402d49001924efcc?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn30@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-00-908_6333aac3aa7e3b95.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ClGfEtEzMsU:SVaryXyYpa4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn15@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-33-127_29dda535f62c7eb2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ClGfEtEzMsU:SVaryXyYpa4:V_sGLiPBpWU":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ClGfEtEzMsU:SVaryXyYpa4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn86@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-34-828_e9293fb2b4073e5d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ClGfEtEzMsU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn24@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-39-558_f5dc6c1477d8b042.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991845},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"The UK's Royal National Institute of Blind People has helped create an accessible pregnancy test for visually impaired women","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/rnib-uk-accessible-pregnancy-test-for-blind-visually-impaired-women-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f96e7a7f21803001222bea3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Main PR Image 2\" height=\"2160\" width=\"2880\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A woman holding the pregnancy test prototype.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The&#38;Partnership</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Visually impaired women cannot use traditional pregnancy tests, so British charity the RNIB teamed up with marketing network The&#38;Partnership to create an accessible one.&#160;</li>\n<li>Traditional tests rely on visual cues, meaning visually impaired women need help to use them &#8211; but the new test delivers results using a raised button.&#160;</li>\n<li>The purpose of the test is to grant women everywere the right to privacy and dignity, say the two companies behind it.</li>\n<li>The product will not go beyond the prototype stage, but its creators hope the research will inspire other companies to focus on accessible design.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Visually impaired women can't use pregnancy tests without assistance, so British designers have created a pioneering prototype, which allows such women to be the first to learn their results.</p><p>Instead of the usual striped lines or electronic screen, the prototype test produces a large raised button to indicate a positive result. This allows women to feel their results with their fingers.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f96e8fff21803001222bea9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RNIB\" height=\"1069\" width=\"1426\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">The&#38;Partnership</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The prototype also features bright colors to differentiate between the top and bottom of the test, a 50% larger absorbent pad, and a resistant grip on the reverse for ease.</p><h2>Traditional pregnancy tests rely on visual cues</h2><p>Currently, all pregnancy tests available in the market provide visual results. Women with visual impairments must ask for help to read their tests, and \"are therefore never the first to know what is happening to their own bodies,\" according to the companies behind the prototype, The&#38;Partnership and UK charity <a href=\"https://www.designforeveryone.org/\">the Royal National Institute of Blind People (RNIB)</a>.</p><p>This is despite more than 5 million pregnancy tests being sold in the UK every year, making them one of the most-used pieces of home medical equipment, according to the RNIB.</p><p>Danielle, a blind woman who was involved in the development of the prototype, said: \"I've taken a pregnancy test in the past and it's been negative, and the person who has been reading it has said 'Oh it's probably just as well though, isn't it?'\"</p><p>In the past, she has also resorted to asking her neighbor for help to read test results, because her then-partner also had a visual impairment.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f96e8b64743a3001216b99d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RNIB\" height=\"2160\" width=\"2880\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Danielle and her daughter. Danielle has had to ask for assistance to read her pregnancy test results.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The&#38;Partnership</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Not being able to read their results in private isn't the only problem visually impaired women face when using traditional pregnancy tests.</p><p>According to the RNIB, the packaging is difficult to open and the small size of the absorbent tip makes it difficult for women to tell whether they have sufficient urine on it.</p><p>The predominantly white designs of the tests also make it difficult for women to tell which way round the test should be held and where the results will appear. Visually impaired people also struggle with the small size of the font on the instructions and the electronic screen, the&#160; added.</p><h2>Accessible design is \"better for everyone\"</h2><p>Working alongside creative agency The&#38;Partnership and product designer Josh Wasserman, the RNIB stepped in to fix this problem.</p><p>The team spent two years designing an accessible pregnancy test to grant women everywhere \"the right to privacy and dignity.\"</p><p>The RNIB has worked previously with Procter &#38; Gamble and pregnancy test manufacturer Clearblue to produce an app for visually-impaired women. Users show their test to a volunteer on a video call, who reads the result to them.</p><p>But this new project is the UK's first fully-accessible pregnancy test prototype, allowing women with sight loss to know their results privately rather than having to find out through others, The&#38;Partnership told Business Insider.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f96e923f21803001222beac?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RNIB\" height=\"2160\" width=\"2880\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A woman holding the pregnancy test prototype. It features nodules that raise if the result is positive.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The&#38;Partnership</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Though the RNIB isn't producing the test beyond the prototype, the team has released its research and design exploration for free on <a href=\"https://www.designforeveryone.org/\">DesignForEveryone</a>, in the hope that other designers will be inspired to focus on accessibility.</p><p>Companies that embrace inclusive design outperform their competitors, <a href=\"https://www.accenture.com/us-en/insights/communications-media/accessibility-advantage\">research by Accenture shows,</a> because their intuitive and easy-to-use designs make products better for everyone. Past examples of accessible technology that have since become mainstream include the typewriter that inspired modern keyboards and voice-controlled home devices, The&#38;Partnership said.</p><p>\"For many women who are blind or partially sighted … their result becomes public, stripping them of their privacy and opening them up to comment and judgement from others,\" it added. \"Through creating the prototype, the team hopes to raise awareness that this, like so many other things, doesn't need to be the case.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/rnib-uk-accessible-pregnancy-test-for-blind-visually-impaired-women-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=2U057THFhO8:UVLHFXkQY2c:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=2U057THFhO8:UVLHFXkQY2c:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2U057THFhO8:UVLHFXkQY2c:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=2U057THFhO8:UVLHFXkQY2c:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2U057THFhO8:UVLHFXkQY2c:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=2U057THFhO8:UVLHFXkQY2c:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=2U057THFhO8:UVLHFXkQY2c:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2U057THFhO8:UVLHFXkQY2c:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/2U057THFhO8\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 15:30:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f96e7a7f21803001222bea3?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"bc1ccbe764c6d29b186b9b0a93a13334","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn35@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-12-124_3c51519c43d45c95.webp","destWidth":2880,"destHeight":2160,"sourceBytes":94436,"destBytes":94436,"author":"insider@insider.com (Grace Dean)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f96e7a7f21803001222bea3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn35@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-12-124_3c51519c43d45c95.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f96e8fff21803001222bea9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-35-566_35df6af287fd34b9.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f96e8b64743a3001216b99d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn33@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-39-038_fc68e1608734bb45.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f96e923f21803001222beac?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn73@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-36-660_93d2318b9fcb4421.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2U057THFhO8:UVLHFXkQY2c:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn20@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-36-189_ae2053b320888e74.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2U057THFhO8:UVLHFXkQY2c:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn44@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-32-296_c81b657042704df6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2U057THFhO8:UVLHFXkQY2c:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn37@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-38-423_33c44d83392c1240.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/2U057THFhO8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn32@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-29-848_36d0ac6b24ce7a2e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991870},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"I lost my job as an NYC public school teacher for having a provocative past. Here's how I turned the humiliating experience into a flourishing freelance career.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-i-turned-bad-experience-into-successful-freelance-career-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d7bb3c22e22af15ac25a7c5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Melissa Petro selfie\" height=\"866\" width=\"1155\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Melissa Petro turned to freelance writing and gig work after losing her job as a schoolteacher.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Melissa Petro / Instagram</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Melissa Petro is a freelance writer who lives with her husband and two children in New York City.</li>\n<li>In 2010, Petro lost her job as an elementary school teacher after months of negative press coverage attacking her for past experiences in the sex industry.</li>\n<li>Instead of giving into what she says was the most humiliating experience of her life, Petro took the loss of her teaching career as a lesson, and devoted herself to pursuing the career she'd always dreamed about &#8212; being a writer.</li>\n<li>She leaned on people who cared about her for advice and support, cut back on expenses, and hustled her way from earning under $20,000 to close to $60,000 a year.</li>\n<li>Above all, Petro found ways to turn her biggest liability into an asset, and used her story as an opportunity to get published on high profile platforms and gain writing experience.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>People often fantasize about giving up their daily grind to become a freelancer — and for many, freelance writing has a particular appeal.&#160;</p><p>For as long as I could remember, I had dreams of becoming a writer. Still, in college, I pursued what I felt was a more practical degree. I earned a BA in sociology and began a career in social services, working with economically disadvantaged women and girls. Coming from an economically disadvantaged background myself, I worked on and off in the sex industry to afford my education.&#160;</p><p>I wrote about my experiences in the sex industry, and harbored ambitions to write a memoir. But even after earning an MFA in creative nonfiction from the New School, writing felt like a somewhat embarrassing — and expensive — hobby. I pursued a second master's degree, this time in childhood education, to qualify for a \"real\" job: teaching art and writing at a public elementary school in the South Bronx.&#160;</p><h2><strong>I would've never quit my full-time job — and given up the salary and benefits — had I not been forced to do so</strong></h2><p>In 2010, a reporter from the New York Post took an interest in a 900-word <a href=\"https://www.huffpost.com/entry/post_803_b_707975\">essay</a> I wrote for the Huffington Post in which I talked candidly about a brief period in my life (in grad school) when I traded sex for cash. Some weeks after my essay ran, the tabloid plastered my picture on its cover under an intentionally shocking headline: \"Bronx Teacher Admits: I'm an Ex Hooker.\"</p><p>My employer at the time, the New York City Department of Education, immediately yanked me from the classroom and put me in reassignment, also known as the \"rubber room.\" After months of relentless negative press coverage, I resigned.</p><p>It was humiliating, but in retrospect, I'm better off for it. Here's how I turned the worst thing that's ever happened to me into a flourishing freelance career.</p><p><em><strong>Read more</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-recent-college-grads-make-6-figures-freelancing-2020-10\">How to make 6 figures as a freelancer right out of college, according to 3 recent grads bringing in over $100,000 a year</a></em></p><h2><strong>I let my loss wake me up</strong></h2><p>In a <a href=\"https://www.huffpost.com/entry/oprah-winfrey-career-advice_l_5e304f78c5b6ce51a4ec1c56\">lecture</a> to Stanford Graduate School of Business students, Oprah Winfrey argued there is no such thing as failure; Instead, she says, the purpose of any failure or loss is to move you in another, better direction. As Oprah put it: \"The losses are there to wake you up.\"&#160;</p><p>While the gist of this has always been a guiding principle of mine, I had never lived through something so seismic as the loss of my teaching career.&#160;</p><p>For months, news of my reassignment was everywhere. CNN ran the story as \"breaking news.\" CBS published a slideshow of my Facebook photos. Even then-<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/michael-bloomberg-called-for-removal-teacher-past-sex-work\">New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg weighed in on the matter,</a> condemning my conduct and suggesting what I'd done was somehow criminal.&#160;</p><p>Beyond the public humiliation, there were practical matters to consider. Financially, I had no savings or family to fall back on. I was scared.</p><p>Initially, I applied for positions similar to the one I'd lost — teaching jobs, daycare centers, nannying, as well as work in social services. Interviews pretty much ended just as soon as my potential employer would ask, \"Why did you leave your last job?\" I seemed like no one wanted to associate themselves with a woman dubbed the \"hooker teacher.\"</p><p>In moments like these, there's a temptation to panic. Instead, as Oprah said: \"Get still and ask yourself, 'what is the next right move?'\"&#160;</p><p>My situation began to improve when I stopped applying for jobs I didn't really want anyway and surrendered to reality.</p><h2><strong>I turned to people I knew would have my back</strong></h2><p>When the whole situation first started, I sent SOS emails to nearly everyone I knew, asking for advice and assistance. I had a fair number of contacts from grad school and within the literary community. Many expressed outrage at what was happening to me, and wanted to help.</p><p>Rather than another plum salary position in a field not necessarily related to writing, I began cobbling together part-time gigs that would ultimately support my career as a writer.&#160;&#160;</p><p>I did data entry for $10 an hour at a prestigious literary journal. I scored a gig teaching memoir-writing, and then another. And I worked for free, teaching writing workshops to marginalized communities including drug users, survivors of sexual exploitation, and LGBTQ teens. I applied for grants, and eventually the volunteer work started to pay.&#160;&#160;</p><p>I also continued to write, pitch, and publish my writing as much as I could.</p><h2><strong>I turned my biggest liability into an asset&#160;</strong></h2><p>A decade later, I've written on a variety of topics: <a href=\"https://psmag.com/news/a-literary-festival-in-the-shadow-of-genocide\">a literary festival in Sri Lanka</a>, a <a href=\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/gyxgaw/noura-al-jizawi-profile-syrian-female-prisoners\">Syrian activist who survived arbitrary detention</a>, and a <a href=\"https://nationswell.com/bicycle-deaths-new-york-nyc/\">memorial project to honor bicyclists killed in traffic accidents</a>, to name a few.&#160;</p><p>But initially, I had one story that people wanted to hear about and so <a href=\"https://www.salon.com/2011/05/05/hooker_teacher_what_i_was_thinking/\">I sold it</a>. I sold it <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2012/mar/28/lost-job-teacher-call-girl\">again</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.thecut.com/2013/07/we-pardon-spitzer-not-ex-sex-workers-like-me.html\">again</a>, and <a href=\"https://jezebel.com/dear-new-york-post-im-a-teacher-not-a-hooker-5934243\">again</a>, and <a href=\"http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2014/12/a-day-to-respectandunderstandsexworkers.html\">again</a>. In some ways, you might say that here, right now, I am selling it again. It's a fresh angle (humiliating scandal) on an evergreen topic (how to make it as a freelancer).&#160;</p><p>I learned about things like story angles and other aspects of craft from my editors. Sure, my MFA was an enriching experience, but I wouldn't say it prepared me at all for the business of freelancing. Instead, thanks to my provocative story, I had the chance to publish on high-profile platforms and work with amazing professionals who were extremely patient with me as an inexperienced writer. Because I had a story they wanted that only I could tell, editors were willing to teach me the ropes.&#160;</p><p>Besides the bit about brushing off failure, this is my number one word of advice to new writers: If you offer an editor a story that only you can tell, they will help you tell it.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/marketing-director-quit-job-freelance-50k-to-250k-email-template\">A marketing director making $50,000 quit her job and now makes five times more as a freelancer. Here's the email template she used to build a subscriber network of over 100,000 people.</a></em></p><h2><strong>I lowered my expenses&#160;</strong></h2><p>My first year as a freelance writer, I made less than $20,000. I lived on this, plus unemployment, plus credit cards. It was rough.&#160;</p><p>To lower my expenses, I moved back in with an on-again, off-again boyfriend. The apartment was in my name, and he eventually moved out, leaving me with a super cheap living situation. I saved money in other ways as well. Rather than taking the subway, I'd walk from one gig to the next. I washed my clothes by hand in the bathtub. I skipped meals. I don't recommend any of this to anyone. If you want to transition from full-time work to freelancing, have some savings, if you can. Otherwise, be prepared to make sacrifices.&#160;</p><h2><strong>I hustled harder than ever</strong></h2><p>When you think freelancer, you might picture Carrie Bradshaw scribbling down her most intimate thoughts on life and love, in between extravagant shopping trips and lunch dates with the girls. Especially in a slow economy, some people hear freelancer and think \"unemployed.\"</p><p>In truth, freelancing is hard work.</p><p>I pitch literally hundreds of story ideas each year. I sell maybe a dozen. In the beginning, most articles sold for $100- $200 a piece. I was single and child-free then, and so I worked all the time and was always available to respond to a news peg. Side gigs — more than writing — paid my bills. These days, my rate has gone up significantly — good thing too, because as a mom of two I've got a lot less time on my hands.&#160;</p><p>You can earn a decent income from writing alone if you have the time and ability to hustle, or once you have some experience. The year before I got married and became pregnant, I think I made around $60,000 — just under what I'd earned as a public school teacher. This year, I'll make about half that, in only a quarter of the time.&#160;</p><p>Over a decade later, I still miss public school teaching. I loved my profession and I sometimes wish I had a \"real\" job — and then I remember: I do.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/how-i-turned-bad-experience-into-successful-freelance-career-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=sDg_T9wm3Ds:5Fr_iN1HATs:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a 2020 14:41:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5d7bb3c22e22af15ac25a7c5?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"878b380edcf9b835087ff756cc32e6e2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn19@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-04-327_b91cca481f59aba0.webp","destWidth":1155,"destHeight":866,"sourceBytes":44798,"destBytes":44798,"author":"insider@insider.com (Melissa Petro)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5d7bb3c22e22af15ac25a7c5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn19@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-04-327_b91cca481f59aba0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=sDg_T9wm3Ds:5Fr_iN1HATs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn80@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-27-398_a8c066a59e9df803.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=sDg_T9wm3Ds:5Fr_iN1HATs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn85@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-38-078_705693e887529d7b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=sDg_T9wm3Ds:5Fr_iN1HATs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn64@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-31-352_244551aa64874b7f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/sDg_T9wm3Ds":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn57@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-37-644_4ce3e9bc4c5f88bf.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991843},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"JPMorgan’s quant chief shares 5 trade recommendations following Pfizer’s vaccine ‘game-changer’","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/market-strategy-5-trade-tips-kolanovic-coronavirus-vaccine-rotation-jpm-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faed1811c741f0019ac9b66?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Pfizer NYSE\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brendan McDermid/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pfizer-coronavirus-vaccine-success-plans-for-emergency-approval-fda-2020-9?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\"></a><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pfizer-coronavirus-vaccine-success-plans-for-emergency-approval-fda-2020-9?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\">Pfizer's vaccine progress</a> \"is a game-changer\" that will sustain a broad market rotation through the end of the year, Marko Kolanovic, a top quantitative strategist at <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/jpm-stock?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">JPMorgan</a>, said Thursday.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>Monday saw the <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-value-rotation-previews-2021-action-strategy-outlook-jpmorgan-2020-11-1029798647\">biggest single-day rotation into value stocks since 2008</a>, but there's still room for cyclical sectors to rally, according to the bank.</strong></li><li><strong>With volatility plummeting and investors turning more bearish on a likely divided US government in 2021, investors in other markets are also taking on more risk.</strong></li><li><strong>Here are the five trading strategies Kolanovic recommended for the broad rotation.</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestutm_source=msn.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=msn-slideshow&utm_campaign=bodyurl?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestts&#38;utm_medium=ingest\">Visit the Business Insider homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pfizer-coronavirus-vaccine-success-plans-for-emergency-approval-fda-2020-9?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\">Pfizer's vaccine update</a> sparked a mass rush to risky assets. With reactionary trades largely played-out, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/jpm-stock\">JPMorgan's</a> top quant recommends five strategies for benefiting further from the market rotation.</p><p>Stocks notched a weekly gain despite choppy price action and soaring coronavirus case counts. Pfizer's Monday announcement that its experimental vaccine was more than 90% effective at preventing COVID-19 fueled new market optimism and led investors to bet on a sooner-than-expected economic recovery. By the end of the day, the stock market saw its <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-value-rotation-previews-2021-action-strategy-outlook-jpmorgan-2020-11-1029798647\">biggest single-day rotation to value stocks since 2008</a>.</p><p>The vaccine news \"is a game-changer,\" but those who missed out on the week's biggest rallies still have the chance to benefit, Marko Kolanovic, head of macro quantitative and derivatives strategy at <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/jpm-stock?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">JPMorgan</a>, said. With volatility plummeting from recent highs and investors' risk appetites improving, several long plays stand to outperform as the US comes closer to distributing a vaccine, he added.</p><p>Here are the five strategies Kolanovic laid out to clients:&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-jeffrey-gundlach-likens-market-to-tech-bubble-2020-11\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">'The most dangerous type of market': Billionaire Bond King Jeffrey Gundlach says stocks are entering the difficult final stages of their cycle — and warns the market will 'crack pretty hard' in the near future</a></em></p><h3>Pushing further into stocks</h3><p>A combination of moderate investor positioning, divided government, vaccine hopes, and rebounding profits creates \"one of the best backdrops\" for stocks in years, Kolanovic said in the Thursday note. JPMorgan expects the S&#38;P 500 to climb slightly higher to 3,600 by the end of the year and to 4,000 by early 2021.</p><p>As such, the top quant recommended investors turn increasingly overweight in stocks. The pivot can be funded by selling off bonds, he added.</p><p>The two run-off Senate races in Georgia present a significant risk to the trade, as a Democratic sweep would make it easier for a Biden administration to pass tax hikes and stricter regulations. Still, Kolanovic said the likelihood of such an outcome is small, and that it only poses short-term uncertainty.</p><h3>Equities abroad</h3><p>As beneficial as the divided-government election outcome can be for US stocks, emerging-markets equities will jump even higher, according to the firm. A weakening US dollar, reduced geopolitical risk, cheap emerging-markets valuations, and light positioning will all contribute to the group's outperformance, Kolanovic said.</p><p>The bank holds \"overweight\" ratings on Korean, Brazilian, and Russian stocks. Malaysian, Colombian, and Middle East-North African stocks hold an underweight rating.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/where-to-invest-in-2021-themes-driving-markets-goldman-sachs-2020-11\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Goldman Sachs unveils the top 10 themes it expects to drive the markets in 2021 — and shares where to invest your money</a></em></p><h3>Shifting to cyclical</h3><p>Even though Monday saw a massive move from growth stocks to cyclical sectors, there's still room for the trade to gain. Kolanovic recommended investors brace for a sustained rotation into value and cyclical names as the market prepares for an end to the global health crisis.</p><p>\"The backdrop of a globally synchronized expansion, legislative gridlock, and positive vaccine news should mark a breakout point for value stocks,\" Kolanovic said, adding that momentum and growth names \"should lag\" through the rotation.</p><p>The quant guru pointed to \"unsustainably stretched\" growth-to-value correlation and continued crowding in momentum stocks for the call. A \"severe dislocation\" between the two market groups remains, leaving plenty of opportunity left for those who missed the recent rotation.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-strong-returns-low-prices-credit-suisse-2020-11?r=gr-sub\" data-analytics-position=\"1\" data-analytics-module=\"\">CREDIT SUISSE: Buy these 8 stocks now because they're set to benefit from a powerful combination of strong returns and low expectations</a></em></p><h3>Boost commodities, dump cash</h3><p>Cyclical commodities including energy, metals, and agricultural products that languished throughout the pandemic are set to rally alongside a broader economic rebound, Kolanovic said. Gold prices will sink as investors shift away from safe havens, he added.</p><p>\"Our Oil Strategists believe the pandemic, not the election, is the main driver for crude, as oil markets need to clear current imbalances before long-dated prices can rise, and US production is likely to fall next year under any administration,\" the strategist wrote.</p><p>To help finance the commodity trade, JPMorgan recommended going underweight in another safe-haven asset: government bonds. US yields, despite partially recovering through the week, still sit near record lows as investors stay put in the stable assets. Improving economic data and Pfizer's vaccine update lifted the bank's medium-term outlook, and a rotation to riskier assets can quickly drag on sovereign debt.</p><p>Holding cash through the rotation was also ill-advised, as the dollar is set to weaken and investors would be missing out on sizeable gains across several markets.</p><p>Still, shrinking bets on government debt shouldn't push investors from bonds altogether. JPMorgan reiterated its \"overweight\" rating for corporate credit as spreads exceed year-end targets.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-tips-for-success-william-danoff-shares-market-beating-guide-2020-11?r=gr-sub\" data-analytics-position=\"4\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Peter Lynch disciple William Danoff manages over $124 billion and has beaten the market for 30 years. He shares the 10 investment rules that ensured his success.</a></em></p><h3>'Dash for trash'</h3><p>That's not to say investors can't be choosy in the corporate debt space. Kolanovic reversed his \"underweight\" rating for high-yield debt, adding that a shift away from high-grade corporate credit leaves plenty of cash available to lift junk bonds.&#160;</p><p>\"The Pfizer vaccine news sparked a 'dash for trash' as investors grab issues from companies most affected by the pandemic, which have lagged in recent months,\" he wrote.</p><p>Drivers of the upcoming rally include under-positioning, dealer de-risking, and resolution of key risks. Vaccine-fueled optimism is just \"icing on the cake,\" the bank said. Continued support from the Federal Reserve also diminishes the risks typically associated with such bonds.</p><p>In Europe, the bank's strategists recommend positioning heavily for outperformance in sectors hit hardest by the pandemic. Non-cyclicals will lag relative to the broader corporate credit market, they added.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Now read more markets coverage from Markets Insider and Business Insider:</strong></em></p><p><em><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-cathie-wood-ark-invest-shares-2-innovation-winners-2020-11\" data-analytics-position=\"5\" data-analytics-module=\"\">ARK CEO Cathie Wood is beating 98% of her peers this year. She and her team share the investment cases for 2 'winner-take-most' stocks in their portfolios, and explain why she is unfazed by the rotation into value.</a></strong></em></p><p><em><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-coronavirus-cases-spiked-fiscal-stimulus-expired-economic-recovery-chart-2020-11\" data-analytics-position=\"1\" data-analytics-module=\"\">One alarming chart shows virus cases spiked soon after initial stimulus efforts were exhausted</a></strong></em></p><p><em><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/consumer-sentiment-falls-surging-covid19-cases-concern-economic-recovery-umich-2020-11\" data-analytics-position=\"2\" data-analytics-module=\"\">US consumer sentiment falls for the first time in 4 months as spiking COVID-19 cases spur worry</a></strong></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"The world's largest wealth manager says stocks still have upside after Monday's vaccine rally — and offers 4 sectors with the greatest potential","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-outlook-ubs-4-sectors-upside-rally-vaccine-haefele-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faef3881c741f0019ac9c7b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"NYSE Trader\" height=\"2000\" width=\"4000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Bryan R Smith/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>The certainty of an economic recovery has increased now that the election has concluded and a fiscal stimulus and coronavirus vaccine are likely on the way, according to UBS's Mark Haefele.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>The global chief investment officer said on Friday that he expects the S&#38;P 500 to gain roughly 6% by mid-2021 with new stock sectors taking leadership.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>In a monthly letter to clients published Friday, Haefele recommended investors seek out small-and-mid-cap stocks, global industrials, consumer discretionary, and US financial stocks to find returns.</strong></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\"><strong>Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</strong></a><strong style=\"color: #222222;\">.</strong></li></ul><hr><p>The stock rally that ensued after Monday's positive vaccine news isn't the last time stocks will shoot higher, but new sectors will begin to take leadership in the next few months, according to UBS wealth management's global chief investment officer.&#160;</p><p>\"Last month, I argued that the US election would unlock new stimulus, successful vaccine trials would increase certainty about the economic outlook, and that central bank policy makes the long-term case for equities over cash clear,\" Mark Haefele said. \"With these drivers playing out, and with uncertainty over the economic and market outlook reducing, we expect market leadership to change.\"</p><p>In the monthly letter to clients published Friday, Haefele recommended looking for returns within sectors that have scope to \"catch up\" as the vaccine begins to facilitate an economic recovery.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-jeffrey-gundlach-likens-market-to-tech-bubble-2020-11\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">'The most dangerous type of market': Billionaire Bond King Jeffrey Gundlach says stocks are entering the difficult final stages of their cycle — and warns the market will 'crack pretty hard' in the near future</a></em></p><p>Small-and-mid cap stocks, global industrials, consumer discretionary, and US financial stocks are four sectors with upside, Haefele said have upside.&#160;</p><p>The CIO also said third quarter corporate earnings were stronger than he expected —and the data reflects that. Nearly 85% of companies beat earnings estimates in the third quarter. Estimates for fourth quarter earnings have risen by 2.7%, and forecasts for the next year are up as well, Haefele added.</p><p>With earnings surprising to the upside and valuation multiples justified by the continued low interest rates, plus a vaccine on the horizon, UBS expects the <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/s&p_500_500\">S&#38;P 500</a> to trade at 3,800 by June of 2021, roughly 6% higher than Friday's levels.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/where-to-invest-in-2021-themes-driving-markets-goldman-sachs-2020-11\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Goldman Sachs unveils the top 10 themes it expects to drive the markets in 2021 — and shares where to invest your money</a></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read 2020 13:08:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5faef3a61c741f0019ac9c7c?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"d6d9429a424d79ff9a5e669fbb2c1b48","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn49@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-40-148_b8b910c6c07c4b80.webp","destWidth":3552,"destHeight":2664,"sourceBytes":246102,"destBytes":246102,"author":"egraffeo@businessinsider.com (Emily Graffeo)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5faef3881c741f0019ac9c7b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn23@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-29-076_e47ed16b108675a2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=SQbhK7CpgGc:tkWTD9r8kew:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn4@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-26-232_00cc524fca5f2c4f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=SQbhK7CpgGc:tkWTD9r8kew:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn1@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-37-990_377329b01e842e65.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=SQbhK7CpgGc:tkWTD9r8kew:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn91@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-31-573_43e9798908e709d1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/SQbhK7CpgGc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn64@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-26-016_ff97e89ab90eeb50.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991873},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Meet the millennial cofounders of Apparis, the cult-favorite vegan coat brand that raised $3 million in funding this year and just launched a collaboration with Juicy Couture","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/apparis-founders-talk-latest-funding-round-juicy-couture-partnership-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9786084743a3001216bce0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Apparis Founders\" height=\"641\" width=\"853\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lauren Nouchi (L) and Amelie Brick (R), the cofounders of Apparis. Nouchi was featured in this year&#39;s Forbes&#39; 30 under 30 Arts &#38; Style list.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Apparis</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><strong>Amelie Brick, 37, and Lauren Nouchi, 29, are the cofounders of Apparis, an apparel company best known for its vegan coats.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>The brand just officially launched a collaboration to reinvent the famous Juicy Couture tracksuit.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>Earlier this year, it c</strong><strong>losed a $3 million round in funding, and counts Karlie Kloss and footballer Cam Newton as backers, </strong><a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexandrasternlicht/2020/08/25/vegan-fur-coat-maker-apparis-raises-3-million-to-expand-cruelty-free-fashion/#10afc3072442\"><strong>as reported by Forbes</strong></a><strong>.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>The brand has also expanded into homewear, as the pandemic continues to sweep through the world, and the cofounders say they anticipate people spending even more time at home. </strong></li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Amelie Brick and Lauren Nouchi are the cofounders of Apparis, an apparel brand best known making vegan coats — fur that doesn't come from real animals.</p><p>They quit their jobs in luxury fashion to launch the company in 2016 after they saw a gap in the fur market, Nouchi told Business Insider, anticipating a decline in demand for real fur over the next few years, leaving space for an alternative.</p><p>Brick, 37, and Nouchi, 29, are both from the southern French city of Marseille. They knew of each other through mutual friends and family and teamed up to launch Apparis in, well, Paris.</p><p>Enter, their vegan cur coat line, Apparis, which began hosting pop-up shops in Williamsburg in 2017,&#160;showing off a few vegan coat designs created by Nouchi, and has since become known for its Goldie fur jacket, which retails for $230.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9786384743a3001216bce1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Apparis\" height=\"1300\" width=\"1080\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Hot Thunderstorm Studio</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The coats ended up being so popular that they caught the attention of a buyer for Bloomingdale's, who asked them to present a collection. Nouchi said it was just in time.</p><p>\"At the time, nobody was really doing what we were doing,\" Nouchi said. \"I feel like if we had the same idea for vegan coats now, we would be too late.\"&#160;</p><p>Indeed, over the past two years, Nordstrom and Macy's announced they would <a href=\"https://nypost.com/2020/09/29/nordstrom-to-ban-fur-exotic-skins-in-its-stores/\">ban the sell of real fur</a>, with the latter <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/macys-bloomingdales-will-stop-selling-fur-2019-10\">banning all unethically sourced produced</a> from its stores. Gucci, Burberry, Versace, and Coach have also opted for alternatives to real fur. Fur farming has also been banned by many countries, including Norway, Germany, and Belgium, as well as the state of California, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/14/style/fur-ban-california.html\">as reported by The New York Times.</a>&#160;</p><p>Today, the brand is sold in Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue, Moda Operandi, and hundreds of other major retailers. <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexandrasternlicht/2020/08/25/vegan-fur-coat-maker-apparis-raises-3-million-to-expand-cruelty-free-fashion/#10afc3072442\">As reported by Forbes</a>, the brand made $7.3 million in revenue last year, with wholesale accounting for 60%.&#160;</p><p>To source its vegan fur, Brick says she tapped into the network of people she already knew, and connected with a man who owned a business that specializes in vegan fur production. He helped them produce their now-signature vegan fur, which they call PlucheTM faux fur.&#160;</p><p>\"I explained to him that I and my business partner had big plans to expand into the US markets,\" Brick says. \" And that we wanted to bring very amazing, yet affordable alternatives to real fur.\"&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f987e76861cb70019936ceb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Apparis\" height=\"1200\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Hot Thunderstorm Studio</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>How Apparis raised $3 million in its latest funding round</h2><p>At first, Brick says they bootstrapped the business, putting together their savings and investing every dollar made back into the company. They didn't have plans to raise funding at first, but eventually decided to seek investors.&#160;</p><p>One female investor, Brick said, really fell in love with their business plan and ended up helping them navigate the tricky field of VC funding, by introducing them to other VCs and angel investors that ended up investing in the business.&#160;</p><p>The result is that they were able to raise <a href=\"https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/apparis-announces-3m-seed-funding-301117913.html\">$3 million in funding</a> this past year, despite the pandemic. It took them a year to raise funding, Brick told Business Insider, because they were very selective about who they decided to bring on. Current investors include Third Kind Venture Capital and Exor Seeds, model Karlie Kloss, and even Cam Newton, who discovered the brand at one of their pop-up shops in New York City.&#160;</p><p>\"We were looking to bring in people who deeply believe in the long-term value of the brand,\" Brick says. \"And we met really interesting people that gave us a perspective beyond our own industry.\"&#160;</p><h2><strong>As the pandemic continues, the brand pivots to home wear&#160;</strong></h2><p>Right now, about 15 people work full-time for the company, Brick said, including on their creative teams, product team, sales team, and on their supply chain. \"Everyone is doing a lot more than what they are supposed to do, for sure,\" she said.&#160;</p><p>About 80% of Apparis products are made in one factory in China, and Brick said they are \"conservative\" with inventory. They typically try to buy in small batches rather than big productions, to help prevent waste.&#160;</p><p>Having only one factory in China helped them during the pandemic, Brick said, because they weren't too impacted by the manufacturing and production shutdowns that affected many retailers throughout the world.</p><p>This was because by the time COVID hit Europe and the Americas in March, China was already getting better. Luckily, March is usually when the company begins production, and they were able to (cautiously) continue manufacturing their coats, Nouchi said.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f97865ef21803001222c1ee?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Apparis Home\" height=\"1080\" width=\"1080\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Apparis Home.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Hot Thunderstorm Studio</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>So they took this time instead to focus on rebranding the company. They focused heavily on the social media strategy and decided to use excess fabric that was left over in their factory to launch a home collection label, which was released this month.</p><p>Nouchi said they decided to launch this new collection because they were anticipating that people would continue to spend more time at home and would be looking to purchase items such as candles and pajamas.&#160;</p><p>Indeed, luxury retailers <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/luxury-shopping-trends-during-pandemic-moda-operandi-report-2020-5\">Moda Operandi, Olivela, and The RealReal</a> both told Business Insider that they have seen an uptick in purchases for items such as home decor and casual wear such as sweatpants, as people have begun spending more time at home.</p><p>In the weeks after March 9, Moda Operandi said that searches for the word \"sweats\" rose 50% on their website, while The RealReal revealed in August that demand skyrocketed for items such as candles and pillows, increasing 90% and 216% from March to June, respectively.&#160;</p><p>\"We did a test launch in April and decided to extend the category and launch a much bigger collection for home in the fall,\" Nouchi said, adding that their home collection includes pajamas, eye masks, candles, headbands, and slippers.&#160;</p><p>\"We were able to reinvent ourselves,\" she continued. \"And innovate and be online and follow what the consumers are currently purchasing.\"&#160;</p><h2><strong>The brand has also recently released a collaboration with Juicy Couture&#160;</strong></h2><p>Fresh off its $3 million funding round and the launch of its home collection, the duo still found time to land a collaboration with '90s staple Juicy Couture, which was released on October 29th.&#160;</p><p>The partnership, according to Nouchi, happened quite simply. They were looking to do an outside-of-the-box collaboration and liked Juicy Couture's big name and nostalgia appeal, so they made an approach, and the brand loved it.&#160;</p><p>\"Basically what we decided to do was reinvent their tracksuits,\" Nouchi said. \"We took their iconic shapes, and we developed exclusivity for this collaboration, a very thin fur that is very soft.\"&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9786ac4743a3001216bce2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Apparis\" height=\"3000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Apparis Juicy Collection.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Hot Thunderstorm Studio</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The collection, known as Faux Fur Fantasy, is made with Apparis' signature PlucheTM faux fur and vegan shearling fabric. It was modeled by Brenn and Jules Lorenzo, known as the Skate Kitchen Twins, part of an all-female skate crew called Skate Kitchen.&#160;</p><p>It's also the 25th anniversary of the Juicy tracksuit, an emblem of the '90s and early 2000s, which has been seen on everyone from Paris Hilton to Kim Kardashian.&#160;</p><p>Nouchi said the company, which previously collaborated with Diane von Furstenberg on jackets, plans to partner with more high-profile brands in the future. It would like to enter into more \"out-of-the-box\" kinds of partnerships that will continue to push the creativity of the brand.&#160;</p><p>\"It's all about being bold, daring to be different, and really aligning again with what we are trying to say,\" she continued. \"We want to make cruelty-free fashion, and we want to do it in a way that empowers women. That's just part of the DNA of Apparis.\"&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
