2020 17:05:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f9786084743a3001216bce0?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"00c953875f989b05471672a9de68f74f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn64@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-05-509_454aeaf4aa4bad33.webp","destWidth":853,"destHeight":641,"sourceBytes":28906,"destBytes":28906,"author":"ddavis@businessinsider.com (Dominic-Madori Davis)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f9786084743a3001216bce0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn64@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-05-509_454aeaf4aa4bad33.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9786384743a3001216bce1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn31@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-24-939_3abd002be33f98f5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f987e76861cb70019936ceb?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn68@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-31-153_9864988e819af37c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f97865ef21803001222c1ee?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn20@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-32-984_d03232f84c109591.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9786ac4743a3001216bce2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn71@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-27-158_4b4c6547ccab9642.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LFj9V21Au9c:pJABfqjczSU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn64@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-29-056_f7acd7135f321c95.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LFj9V21Au9c:pJABfqjczSU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn34@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-35-389_4aee64cdf2b28474.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LFj9V21Au9c:pJABfqjczSU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn65@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-963_8e2720ed8eea38b8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/LFj9V21Au9c":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn32@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-30-827_8d443f4a28971f8b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991905},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Enlisted sailors aboard the Navy's aircraft carriers are at higher risk for COVID-19, new study shows","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/enlisted-sailors-aboard-navy-aircraft-carriers-higher-covid-19-risk-2020-11","description":"<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5eb190c15785326cc2295916?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Navy aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt sailors\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   Sailors board the the aircraft carrier USS Theodore Roosevelt, May 2, 2020. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">US Navy/Seaman Alexander Williams</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\"> \n <li>Tight confines aboard US Navy ships mean coronavirus is more likely to spread among enlisted crew members, according to a study released this week.</li> \n <li>A separate military study on COVID-19 among Marine recruits at Parris Island in South Carolina also highlights the challenge of catching asymptomatic cases.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li> \n</ul>\n<p>Coronavirus cases are more likely to spread among enlisted crew members on <a href=\"http://www.military.com/navy\">Navy</a> ships, a new study released this week found, due to the sailors' tight living and workspaces.</p>\n<p>Enlisted sailors on the <a href=\"https://www.military.com/equipment/nimitz-class-aircraft-carrier\">aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt</a> were more likely than officers to have confirmed or suspected cases of COVID-19, a study published this week in the New England Journal of Medicine found.</p>\n<p>Not only do enlisted personnel make up the bulk of the Roosevelt's crew at about 90%, but they also \"sleep in open bays packed with dozens of tightly spaced bunks, work in densely populated areas, and congregate in gathering points such as the gyms and galleys,\" the study states.</p>\n<p>\"These conditions probably facilitated the transmission of [the virus], as evidenced by the higher likelihood of COVID-19 among enlisted crew members than among officers,\" researchers found.</p>\n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5eda476cf34d05536c139844?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Navy aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt sailor\" height=\"1406\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   Sailors in the navigation bridge on aircraft carrier USS Theodore Roosevelt, June 4, 2020. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">US Navy/MCS 3rd Class Zachary Wheeler</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<p>Sailors working in closed spaces — including in reactor, engineering, supply or weapons departments — were more likely to have the illness than those who spent more time in open-air conditions, the study found. Some of the first positive COVID-19 cases on the Roosevelt were from the reactor department.</p>\n<p>The findings match what experts have said about the likelihood for the virus to spread faster indoors than outside, where it can dissipate. The study also found that those in the medical department who wore personal protective equipment had a somewhat lower \"attack rate\" despite the personnel being exposed to infected patients in small spaces.</p>\n<p>Aside from tight quarters, disease spread by pre- and asymptomatic crew members was another big challenge.</p>\n<p>\"Nearly half of those who tested positive for the virus never had symptoms,\" the study found.</p>\n<p>A separate military study on COVID-19 among Marine recruits at <a href=\"http://www.military.com/base-guide/marine-corps-recruit-depot-parris-island\">Parris Island</a> in South Carolina also highlights the challenge of catching asymptomatic cases. In a study of more than 1,800 recruits there, daily temperature checks and symptom monitoring failed to identify all the positive cases.</p>\n<p>Fifteen of the 16 recruits who tested positive for the virus within two days of their arrival showed no COVID-19 symptoms.</p>\n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/554a5abaeab8eab60e4ac2e1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"marines parris island\" height=\"1196\" width=\"2048\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   Marine recruits at Parris Island. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">US Marine Corps Photo</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<p>\"Most recruits who tested positive were asymptomatic, and no infections were detected through daily symptom monitoring,\" the study says, which could mean that temperature checks and symptom screenings in some colleges, theme parks and workplaces won't catch all positive cases.</p>\n<p>Researchers say the lessons from the Roosevelt and Parris Island studies can be applied to some civilian settings where people live or work in tight quarters, such as college dorms, nursing homes or meat-packaging plants.</p>\n<p>The studies' findings might point to the need for quarantine periods to last longer than two weeks, a doctor wrote in the medical journal following the report, considering that cases were still emerging among Marine recruits at Parris Island more than 14 days after they arrived.</p>\n<p>\"The results of this study show that the ability of screening procedures to detect infection before and after quarantine needs to be strengthened,\" the paper states.</p>\n<p><em>— Gina Harkins can be reached at <a href=\"mailto:gina.harkins@military.com\">gina.harkins@military.com</a>. Follow her on Twitter<a href=\"http://www.twitter.com/ginaaharkins\"> @ginaaharkins</a>.</em></p>\n<div class=\"read-original\">\n Read the original article on \n <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/enlisted-sailors-aboard-navy-aircraft-carriers-higher-covid-19-risk-2020-11\">Business Insider</a>\n</div>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=RytsF3zT4gk:q471zXAZtTg:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=RytsF3zT4gk:q471zXAZtTg:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RytsF3zT4gk:q471zXAZtTg:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=RytsF3zT4gk:q471zXAZtTg:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RytsF3zT4gk:q471zXAZtTg:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=RytsF3zT4gk:q471zXAZtTg:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=RytsF3zT4gk:q471zXAZtTg:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RytsF3zT4gk:q471zXAZtTg:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/RytsF3zT4gk\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 14:45:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5ee38ebdf0f4190b6b2deeb7?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"72080d4fbd223ed9661230941d546155","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn62@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-39-947_221e5c96a484a2b4.webp","destWidth":1875,"destHeight":1406,"sourceBytes":72068,"destBytes":72068,"author":"insider@insider.com (Gina Harkins)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5eb190c15785326cc2295916?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn20@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-29-667_9165b688d8b1e7be.webp","https://i.insider.com/5eda476cf34d05536c139844?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn97@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-33-875_2d5e9b3e97a78ba4.webp","https://i.insider.com/554a5abaeab8eab60e4ac2e1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn94@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-34-825_8b2d5590fd195cdc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RytsF3zT4gk:q471zXAZtTg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn91@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-27-300_9d9c0822f40f15a2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RytsF3zT4gk:q471zXAZtTg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn48@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-30-031_2ce7a3befd5426cc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=RytsF3zT4gk:q471zXAZtTg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn96@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-38-888_886f028f66e6c10c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/RytsF3zT4gk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn6@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-34-895_35e9c3f543a72a1e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991839},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Werner Herzog's new film, 'Fireball,' explores the power and mystery of meteorites","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/werner-herzog-new-film-about-meteorites-fireball-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faea89c4652d40019744399?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Fireball_Photo_0106\" height=\"4480\" width=\"6720\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>British volcanologist Clive Oppenheimer speaks with Professor Simon Schaffer about the Ensisheim meteorite in &#34;Fireball: Visitors from Darker Worlds.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Apple TV&#43;</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>\"Fireball,\" a new documentary about meteors directed by Werner Herzog and Clive Oppenheimer, premiered Friday on Apple TV+.&#160;</li>\n<li>The documentary explores the role that space rocks have played in shaping the world's history.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>On November 7, 1492, a fiery space rock whistled through the sky. It rocketed into a wheat field near the town of Ensisheim, in modern-day France, punching a hole 3 feet deep into the soil. A young boy was its only witness, according to historical accounts.&#160;</p><p>Ensisheim at that point was the headquarters of Austrian troops. Just weeks after the meteor's arrival, the Austrian military commander, King Maximilian, came to the town on his way to battle the French. Upon learning about the impact, Maximilian declared it to be a sign of divine favor – and the town believed him.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faeab4e1e8d5000198135d2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Fireball_Photo_0102\" height=\"2592\" width=\"4608\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Werner Herzog films during &#34;Fireball: Visitors From Darker Worlds.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Apple TV&#43;</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>\"For those people, wonderful supernatural signs in the heavens were messages,\" Professor Simon Schaffer, of Cambridge&#160;University, says in <a href=\"https://tv.apple.com/us/movie/fireball-visitors-from-darker-worlds/umc.cmc.4kxqi7mmx247xjrdfll0lsme1?at=1000lDR&itscg=MC_20000&itsct=atvp_brand_omd&mttnagencyid=1625&mttncc=US&mttngadurl=https%3A%2F%2Ftv.apple.com%2Fus%2Fmovie%2Ffireball-visitors-from-darker-worlds%2Fumc.cmc.4kxqi7mmx247xjrdfll0lsme1%3F&mttngmo=&mttnmyad=472470645547&mttnmysite=uqa99n2zg0&mttnpid=305109&mttnsiteid=143238&mttnsub1=b&mttnsub2=c&mttnsub3=s4kLbwLsc_472470645547_uqa99n2zg0_c&mttnsubad=OUS2019882-1&mttnsubadgpname=kwd-296703568482&mttnsubadgpref=115212621070&mttnsubadref=&mttnsubcmp=11352840452&mttnsubkw=%2Bfireball&mttnsubpid=g&mttnsubplmnt=;mttnsubcmp=11352840452&#38;mttnsubkw=%2Bfireball&#38;mttnsubpid=g&#38;mttnsubplmnt=\">\"Fireball: Visitors from Darker Worlds,\" a new documentary</a> from filmmaker Werner Herzog about meteorites. \"This was, as it were, an email sent from God to the subjects of Maximilian to tell them that his rule was legitimate, that he'd defeat his enemies, and that they should obey his command.\"</p><p>Herzog co-directed the documentary with British volcanologist Clive Oppenheimer. It premiered Friday on Apple TV+ and takes viewers on a sightseeing tour of some of the world's most historic meteorites and impact craters. The film also features the people who study these space rocks.&#160;</p><p>This is the second documentary Herzog and Oppenheimer have made together; the previous one, <a href=\"https://www.netflix.com/title/80066073\">\"Into the Inferno,\"</a> was about volcanoes. With \"Fireball,\" the pair hope to further elevate science through filmmaking.</p><p>\"We always said, 'this has to be a new form,'\" Herzog told Business Insider. \"'We should depart from the National Geographic movies. Yes, they have very good stuff, but let's put it on a different level. This sense of awe, the raw excitement.'\"&#160;</p><h2>'Stones that are falling from the heavens'</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faea9e61e8d5000198135ca?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Fireball_Photo_0107\" height=\"960\" width=\"960\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Werner Herzog behind the scenes of &#34;Fireball: Visitors From Darker Worlds.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Apple TV&#43;</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In the documentary, Herzog and Oppenheimer visit the Vatican, where a Jesuit priest named Brother Guy Consolmagno presides over an <a href=\"http://www.vaticanobservatory.va/content/specolavaticana/en/research/facilities/meteorite-collection.html\">extensive meteorite collection</a>. The film also includes shaky footage of the Black Stone, a sacred rock in the city of Mecca that Muslims circle during their pilgrimages. It <a href=\"https://opentextbc.ca/astronomyopenstax/chapter/meteorites-stones-from-heaven/\">might be a meteorite</a>, though researchers have not been allowed to study it.&#160;</p><p>\"We found footage shot by a Pilgrim on his cell phone,\" Herzog said of the footage shown. \"Like metal particles attracted by a magnet, everybody's converging and screaming in this hustle, and jockeying for position for touching or kissing it. It's just phenomenal, phenomenal.\"</p><p>Each scene in the film relates to the central premise: that wherever they've fallen, meteorites have shaped human political and religious life.&#160;</p><p>\"These are stones that are falling from the heavens,\" Oppenheimer told Business Insider. \"This is some clue that the gods are intervening in human affairs.\"</p><p>Of course, the documentary does not neglect Earth's most famous asteroid impact. About 66 million years ago, a giant space rock <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/asteroid-struck-perfect-angle-to-doom-dinosaurs-study-2020-5\">slammed into the Yucatán Peninsula</a> in modern-day Mexico with a force equivalent to millions of nuclear bombs. It triggered a mile-high tsunami, acidified the oceans, and released billions of tons of sulfur that blocked sunlight and cooled Earth. An estimated three quarters of all plant and animal species on Earth died as a result, including the dinosaurs. That mass extinction eventually paved the way for mammals to reign.&#160;</p><p>\"We probably wouldn't be here ourselves, Homo sapiens, as a species, were it not for this colossal impact,\" Oppenheimer says in the documentary.&#160;</p><p>The impact crater is located near Chicxulub Puerto, which Herzog describes in the film as \"a beach resort so godforsaken you want to cry.\"</p><h2>Tracking space rocks before they hit</h2><p>Asteroids at any time have the potential to impact the world's future, the new film reminds viewers.&#160;</p><p>In the documentary's second half, Herzog and Oppenheimer visit the Pan-STARRS Operational Center in Hawaii, where astronomers scan rows of computer monitors for signs of asteroids that might become meteorites by entering Earth's atmosphere.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faea9231e8d5000198135c7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Fireball_Photo_0104\" height=\"2688\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Clive Oppenheimer with Mark Willman and Joanna Bulger at the Pan-STARRS Observatory, Haleakalā, Hawaii in &#34;Fireball: Visitors From Darker Worlds.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Apple TV&#43;</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Of the 25 million bits and chunks of space debris that become meteors, most burn up in the atmosphere. Even most of the ones that land, becoming meteorites, are too tiny to make much of an impact either.&#160;&#160;</p><p>If the Pan-STARRS team does detect a large asteroid, their options then depends on its size. The group could likely warn people living in the asteroid's path. But a very large space rock — say a few kilometers in diameter — could crash with the force of the Chicxulub asteroid, and escape would be impossible.</p><p>Programs like Pan-STARRS also don't catch everything; NASA's scanning program, for instance, detected less than half of all <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/asteroid-detection-mission-neocam-nasa-funding-astronaut-support-2018-11\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"330e94f70b8a553f28ef4a204896f576\">\"city killer\" asteroids</a> larger than about 460 feet wide in 2019.&#160;</p><p>If the Hawaiian observatory detected an asteroid heading toward the US, Herzog said, he knows how he'd spent his last few hours: \"I would start shooting a movie.\"&#160;</p><div Neilson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5faea89c4652d40019744399?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn39@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-32-159_c567ff19dcab43b3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faeab4e1e8d5000198135d2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn91@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-38-740_aa3cb1c6cfcbf363.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faea9e61e8d5000198135ca?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn28@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-28-757_c642a556f7ad93bf.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faea9231e8d5000198135c7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn66@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-37-054_38c8e65bacd11809.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bddq7DawWHI:UHU5vmCYqDE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn11@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-27-558_66d2eb35acc955b7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bddq7DawWHI:UHU5vmCYqDE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn30@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-38-467_b1c3b8d9a3aad616.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bddq7DawWHI:UHU5vmCYqDE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn35@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-30-898_faeafb8d42554d78.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/bddq7DawWHI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn53@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-36-883_43effb4612328d37.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991851},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"A 25-term congressman from Alaska who called COVID-19 the 'beer virus' and said concerns were 'created primarily by hysteria' has tested positive for the disease","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/alaska-congressman-covid-19-positive-after-downplaying-it-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faff1b31c741f0019ac9d88?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Don Young\" height=\"2008\" width=\"4016\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Rep. Don Young, R-Alaska, arrives to hold a news conference on March 7, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Alaska Rep. Don Young has tested positive for COVID-19, he announced Thursday in a tweet, becoming the latest lawmaker to contract the disease.</li>\n<li>Young previously called COVID-19 the \"beer virus\" and suggested its severity was overblown but said Thursday he was feeling \"strong\" following his diagnosis.&#160;</li>\n<li>Young, the longest-serving current member of Congress, is just one of a number of officials who tested positive for the disease after previously downplaying its severity.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Alaska Rep. Don Young on Thursday announced he'd tested positive for COVID-19 after previously downplaying the severity of the coronavirus pandemic.</p><p>\"I am feeling strong, following proper protocols, working from home in Alaska, and ask for privacy at this time,\" the 87-year-old, who is Alaska's only member of the US House of Representatives, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/repdonyoung/status/1326996302765445120\">said in a tweet</a>. \"May God Bless Alaska.\"</p><p>As <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-usa-congressman-idUSKBN27T0BD\">Reuters</a> reported, Young's infection comes after he previously downplayed the severity of the pandemic, arguing in March that concerns related to the virus were \"created primarily by hysteria.\"</p><p>\"I call it the beer virus. How do you like that?\" Young, who recently <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/alaska-at-large-house-election-don-young-alyse-galvin-2020\">won his bid for reelection</a>, said at the outset of the pandemic in the US, according to Reuters. \"Anyway, it attacks us senior citizens. I'm one of you. I still say we have to as a nation, as a state, to go forth with the everyday activities.\"</p><p>Young, the longest-serving current member of Congress, is one of a number of public officials who downplayed the severity of the pandemic before <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/louis-gohmert-tests-positive-coronavirus-refused-wear-masks-2020-7\">themselves testing positive</a>. President Donald Trump in October tested positive for the virus and was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-leaving-hospital-but-not-in-recovery-for-a-week-2020-10\">treated at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland</a>, after months of downplaying the pandemic and flouting public health measures meant to curb the spread.</p><p>Over the past seven days, approximately 5% of all COVID-19 tests administered in the state have returned a positive result, according to data from <a href=\"https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/region/us/alaska\">Johns Hopkins University</a>. There have so far been 22,405 confirmed cases of the disease in Alaska and just under 100 confirmed deaths.</p><p>The US has taken a dramatic turn for the worse in recent weeks as health experts for months have <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/infectious-disease-osterholm-darkest-weeks-of-pandemic-2020-10\">warned about a surge of new cases in the fall and winter months</a>. The current uptick in cases comes just weeks before Thanksgiving and the holiday season, as public officials in scores of states from <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cuomo-prohibits-gatherings-larger-than-10-2020-11\">New York</a> to <a href=\"https://www.foxnews.com/us/north-dakota-governor-announces-statewide-mask-mandate-as-coronavirus-cases-surge\">North Dakota</a> implement new orders to stem the spread of the virus.</p><p>As Reuters noted, Alaska Gov. Mike Dunleavy also sent a text message on Thursday to residents of the state, warning them about an uptick in cases and strain on hospitals.&#160;</p><p>\"No matter what you believe about the virus, the facts are the facts,\" Dunleavy, a Republican, said in a video. \"Hospitalizations and sick health-care workers are reaching untenable levels.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original Perrett)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5faff1b31c741f0019ac9d88?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-36-134_bb1db634e7f173f2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8sA8L_WE1lU:4bXDD9sPGJ0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn21@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-38-265_98eb9dafce019575.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8sA8L_WE1lU:4bXDD9sPGJ0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn86@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-33-648_6d6c5d1f5e3051f9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8sA8L_WE1lU:4bXDD9sPGJ0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn12@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-35-882_4acc1c6c72d8c642.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/8sA8L_WE1lU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn91@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-26-157_49493ed0438daf10.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991833},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Florida residents voted for a $15 minimum wage. Here's how much $15 is really worth in the Sunshine State and other states and cities that have increased their minimum wage.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/15-minimum-wage-value-regional-price-parities-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fac2166b09abb0018625ffd?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Florida coronavirus\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Charles Perez wears a protective face mask and gloves as he waits on tables at the Morada Bay Beach Cafe in Islamorada, Florida, on June 1, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lynne Sladky/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/florida-minimum-wage-rise-vote-amendment-15-tipped-employees-workers-2020-11\">Florida residents voted to increase the minimum wage to $15</a>, a gradual raise that will start with an increase to $10 next September.</li>\n<li>But $15 in one state may not get you as far as in another state with a lower cost of living.</li>\n<li>Using 2018 regional price parities data from the <a href=\"https://www.bea.gov/data/income-saving/real-personal-income-states-and-metropolitan-areas\">Bureau of Economic Analysis</a>, we looked at how much $15 can get you in different states and cities that have approved a $15 minimum wage.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Raising the minimum wage has been a big topic of debate at the city, state, and federal level over the years, with activists and politicians setting a $15 hourly wage as a target benchmark. The value of $15, however, varies depending on an area's cost of living.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/florida-minimum-wage-rise-vote-amendment-15-tipped-employees-workers-2020-11\">Florida</a> voters went to the polls on November 3 and resoundingly backed a minimum wage of $15. Almost <a href=\"https://ballotpedia.org/Florida_Amendment_2,_$15_Minimum_Wage_Initiative_(2020)\">61% of voters</a> supported the referendum, which will be phased in over the next few years until it reaches the full $15 per hour in 2026.</p><p>President-elect Joe Biden also <a href=\"https://joebiden.com/empowerworkers/#\">supports raising the federal minimum wage to $15</a>. The last increase in the nationwide minimum was on July 24, 2009, increasing from $6.55 to $7.25 an hour.</p><p>Supporters of this higher minimum wage believe it will help people earn a living wage and get out of poverty. The Florida Policy Institute wrote in a <a href=\"https://www.floridapolicy.org/posts/statement-on-amendment-2-passage-and-state-policy-landscape\">press release</a> on Election Day that the $15 minimum wage in the state would \"reduce historical pay inequities experienced by women and people of color and increase the income of more than 1 in 4 Florida workers.\"</p><p>However, some are wary of what a minimum wage increase could mean for employment and costs to businesses. A <a href=\"https://frla.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/200907_BAC_FL_EstimatingtheImpactofa15MinimumWageinFlorida.pdf\">study</a> by economists at Miami University and Trinity University in part, which the paper notes was \"prepared with support from Save Florida Jobs, Inc\", found that the state will lose 158,000 jobs by 2026 as a result of the minimum wage increase. The economists used a similar method to a <a href=\"https://www.cbo.gov/publication/55410\">Congressional Budget Office</a> study that estimated a $15 federal minimum wage would help 1.3 million Americans get out of poverty but also would mean 1.3 million job cuts.</p><p>Dean Baker, senior economist at the Center for Economic and Policy Research, told Business Insider that some businesses might also be against a $15 minimum wage because of concerns of higher prices or lower profits. Baker said previous research shows that places that already raised the minimum wage \"substantially\" saw little job loss.</p><p>A raise in the minimum wage doesn't just affect those making this amount but can also boost those already earning slightly higher pay, according to Baker. This is because businesses will likely also have to raise pay for workers whose wages are a bit higher than the minimum.</p><p>Similarly, the <a href=\"https://www.cbo.gov/system/files/2019-07/CBO-55410-MinimumWage2019.pdf\">CBO study</a> found a $15 minimum wage would could also mean an increase in pay for 10 million people who already earn slightly more than this hourly wage. <a href=\"https://www.epi.org/publication/raising-the-federal-minimum-wage-to-15-by-2024-would-lift-pay-for-nearly-40-million-workers/\">David Cooper</a>, senior economic analyst at the Economic Policy Institute, noted that raising the federal minimum wage to $15 by 2024 would lift the pay of 40 million workers and help some people make enough to get out of poverty.</p><p>There is no clear answer whether a higher minimum wage has more benefits or consequences, with <a href=\"https://www.miamiherald.com/miami-com/restaurants/article246987592.html\">business anecdotes</a> and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-15-minimum-wage-election-economy-paychecks-low-workers-2020-10\">academic studies</a> highlighting different outcomes for businesses, workers, and families.</p><h2>The value of a $15 per hour minimum wage</h2><p>The value of $15 varies throughout the US because some places have a higher cost of living. For instance, Hawaii is the most expensive place to live, followed by New York and the District of Columbia. Business Insider decided to look at how much $15 nationally is worth in Florida and other places that have already approved this level.</p><p>In regards to whether the minimum wage should vary depending on how expensive it is to live in a particular state or city Baker said, \"that leads myself and many other economists to think, okay, we want a good federal floor and then states could raise it above that, where they have a cost of living that would warrant that and cities within states could do that.\"&#160;</p><p>Using 2018 regional price parities, which compare the buying power of a dollar, or the cost of living in different states and metro areas across the nation, from the <a href=\"https://www.bea.gov/data/prices-inflation/regional-price-parities-state-and-metro-area\">Bureau of Economic Analysis</a>, we looked at the purchasing power in places that have recently passed minimum wage increases. That is, we looked at how much $15 at the national average can get you in the eight states and select cities that have already approved a $15 minimum wage.</p><p>The following is a look at the value of $15 in these places, along with where the minimum wage currently stands.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\t$15 translates to $11.40 in San Francisco.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fab0a63f7d1cb0019e3affe?format=jpeg\" alt=\"San Francisco\" height=\"2062\" width=\"2750\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jane Tyska/Digital First Media/East Bay Times/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The city let voters <a href=\"https://sfgov.org/olse/minimum-wage-ordinance-mwo\">in 2014</a> decide if they supported a gradual increase to a $15 minimum wage. The minimum wage ordinance raised the wage from <a href=\"https://sfgov.org/olse/historical-wage-rates-definition-government-supported-employee\">$11.05 to $12.25 in May 2015 </a>and reached $15 in 2018. The wage is now adjusted by inflation, and the <a href=\"https://sfgov.org/olse/sites/default/files/minimum%20wage%20poster%202020%20copy.pdf\">current minimum wage is $16.07</a> in San Francisco.</p>\n\t$15 translates to $12.09 in New York City.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4e635d7ed0ee001e25cb17?format=jpeg\" alt=\"New York City skyline\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Westend61/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>In <a href=\"https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-15-minimum-wage-phase-continue-2020-following-dob-analysis-showing#:~:text=%2415%20Minimum%20Wage%20Phase%2Din,-The%20%2415%20minimum&#38;text=For%20workers%20in%20New%20York%20City%20employed%20by%20small%20businesses,on%2012%2F31%2F2019.\">2016</a>, New York State passed a law that had New York City raise the minimum wage to $15 by 2018 for businesses with at least 11 employees and by 2019 for larger businesses. This was part of New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo's plan for minimum wage increases across the state in the <a href=\"https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-15-minimum-wage-phase-continue-2020-following-dob-analysis-showing#:~:text=%2415%20Minimum%20Wage%20Phase%2Din,-The%20%2415%20minimum&#38;text=For%20workers%20in%20New%20York%20City%20employed%20by%20small%20businesses,on%2012%2F31%2F2019.\">2016-2017 state budget</a>.</p><p>The NYC metro area has the highest regional price parity in the state and is 24.1% higher than the national average, making it more expensive than other areas in the state. For instance, $15 in New York City has the same buying power as $12.80 in Ithaca or $11.81 in Rochester.&#160;</p>\n\t$15 translates to $12.24 in Santa Rosa, California.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fac20797f8f4200182a6478?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Santa Rosa California\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melina Mara/The Washington Post/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Although California is raising the minimum wage gradually to $15, this metro area already has a minimum wage of $15 for some businesses under its <a href=\"https://srcity.org/3164/Minimum-Wage\">minimum wage ordinance</a>. The Santa Rosa City Council <a href=\"https://unionhall.aflcio.org/nblc/news/santa-rosa-city-council-votes-give-some-workers-15-minimum-wage-2020#:~:text=The%20Santa%20Rosa%20City%20Council,1%20and%20%2415%20by%202021.\">voted in 2019</a> to raise the minimum wage to $15. Businesses with more than 25 workers reached this rate first in July 2020, two years ahead of when businesses of this size in the rest of California are planned to reach this rate. Santa Rosa businesses with 25 or fewer workers will reach this rate next year.</p>\n\t$15 translates to $12.73 in DC.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c909994fce90018f7b5a1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Washington DC\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Photographer is my life./Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>In 2016, the District of Columbia passed a law to reach $15 in 2020, under the Fair Shot Minimum Wage Amendment Act of 2016 and a unanimous vote by the city council. This was part of the <a href=\"https://mayor.dc.gov/release/mayor-bowser-marks-next-step-toward-15-minimum-wage\">Fight For $15</a> initiative with a plan to gradually increase the minimum wage.</p>\n\t$15 translates to $12.89 in New York State.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7f17a7282c500018c794d1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"manhattan new york\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Alexander Spatari/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>According to the <a href=\"https://www.ny.gov/new-york-states-minimum-wage/new-york-states-minimum-wage#:~:text=The%20Minimum%20Wage%20Act%20(Article,they%20reach%20%2415.00%20per%20hour.\">state's website</a>, minimum wages will continue to increase across the state until $15 is reached. This legislation was passed with the <a href=\"https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-15-minimum-wage-phase-continue-2020-following-dob-analysis-showing#:~:text=%2415%20Minimum%20Wage%20Phase%2Din,-The%20%2415%20minimum&#38;text=For%20workers%20in%20New%20York%20City%20employed%20by%20small%20businesses,on%2012%2F31%2F2019.\">2016-2017 state budget</a>. <a href=\"https://labor.ny.gov/workerprotection/laborstandards/workprot/minwage.shtm\">Long Island and Westchester</a> will reach this figure in 2021. Rates will continue to increase until the state reaches $15. New York City already has a $15 minimum wage.</p>\n\t$15 translates to $13.00 in California.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7635e00ab50d00184adab1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"san jose california\" height=\"1328\" width=\"1771\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Steve Proehl/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>In 2016, California Gov. Jerry Brown signed into law a minimum wage of $15, according to the <a href=\"https://www.ncsl.org/research/labor-and-employment/state-minimum-wage-chart.aspx#:~:text=On%20April%204%2C%20California%20Governor,%2415%20per%20hour%20by%20Jan.\">National Conference of State Legislatures</a>. The state was the first to approve this rate. The timeline for reaching this amount varies based on the size of the business. Businesses with 25 or fewer employees will have this minimum wage in 2023, while larger businesses will reach $15 per hour one year earlier.</p>\n\t$15 translates to $13.02 in New Jersey.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9af60e69331a0011bc6150?format=jpeg\" alt=\"hoboken new jersey\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Fabian Meseberg / EyeEm/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy signed a <a href=\"https://www.nj.gov/governor/news/news/562019/20190204b.shtml#:~:text=Under%20the%20new%20law%2C%20the,hour%20on%20January%201%2C%202024.\">law in February 2019</a> that would gradually increase the minimum wage to $15 by 2024. The law notes that seasonal workers and businesses with five or fewer workers will reach this rate in 2026. The current minimum wage in the state is $11 per hour and will continue to increase by one dollar each year.</p>\n\t$15 translates to $13.29 in Seattle.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fab1344f7d1cb0019e3b02b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Seattle Washington\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matteo Colombo/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>This city's <a href=\"https://www.seattle.gov/laborstandards/ordinances/minimum-wage\">minimum wage ordinance went into effect in 2015</a> after the city council approved of this minimum wage level and Mayor Edward B. Murray signed it into law in <a href=\"http://murray.seattle.gov/minimumwage/\">2014</a>. The minimum wage varies depending on the size of a business. For instance, the minimum wage for businesses with at least 501 employees is set at $16.39 per hour.</p><p>For small businesses, the minimum wage is $13.50 and will continue to increase until reaching $15 and then will be adjusted for inflation. It also differs if you get medical benefits through your employer. For instance, if you work at a company with 500 or fewer employees and your employer pays either $2.25 per hour in tips and/or medical benefits, then the minimum wage is $15.75.</p>\n\t$15 translates to $13.67 in Massachusetts.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f08cf0c4dca68387267043b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Boston Massachusetts\" height=\"1334\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Travelpix Ltd/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Massachusetts passed a bill, known as the \"<a href=\"https://www.mass.gov/news/governor-baker-signs-grand-bargain-legislation\">grand bargain bill</a>,\" in 2018 that included raising the minimum wage to $15 along with some other work benefits like paid family leave, according to <a href=\"https://www.bostonmagazine.com/news/2018/06/21/massachusetts-15-minimum-wage/\">Boston Magazine</a>. The <a href=\"https://www.mass.gov/info-details/massachusetts-law-about-minimum-wage#massachusetts-minimum-wage-\">current minimum wage</a> in the state is $12.75, which went up in January. The minimum wage will continue to increase each January by $0.75 until it reaches $15 in 2023. Tipped workers must also make this current minimum wage through base pay and tip credit.</p>\n\t$15 translates to $13.84 in Maryland.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5efe02624dca68132928fd74?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Baltimore Maryland\" height=\"1334\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Cyndi Monaghan/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The state raised the minimum wage from $10.10 to $11 this past <a href=\"https://www.dllr.state.md.us/labor/wages/minimumwagelaw.pdf\">January</a>. The next increase will happen next January, which will be $11.75 for employers with at least 15 workers and $11.60 for smaller businesses. The wage will continue to increase until large businesses reach $15 in 2025 and smaller businesses reach this in 2026.</p><p>Although the state became the sixth one to approve a gradual increase to $15, not everyone wanted a raise. Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan vetoed the bill because, according to <a href=\"https://www.baltimoresun.com/politics/bs-md-minimum-wage-explainer-20190328-story.html\">The Baltimore Sun,</a> Hogan said it could lead to job cuts and make the state \"less competitive\" where surrounding states had lower wages. The Democratic-majority legislature overrode the veto.</p>\n\t$15 translates to $14.14 in Connecticut.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f0c9c08f34d050f2e18577f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"greenwich connecticut\" height=\"1423\" width=\"1897\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images/DenisTangneyJr</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Connecticut Gov. Ned Lamont passed <a href=\"https://portal.ct.gov/Office-of-the-Governor/News/Press-Releases/2019/05-2019/Governor-Lamont-Signs-Minimum-Wage-Increase\">Public Act 19-4 law in May 2019</a>, and the following October the minimum wage increased from $10.10 to $11 per hour. The current wage is $12 and will continue to increase by a dollar until $15 is reached in 2023, per the <a href=\"https://portal.ct.gov/Office-of-the-Governor/News/Press-Releases/2020/08-2020/Governor-Lamont-Reminds-Residents-That-Minimum-Wage-Is-Scheduled-To-Increase-on-Tuesday#:~:text=%2411.00%20on%20October%201%2C%202019,July%201%2C%202022%3B%20and%20finally\">state government's website</a>. Afterward, the wage will \"become indexed to the employment cost index,\" meaning it will be adjusted for inflation.</p>\n\t$15 translates to $14.91 in Florida.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e84ddc32ff839685c1b7792?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Miami Florida\" height=\"1334\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Miami, Florida\n<p class=\"copyright\">Walter Bibikow/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The Sunshine State just raised the minimum wage to $15 by a referendum. The increase will happen gradually starting with an increase from $8.56 to $10 next September. Florida, which is now the eighth state to approve a $15 minimum wage, will reach a minimum wage of $15 in 2026. Afterward, it will be adjusted for inflation.</p>\n\t$15 translates to $15.29 in Illinois.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ef4f4d4aee6a87211464044?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Napeville, Illinois\" height=\"1413\" width=\"1884\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">DenisTangneyJr/iStock/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The minimum wage in Illinois was raised from $9.25 to $10 <a href=\"https://www2.illinois.gov/idol/Laws-Rules/FLS/Pages/minimum-wage-rates-by-year.aspx\">this past July</a> and will continue to increase by a dollar each January until 2025. Tipped employees in the state could be paid 60% of the minimum wage per the state government's website. Before the state raised the wage to $9.25 in January, the minimum wage stood at $8.25 since 2010 per the <a href=\"https://www2.illinois.gov/idol/Laws-Rules/FLS/Documents/MinimumWageHistoricRates.pdf\">state government's website</a>.</p><p>Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker signed the bill, known as the Minimum Wage Law, in February 2019, according to the <a href=\"https://www.chicagotribune.com/politics/ct-met-illinois-minimum-wage-pritzker-signs-bill-20190219-story.html\">Chicago Tribune</a>. According to the Tribune, businesses with 50 or fewer employees may be eligible for the Minimum Wage Tax Credit, where they can claim a tax credit of 25% of the costs in 2020 to help with some of the expenses associated with raising the minimum wage. That credit will decrease in following years however, according to the <a href=\"https://www.ilga.gov/commission/jcar/admincode/086/086001000V73900R.html\">Illinois General Assembly site</a>.</p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/15-minimum-wage-value-regional-price-parities-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=3UK6ggCgVcc:fStLALlyVLo:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=3UK6ggCgVcc:fStLALlyVLo:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=3UK6ggCgVcc:fStLALlyVLo:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=3UK6ggCgVcc:fStLALlyVLo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 14 Nov 2020 13:50:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fac2166b09abb0018625ffd?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"649ddec225ac1ff50fd2a7cd38aaa398","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn72@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-07-804_de4fa8165d794e48.webp","destWidth":1777,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":130388,"destBytes":130388,"author":"insider@insider.com (Madison Hoff)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fac2166b09abb0018625ffd?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn72@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-07-804_de4fa8165d794e48.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fab0a63f7d1cb0019e3affe?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn69@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-28-177_5f441b84cce46511.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4e635d7ed0ee001e25cb17?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn22@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-36-624_110c57af9193100d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fac20797f8f4200182a6478?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn98@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-37-506_e33e7e367a462e0a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7c909994fce90018f7b5a1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn56@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-32-204_2515151d1380da48.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7f17a7282c500018c794d1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn59@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-26-971_a596136f545cbe8e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7635e00ab50d00184adab1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn37@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-39-264_0f1e89eed9069abc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9af60e69331a0011bc6150?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn79@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-25-000_92f45909d3f26115.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fab1344f7d1cb0019e3b02b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn21@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-24-935_7c7e5911f684d312.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f08cf0c4dca68387267043b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn93@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-37-925_cb22e8b4c88f9412.webp","https://i.insider.com/5efe02624dca68132928fd74?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn23@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-26-417_bfdc1fbe44209cc8.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f0c9c08f34d050f2e18577f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn71@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-33-578_9d54bf18121db681.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e84ddc32ff839685c1b7792?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn8@2020_2/2020/11/14/17-30-39-756_0807d70f731d3cb5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ef4f4d4aee6a87211464044?format=jpeg":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=3UK6ggCgVcc:fStLALlyVLo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn88@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-26-134_cb4196c3a2cebe76.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=3UK6ggCgVcc:fStLALlyVLo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn16@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-26-477_02eb48b591b334af.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=3UK6ggCgVcc:fStLALlyVLo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn8@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-30-725_015169d94f548997.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/3UK6ggCgVcc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn39@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-25-775_1a2a86a4c4f62dda.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991871},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"This California company leases backyards for 99 years to build tiny homes and rent them at affordable rates to fight the housing crisis","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/oby-build-tiny-homes-in-california-to-fight-housing-crisis-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faed14c1c741f0019ac9b64?format=jpeg\" alt=\"1. OBY Exterior Angle\" height=\"1926\" width=\"2569\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>OBY house.\n<p class=\"copyright\">OBY</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>OBY leases backyards in California for 99 years.</li>\n<li>The company builds tiny homes in the yards to rent them out.</li>\n<li>Wood construction and solar panels make the homes relatively environmentally friendly.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>OBY is a housing company that says it can fight climate change and the lack of affordable housing in California at the same time, using tiny homes.</p><p>The model is that <a href=\"https://obyhouse.com/house\">OBY</a>, or \"Our Backyard,\" rents a backyard in the East Bay for 99 years. On that space, it builds a tiny home, which is rented out at below market rate. The homeowners make $500 per month in income, while OBY agrees to take on any maintenance on the homes and finds tenants.</p><p>\"When they sell their house, it transfers with the house,\" cofounder Declan Keefe told <a href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/90540571/this-company-signs-99-year-leases-build-permanently-affordable-backyard-houses\">Fast Company</a>. \"We're purposefully doing that so that we can maintain the affordability long term.\"</p><p><strong><em>Read more: </em></strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/knotel-dramatically-cut-back-portfolio-achieve-profitability-flexible-workspace-2020-11?r=mm-sub\">Knotel plans to scale back its global portfolio by 60% over the next 6 months as the pandemic and financial problems have quashed its once grand ambitions to dominate the flex workspace sector</a></p><p>With high costs of living and a lack of housing, California has recently made it easier to add accessory dwelling units, granny flats, and other tiny homes on property that already has a main home. California Governor Gavin Newsom and San Jose Mayor Sam Liccardo are working together to experiment with possible affordable housing solutions, <a href=\"https://www.citylab.com/equity/2019/04/california-home-prices-affordable-housing-san-jose-rentals/580750/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"850e0eea92b44794a55d72d81799c5e8\">CityLab</a> reported, and Newsom has committed to adding 3.5 million homes to the state by the end of his term. In San Jose, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/affordable-prefab-tiny-homes-in-san-jose-for-backyard-2020-4\">tiny home company Abodu</a> just raised $3.5 million in funding for its ADUs that are preapproved for permits in the city.</p><p>Take a look at what OBY does here.</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tOBY builds 576 square foot backyard homes, with wood frames and wood pulp insulation and solar panels on roofs.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faed2371c741f0019ac9b6a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"5. OBY Front\" height=\"2475\" width=\"3300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>OBY house.\n<p class=\"copyright\">OBY</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAll of the wood in the home's construction is from sustainably harvested forests and sequesters carbon. The company avoids more carbon-intensive materials, like concrete and gypsum board.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faed2f41c741f0019ac9b6f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"7. Exploded\" height=\"2475\" width=\"3300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>OBY house.\n<p class=\"copyright\">OBY</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe homes have two bedrooms, along with a kitchen, bathroom and onsite laundry, and dining/living space.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faeda7c1c741f0019ac9b9f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"6. OBY Plan\" height=\"2475\" width=\"3300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>OBY house.\n<p class=\"copyright\">OBY</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe company says its designs focus on \"compact living,\" with larger open living spaces and smaller sleeping areas.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faeda6f1c741f0019ac9b9e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"4. OBY Kitchen\" height=\"2475\" width=\"3300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>OBY house.\n<p class=\"copyright\">OBY</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe houses come as prefabricated kits, created by a coop of builders and carpenters located throughout the area, rather than at a central factory.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faeddc91c741f0019ac9bb6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"2. OBY Living Dining\" height=\"2180\" width=\"2907\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>OBY house.\n<p class=\"copyright\">OBY</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThen, Oakland-based Arizmendi Construction Cooperative puts the pieces together onsite, including the foundation, plumbing, and electricity.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faede4b402d49001924ee16?format=jpeg\" alt=\"3. OBY Living\" height=\"2475\" width=\"3300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>OBY house.\n<p class=\"copyright\">OBY</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe key to the project is that construction is relatively fast to add to the housing supply in the near term, while the leases last 99 years, and continue even when the house is sold.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faecb91402d49001924ed96?format=jpeg\" alt=\"1. OBY Exterior Angle\" height=\"2550\" width=\"3300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>OBY house.\n<p class=\"copyright\">OBY</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the 2020 13:28:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5faed2371c741f0019ac9b6a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"856a4365583d7ea3b763459ac62e8504","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-14-674_721a55ba9afb1a3e.webp","destWidth":3300,"destHeight":2475,"sourceBytes":278324,"destBytes":278324,"author":"mmeisenzahl@businessinsider.com (Mary Meisenzahl)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5faed14c1c741f0019ac9b64?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn51@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-26-941_6f161ffe13a313f3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faed2371c741f0019ac9b6a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-14-674_721a55ba9afb1a3e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faed2f41c741f0019ac9b6f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn76@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-39-278_15246b15cfb82693.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faeda7c1c741f0019ac9b9f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn31@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-34-236_e960c6a73646a4bb.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faeda6f1c741f0019ac9b9e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn35@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-25-021_91af3809426ec720.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faeddc91c741f0019ac9bb6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn88@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-29-647_607a1f8db21c558f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faede4b402d49001924ee16?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn76@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-24-920_ebebd74ec6f3f865.webp","https://i.insider.com/5faecb91402d49001924ed96?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn58@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-36-964_1d674eb0a6cdbae6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/14/17-30-37-247_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=h4Qf_-JCTg4:mHkUvGyId7M:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn11@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-32-819_a1b652f75fcadd02.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=h4Qf_-JCTg4:mHkUvGyId7M:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn23@2020_3/2020/11/14/17-30-37-475_b366fb8642d51d06.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_1/2020/11/14/17-30-31-512_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=h4Qf_-JCTg4:mHkUvGyId7M:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn59@2020_6/2020/11/14/17-30-33-710_8770da6abe91014d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/h4Qf_-JCTg4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn95@2020_4/2020/11/14/17-30-35-753_d4322facfea26d79.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1605374991886},{"createdTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","updatedTime":"2020-11-15 01:29:51","title":"Joe Biden wins Georgia, the first Democratic presidential victory in the state since 1992","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-wins-georgia-democratic-party-south-presidential-election-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa18f361df1d5001821891e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Biden-Georgia\" height=\"4000\" width=\"6000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President-elect Joe Biden speaks at a drive-in rally in Atlanta during the 2020 presidential campaign.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Joe Biden has won Georgia, according to Decision Desk HQ and Insider, the first Democratic presidential victory in the state since Bill Clinton's narrow win in 1992.</li>\n<li>With nearly all statewide precincts reporting, Biden led Trump by a 0.3% margin (49.5% to 49.2%).</li>\n<li>Due to the closeness of the race, Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger on Wednesday ordered a statewide audit of the presidential election results, which will require each ballot to be counted by hand.</li>\n<li>In winning the state, Biden performed strongly in Atlanta and its populous suburbs.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>President-elect Joe Biden has won Georgia, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/georgia-presidential-election-2020-live-vote-counts-results-2020\">according to Decision Desk HQ and Insider</a>, a huge breakthrough for the Democratic Party in their protracted fight to regain electoral relevancy in the Deep South.</p><p>It is the first time that a Democratic presidential nominee has won the Peach State since Bill Clinton, who, in 1992, carried the state by less than 1% of the vote.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/georgia-presidential-election-2020-live-vote-counts-results-2020\">With nearly all precincts reporting</a>, Biden earned 2,472,154 votes, or 49.5%, compared to 2,458,003 votes, or 49.2%, for President Donald Trump. Biden's statewide lead amounts to 14,152 votes, or 0.3%, out of nearly 5 million votes cast.</p><p>The president-elect has now secured the state's 16 electoral votes, bringing his final Electoral College count to 306, well above the 270 electoral vote threshold for victory. Trump will earn 232 Electoral College votes.</p><p>Due to the closeness of the race, Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger announced on November 11 that <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/georgia-audit-hand-tally-ballots-vote-8fa73ef353b36eddf14e1360eeecc22d\">he would oversee a statewide audit</a> of the presidential race, where every ballot will be counted by hand. Each of Georgia's 159 counties will then have to report final vote totals by November 18, just two days before the state's November 20 deadline for certifying the election results.</p><p>The audit <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-will-georgia-recount-5-million-votes-11605204325\">is not expected the change the overall outcome</a> of the state's results.</p><p>In securing his statewide win, Biden followed the formula of 2018 Democratic gubernatorial nominee Stacey Abrams, routing the opposition in Fulton County, which encompasses Atlanta, while ramping up the vote in DeKalb, Cobb, and Gwinnett counties.&#160;For decades, Cobb and Gwinnett had been suburban Republican strongholds, but in 2016, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/elections/2016/results/georgia\">won both counties</a> with 48% and 50% of the vote, respectively. This year, Biden won Cobb with 56% of the vote and Gwinnett with 58% of the vote.</p><p>After initially trailing Trump in the vote count, Clayton County, with its large Black population, <a href=\"https://www.ajc.com/politics/politics-blog/heart-of-john-lewis-district-deals-blow-to-trump/BCMMSU4ZJFD73AL6MPJCCRPQQM/\">put Biden over the top</a> in the statewide tally. Biden won the suburban Atlanta county with 85% of the vote and a nearly 80,000-vote margin, more than five times his current statewide lead.</p><p>Biden also racked up smaller, but significant margins in outlying Richmond, Muscogee, and Chatham counties, which contain the Democratic-leaning cities of Augusta, Columbus, and Savannah, respectively.</p><p>More than 3.9 million Georgians cast early ballots in the state, which was roughly 51% of all registered voters, <a href=\"https://www.ajc.com/politics/early-voting-brought-record-turnout-in-georgia-ahead-of-election-day/76JRESFLMVEYBGX2J7AAGKABQ4/\">according to the Atlanta Journal-Constitution</a>.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faf2dfb402d49001924efac?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Biden-Warm Springs\" height=\"3712\" width=\"4949\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>During the campaign, Biden gave a speech in Warm Springs, the retreat of former president Franklin D. Roosevelt.\n<p class=\"copyright\">JIM WATSON/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>With its fast-growing Black, Latino, and Asian populations, along with an influx of younger residents and Northern transplants, the Georgia electorate has changed dramatically over the past 20 years. In 2004, white voters made up 70% of the state's electorate, compared to 60% this year, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/08/us/politics/georgia-politics.html\">according to The New York Times</a>.</p><p>The Biden campaign had long eyed Georgia as a potential electoral target, and&#160;<a href=\"https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/will-georgia-turn-blue/\">with increasingly favorable poll numbers</a> and <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/01/stacey-abrams-biden-georgia-433799\">a personal push by Abrams</a>, Biden made a late bid to win the state.</p><p>On October 27, Biden&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/27/us/politics/joe-biden-georgia-polls.html\">traveled to Georgia</a> for the first time since winning the Democratic presidential nomination, giving a speech in Warm Springs, the retreat&#160;of former president Franklin D. Roosevelt, and <a href=\"https://www.ajc.com/politics/biden-races-to-expand-election-map-with-todays-georgia-visit/HETO7YWW65DYPFH3K5MEZQENFM/\">holding a drive-in rally</a> in Atlanta.</p><p>On November 2, the day before the general election, former president Barack Obama <a href=\"https://www.ajc.com/politics/politics-blog/obamas-plea-to-georgia-democrats-put-this-country-back-on-track/ABCRLHULMJHI5BHSB6WMF44ABA/\">held an outdoor rally</a> for Biden in Atlanta, promoting the candidacy of his former No. 2.</p><p>\"Georgia could be the state,\" Obama said. \"Georgia could be the place where we put this country back on track.\"</p><p>In January 2021, the state <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/georgia-senate-runoff-elections-jon-ossoff-david-perdue-warnock-loeffler-2020-11\">will also determine which party will control the US Senate</a>, courtesy of two runoff elections.&#160;</p><p>Republican Sen. David Perdue <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/georgia-senate-race-david-perdue-vs-jon-ossoff-polls-fundraising-2020-8\">faces a stiff challenge</a> from Democrat Jon Ossoff. In the November election, Perdue led Ossoff by a 49.7% to 48% margin. However, under state law, a Senate candidate must receive at least 50% of the vote to win an election, which prompted the runoff.</p><p>The <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kelly-loeffler-vs-doug-collins-georgia-senate-election-polls-fundraising-2020-8\">second Senate runoff</a> is the result of a November special election that featured appointed Republican Sen. Kelly Loeffler, Democrat Raphael Warnock, and a multitude of candidates from different political parties. Loeffler and Warnock were the top two vote-getters in the race, but since neither candidate received over 50% of the vote, they are both advancing to a separate runoff election.</p><p>Democrats currently have 48 Senate seats, compared to 50 seats for the GOP. If Democrats can win both Senate seats, the chamber would be split 50-50, but Vice President-elect Kamala Harris will have the ability to break tie votes, which would give the party majority control.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-wins-georgia-democratic-party-south-presidential-election-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=KK8sNJmrxcU:Wi8WIukdTe8:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=KK8sNJmrxcU:Wi8WIukdTe8:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=KK8sNJmrxcU:Wi8WIukdTe8:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=KK8sNJmrxcU:Wi8WIukdTe8:V_sGLiPBpWU\"
